四.story: FOUR year-olds often put their FOOT (human legs) in their MOUTH - but they are too young to realize.

六.story: Indicating 6 parts of the human body: head, body, 2 arms, 2 legs.

七.story: This kanji is our good old seven, turned upside down.

八.story: Hachi" (eight) begins with the sound of the katakana "ha", and it's approximately the same character.

九.story: Kinda of looks like the kanji of 1　一 with the kanji of 8 八added. So think of it as 一＋八＝九.

十.story: Two needles crossing marks the spot, or you can use the Roman character for ten (rotated 45 degrees).

口.story: Looks like a huge open mouth.

月.story: A month is longer than a day.

田.story: A rice field divided into four parts.

古.story: Tombstone and cross on an old man's grave.

冒.story: Don't look at the sun directly with your eyes, it's risky!

朋.story: My companion and I are like two moons side by side.

明.story: The sun makes the moon bright.

唱.story: Someone chanting with their mouth open for two consecutive days.

晶.story: A diamond sparkles as brightly as three suns.

品.story: Three boxes of goods are devoured by the hungry mouths of waiting consumers.

昌.story: If you work from Sun UP to Sun DOWN you will be prosperous.

早.story: The sun up is early, well before ten.

旭.story: 9am carries with it the rising sun.

胃.story: The rice field is harvested once a month to get food for our stomach.

旦.story: A nightbreak happens when the sun rises over the horizon (floor).

胆.story: The moon has a lot of gall sticking around after sunrise.

亘.story: The sun spans from horizon to horizon in a day.

凸.story: When I get vexed, I give people the middle finger.

自.story: To use an eyedropper by oneself, aim from above to put a drop into the eye.

白.story: A white ray is a drop of sun.

百.story: 100 turned sideways. sort of the same as what ashoksaraf said.

千.story: It takes many drops of ten to get to a thousand.

舌.story: A thousand mouths speak the same TONGUE.

升.story: It is a thousand or ten? I need my measuring box.

昇.story: This kanji does not mean "get up" or "awake." It means rising, like the rising of a salary, or a promotion. STORY: You know that your salary has RISEN UP when your MEASURING BOX has enough dollar bills in it to reach the SUN.

丸.story: Nine plus a drop rounds it off to ten!

寸.story: The decimal system uses drops of ten as a measurement.

肘.story: The elbow is the flesh that glues together the upper and lower arm.

専.story: After you have chosen your 10 fields of study, measure how good you are at each to find out your specialty.

博.story: Ten specialties grants you the title of Dr. with a dot.

占.story: Fortune-telling: using a mouth as a divining rod.

上.story: A magic wand standing on above the floor.

卓.story: The most eminent magician is he who learned to use his magic wand early in life.

朝.story: There is mist as the moon fades away in the morning.

嘲.story: When I wake up, I am always late, so I hurry to work. With a bad case of perpetual morning breath, I am the subject of derision at my office whenever I open my mouth.

只.story: Imagine an animal with only a mouth and legs.

貝.story: Stare at the shellfish, it looks like an eye with legs.

唄.story: The new generation of pop songs have no depth. They just mouth empty lyrics to get money. Not like the pop songs of my day.

貞.story: A magic wand is needed to make a clam stand upright.

員.story: An employee (member of the company) has to clam up his mouth if he wants keep the job!

貼.story: Fortune teller writes your fortune on a piece of paper and tells you to affix it to a shell and throw into the ocean for it to come true. Picture licking the back of the shell like a stamp and affixing it to the fortune.

見.story: As a primitive, this is Mike Wazowski from Monsters Inc. (the giant eyeball with legs...) Makes for easy stories later on.

児.story: In the olden times, a newborn babe came out legs first.

元.story: In the beginning were just two who walked on human legs.

頁.story: A shellfish carrying a page balanced on its head.

頑.story: A stubborn person in the beginning gets something into their head and can't change their mind.

凡.story: A drop of breeze is naught but a mediocre wind.

負.story: Tied up, the shellfish had to accept defeat!

万.story: I bound ten thousand dollars together and hid it under the floor.

句.story: Some Japanese phrases are difficult to wrap your mouth around.

肌.story: When you expose your flesh to the wind it gets textured: goosebumps!

旬.story: Hint: Here's info from Wikipedia regarding why this kanji exists, which helped me remember it: [Japan also divides the month roughly into three 10-day periods. Each is called a jun (旬). The first is jōjun (上旬); the second, chūjun (中旬); the last, gejun (下旬). These are frequently used to indicate approximate times, for example, "the temperatures are typical of the jōjun of April"; "a vote on a bill is expected during the gejun of this month."].

的.story: I managed to hit the bull's eye by throwing my white ladle.

首.story: One has a strong NECK if one can carry HORNS on ONESELF.

乙.story: This is a fish hook, that pulls out the fishguts.

乱.story: The riot police broke up the riot by dragging the rioters away by their tongues with fishooks.

直.story: If you get a needle in your eye that is hooked in there, get to a hospital straightaway.

具.story: Keep an eye on your tools while you work at the table.

真.story: A compass is a tool with a needle on top that points to true north.

工.story: I-beams are used to CRAFT skyscrapers.

左.story: The LEFT side of my brain posesses the faculties needed for logical crafts, like engineering.

右.story: The right side of my brain is for speaking.

有.story: Possessed by the Earth's gravity, the moon stays by its side.

賄.story: If you possess enough shellfish, you can bribe anyone.

貢.story: This next song is a TRIBUTE to a little SHELLFISH friend of mine who was tragically crushed by an I-shaped table.

項.story: To write a paragraph is the craft of grouping sentences on a page.

刀.story: This SWORD is so sharp, it can cut the top part of カ off in カタナ.

刃.story: The part of a sword where a drop of blood can usually be found is the blade.

切.story: The seven samurai used their swords to cut their opponents.

召.story: To seduce is to make a sword of one's mouth.

則.story: When you have both money and the power of the sword, you can make the rules.

副.story: The wealthy guy with the sword standing next to the king, that's the vice-roy who does all the dirty work.

別.story: I don't know about you but to me this seems like someone's head is about to be separated from his body. You can see he's kneeling and his mouth is wide open gasping for the last breath he will ever take.

丁.story: Today, the program "Sesame Street" is brought to you by the letter "T".

町.story: Actually this means town, like one that has lots of streets and is surrounded by all the rice fields.

可.story: A mouth on the street asking for things: "Can I get some help?! Can I get directions, Can I have some money? Can you please speak English?!

頂.story: If I put a street sign on my head what do I get ? A place on the head !

子.story: A child who is ten will still ask for his ma (top looks a bit like katakana ma).

孔.story: The child's arms flailed around at the sight of the hooked tool the dentist was going to use to fill his cavity.

了.story: The experiment was a complete failure! The child was made without any arms!

女.story: To remember the order of strokes, remember a female ninja is called a "kunoichi". That is, く(hiragana) ノ(katakana) 一(kanji, ichi=one).

好.story: A woman is fond of her child.

如.story: A likeness to the Mona Lisa depends on a woman's mouth.

母.story: The two breasts of a momma who breastfeeds.

貫.story: Ariel the Little Mermaid's clamshell bra was held to her breasts by piercings.

兄.story: My elder brother was basically a mouth on legs when he was a teenager.

呪.story: Caution: this means a spell, not to swear. I put a curse on my elder brother so that he can never open his mouth.

克.story: Ten elder brothers can overcome anything.

小.story: A little penguin with its wings at its side.

少.story: Only a few people can make an ugly face like that.

大.story: A person stretching their arms and legs to look large and scare a bear away.

夕.story: The evening is young, the moon is not full.

汐.story: Eventide is just another word for evening, and it has the word tide in it which we associate with water.

外.story: A young magician likes to practice outside in the evening with his magic wand (as opposed to the old magician who wakes early to practice with his wand in 卓 (#52)).

名.story: In the evening, when it becomes dark, open your mouth to say your name so that people can recognise you.

石.story: Indiana Jones jumps up and grabs the lip of cliff just in time to evade the huge STONE rolling out of the mouth of the cave!

肖.story: It doesn't hold a candle to the real thing. They share a resemblance at most.

硝.story: That stone has sparks coming out of it! Someone must have poured nitrate acid on it.

砕.story: To SMASH a STONE you need to hit it NINE or TEN times.

砂.story: Here's how I remember that stone is on the left. This is because sand starts as stones, and only later they become few.

妬.story: The jealous woman bashed the brains in of the guy who betrayed her, with a stone.

削.story: Sparks will fly if you attempt to PLANE your sabre.

光.story: A ray of light is not a wave but made of little photons with human legs.

太.story: A large person with a big drop of sweat dripping off of him because he is so plump.

器.story: Imagine four hungry mouths all sitting around the table. They are all banging their utensils on the table waiting for a big meal to be placed in the centre.

臭.story: The ST. BERNARD DOG lifted his large NOSE high in the air to find out where the stinking smell comes from.

嗅.story: Your mouth stinks: you need to sniff your breath.

妙.story: Exquisite women are few and far between.

省.story: You focus by concentrating your eye on fewer objects.

厚.story: The thick cliff walls protected the children from the sun.

奇.story: Imagine a ST. BERNARD DOG carrying a CAN instead of a barrel in rescue missions. How strange!

川.story: So as not to confuse this with 河 (#157) think of streamers falling down.

州.story: There were 3 little islands in the stream who all decided to set themselves up as independent states.

順.story: Obey, Obey!" says the brain-washing scientist as he sends a stream of orders to fill your head.

水.story: The kanji for water is an abstract primitive itself, so unless one is willing to break down its etymological development, it should just simply be memorized by strokes; constructing a story is not necessarily useful unless it strongly denotes its shape (I find that Heisig's story doesn't do this).

氷.story: Icicles start with 1 frozen drop of water.

永.story: It would take an eternity to count all the drops of water.

泉.story: White is a symbol of purety, so white water is pure water, the precise definition of spring water.

腺.story: A body part that acts like a spring for hormones is a gland.

原.story: Follow the springs down the cliff and you will find a nice meadow.

願.story: Let's petition to save that beautiful MEADOW from overdevelopment by signing on this PAGE.

泳.story: If you don't know how to swim, you'll be in that water for eternity.

沼.story: A marsh is where water is seduced into the ground.

沖.story: Open sea is a lot of water in the middle of nowhere.

汎.story: This is pan- as in the prefix meaning "all". I think of Pangea as being a mediocre continent with water covering the rest of the planet. This was before it broke up into the first-class, well-distributed continents we got now.

江.story: A CREEK is a small trail of water easily crafted with a stick.

汰.story: I couldn't find any reference to this kanji as meaning cleanse. It seems to be most often used in the following compound 沙汰（さた）to mean affair. The other meanings seem to be closer to 'select' so maybe Heisig meant cleanse in the ethnic sense here.. I'm going to use the keyword "selection", as in natural selection. Story: natural selection first began in the water, and those that were too plump were selected out.

汁.story: To make soup you just take water and add (+) the rest of your ingredients.

沙.story: To keep this separated from 砂 (#122): Water erodes away stone a few grains of sand at a time until there is no stone left.

潮.story: The morning tide is basically, well, WATER in the MORNING.

源.story: The water that flows from the meadow is the source of life for the wild antelope.

活.story: Conversations can become more lively after everyone has had a few drinks. It's because "watery tongues" loosen lips!

消.story: To extinguish a SPARK, you need WATER.

況.story: If you ask your teenager if what he's drinking is water (and not Vodka), he will answer "but of course".

河.story: A river CAN exist only if there is WATER.

泊.story: Please supply a guest who stays overnight with WATER and WHITE sheets.

湖.story: This is my favorite story. Simply associate the sad moment of an OLD person, standing near the WATER of the lake and looking at the MOON reflected in the lake. The created primitives themselves are put so beautifully, that you will not forget this kanji.

測.story: A fathom is the unit you use when making rules about water's depth.

土.story: Remembering soil is easy. If soil is soft, you can take a walking stick and plunge it two* feet into the ground.

吐.story: SPIT goes from my MOUTH to the GROUND.

圧.story: The GROUND at the base of a CLIFF must suffer from enormous pressure.

埼.story: This refers to LAND, not the STRANGE gear superheroes wear.

垣.story: Before the Great Wall of China, there was a dirt hedge that spanned across.

填.story: In a hole in the ground, the body of the victim was placed. And then the killer stuffed it up so that the truth would not be found out, he hoped.

圭.story: Piling SOIL upon SOIL for aeons is how SQUARE JEWELS are formed deep in the earth.

封.story: The king used a special seal of ivy leaves glued onto his document.

涯.story: Try to reverse Heisig's story in this Kanji: imagine being trapped in one of those prison towers on an ivy cladcliff like in the movies. From your prison ontop the ivy clad cliff all you can see in the distant horizon is nothing but water.

寺.story: At the Buddhist temple the monks are seated on the ground, glued there in meditation.

時.story: When the SUN starts to shine on the TEMPLE, it's time to get up.

均.story: Soil is scooped up into a ladel. The extra drop is brushed off to make it level.

火.story: For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on fire!

炎.story: To fight fire with fire would just inflame a situation.

煩.story: An anxiety feels like FIRE in the HEAD.

淡.story: Drink water and burn twice as many calories as you eat... you'll definitely get thin. Imagine inside your body, all those calories literally being burned from above and below... THAT's what it takes to become thin.

灯.story: Imagine old gas lamps which had a flame to light up the street signs.

畑.story: Many farms are created by first setting FIRE over the land to clear the land for the FIELDS.

災.story: What a disaster! First a FIRE, then on top of it came FLOODs.

灰.story: The fire underneath the cliff will eventually turn everything above to ashes.

点.story: The FORTUNE TELLER was burned by FLAMES on the spot because she was accused of being a witch.

魚.story: The elements of this kanji are bound up, rice field and cooking fire. When I think of bound up cooked rice, it makes me think of sushi, which in turn brings to mind fish.

漁.story: You need WATER and FISH for fishing.

里.story: The ri is a Japanese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.

黒.story: If you burn the GROUND of a RICE FIELD with FIRE, eventually it will turn black.

墨.story: Theres BLACK on the GROUND...most likely someone spilt some black ink.

鯉.story: Japanese carp are massive fish - they are measured in ri!

量.story: I did such a quantity of work that when NIGHT BREAK came, I was asleep on the COMPUTER.

厘.story: I threw my Rindows computer off a cliff because it kept crashing. Now, after its last crash, it's worth less than a rin.

埋.story: You can't bury computers underground, because of the dangerous heavy metals, so you hide them behind an equally large mound of soil and hope no-one notices.

同.story: Imagine monks wandering around the monastery. Covered in their hoods and chanting as if with one mouth they all look the same !

洞.story: All the animals in the den share the same water.

胴.story: Dead flesh all looks the same when you chop off everything but the trunk. Yes, I'm appalled at how gruesome this story is too.

向.story: Look over yonder ! That tiny dot is robin hood at the mouth of his secret cave !

尚.story: An especially esteemed alien has three antennae on his helmet.

字.story: CHILDren learn Kanji characters underneath a HOUSE.

守.story: A GUARD is usually "glued" to the house he watches.

完.story: Make the perfect impression in the beginning by removing your shoes upon entering a Japanese home.

宣.story: You can proclaim your opinions from the comfort of your HOUSE and have it SPAN the entire globe these days via The Internet.

宵.story: I burn the CANDLE in my HOUSE until the WEE HOURS reviewing the kanji!!!

安.story: It's funny, Hesig gives no Kanji in his book that means cheap/inexpensive... well... if you were wondering what Kanji would carry that meaning, look no further. Sometimes I wonder if Hesig just thinks our little brains would be too easily confused by multiple meanings. Regardless, think of that woman relaxing. Cheapest place to do that is in one's own home rather than at some fancy resort, eh? 家で休暇を取るは安いですね。.

宴.story: The WOMAN spent all DAY preparing a banquet in the HOUSE.

寄.story: The strange house has a sign saying "DRAW NEAR" in its window, instead of a 'Beware' sign. It must be a trick!

富.story: In ancient Japan, a RICE FIELD is a unit of wealth as it can produce enough to feed all the MOUTHs in ONE HOUSE.

貯.story: It takes a lot more than one clam of savings to buy a house on a street.

木.story: If you need a story for a tree, then you need to be hit by one.

林.story: A grove has at least two TREEs.

森.story: The higher you go up a mountain the less trees there are, that's so u dont mess up with their possition like i do.

桂.story: Simple mnemonic : "The Japanese Judas-tree is the tree on which Judas hang himself to the ivy" (Judas the traitor of the Christian bible). Just picture Judas hanging himself, using ivy as a if it was a rope.

柏.story: The wood from oak trees can be used to make barrels in which white wine is aged. What's more, I love white wine with an oaky flavour...

梢.story: At Christmas time, on the treetops, people used to place great big candles (Now we usually place a star instead).

棚.story: A shelf is a wooden companion to books.

杏.story: From the tree straight into the mouth is the best way to eat an APRICOT!

桐.story: In Japan, a paulownia (きり）is known as the "princess tree". It was once a traditional TREE planted at the SAME time as the birth of a daughter. It would grow fast enough that, at the time of her wedding, it could be used to make a dresser as a wedding present for her.

椅.story: To the Japanese, the first time they saw a chair, it looked like a strange use of wood! Probably why they still like to sit on the floor...

枯.story: A tree withers away as it gets old.

朴.story: Wooden wands are the crudest. They are nothng compared to their carbon fibre equivilents.

村.story: If you've ever played an old 8 bit or 16 bit RPG, like Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy or Inindou, you'll remember that every town was all bordered off by a line of trees with no space in between to get out through. Imagine that the trees were glued together so you could only exit town through the main or side gates, (so you couldn't escape the important scripted scenes.)

相.story: ソウ/ショウ/あ INTER /MUTUAL /ASPECT /PHASE /MINISTER. "Long ago, before there were telephones, people living far from one another would climb trees to eye each other's aspects and inter-act for their mutual benefit. Those who did this best became government ministers, with the top person (perhaps the one with the longest neck (首, 首 (#74)) becoming the prime minister 「首相 (しゅしょう)".

机.story: My wooden desk is so messy, it looks like a strong wind blew my things all over it.

本.story: The origin of a book is paper made out of TREEs. ONE tree can make many books.

札.story: Botanists like to identify TREEs by HOOKing tags on them.

暦.story: Years-Months-Days: It takes many years for a cliff to form or erode. A tree takes many months to grow. But days pass by regularly - so in this way, we see the movement of time such as with a CALENDAR.

案.story: I plan to RELAX on top of that TREE.

燥.story: Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "furniture" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (FRAME 215) , 操 (#724), 繰 (#1469), 藻 (#2191). Story: It's been so parched recently that your furniture suddenly catches fire.

未.story: I believe a better version of that by mameha1977: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) does not yet (未) have exremities (末) of vermilion (朱).

末.story: The tree has reached the extremity of its growth and no longer produces small, new branches at the top. Instead the existing top branch just grows longer and longer.

昧.story: Something that is obscure has not yet been brought before the light of day.

沫.story: The extremity of a wave of water is the splash.

味.story: My mouth has not yet swallowed the food because the flavor is so delicious that I keep chewing it.

妹.story: My younger sister is NOT YET a fully grown WOMAN.

朱.story: It's autumn: only one vermilion leaf on the tree has not yet fallen.

株.story: Which tree would you buy stocks in - the healthy one on the left, or the one with only one vermilion leaf left on the right?

若.story: The young little girl held a cute flower in her right hand.

草.story: Grass grows in earlier than flowers.

苦.story: Flowers for the old man suffering in the hospital.

苛.story: How many flowers can I stuff in your nostrils? Well I'm just gonna have to go and see." Bullying at its worst!

寛.story: To be tolerant is to see flowers (meaning "beautiful things") in every house, instead of looking for drawbacks.

薄.story: A Dr. missing his needle can only use dilute flower water for medicine.

葉.story: On top of the leaves a flower appears, promising new generations for the old tree below.

模.story: If I find out this furniture you're selling me is made of imitation wood, I'll put you in the graveyard.

漠.story: The precise locations of sailors who meet a WATERY GRAVE are vague.

墓.story: The soil under a graveyard is full of graves.

暮.story: He made a livelihood out of robbing GRAVEYARDS in broad DAYlight.

膜.story: In the moonlight of the graveyard I hear a zombie say, MMMMM..EMM...BRANEsssss.

苗.story: If you plant seedlings in a FIELD eventually they will FLOWER.

兆.story: A bad portent makes the hairs on your legs stand.

桃.story: The pits of a peach tree look like turtles.

眺.story: Sauron's One fiery eye stare at Frodo and it is a sign of portent. Evil will become whomever the eye is staring upon.

状.story: It was left to the turtle to make right with the dog and thus maintain the status quo.

黙.story: The computer won't stop beeping, which is making the chihauhua bark, and it's driving this guy insane. The only solution he can come up with is to throw them both on the fire and finally enjoy the silence.

然.story: Flesh of a dog over a cooking fire = "hotdog". There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. Believe me, you don't want to know what sort of things . Visualize the hotdog curling as it cooks, to remember the unusual way the flesh primitive curves in this kanji. (tweaked version of ziggr's. Thanks!)

荻.story: REEDS are the only FLOWERS that WILD DOGS like to FIRE up and smoke while they are playing poker.

狩.story: Actually when hunting it may be a good idea to use a pack of dogs as your personal guard.

猫.story: The cat hid in the FLOWERS of the FIELD from the WILD DOGs.

牛.story: A cow tried to climb up a vermilion tree, but in doing so, it broke its two bottom branches off.

特.story: Think of not special people, but special animals. The sacred Hindu cows are special - they can wander around the temple without fear of becoming roast beef.

告.story: The revelation makes the cow's mouth drop down, "Hamburgers are made of what?!

先.story: I've never seen a cow with human legs before!

洗.story: In Japan, you always wash with water from the shower before you enter the bathtub.

介.story: The two strokes at the bottom look like a J and I, which stands for "jammed in.

界.story: One Japanese farmer I know is so small minded that he thinks the entire world is JAMMED IN the borders of his little RICE FIELD.

茶.story: Some people think drinking tea is boring and quaint. That's why I spice mine up by adding a cocktail umbrella, which of course is made from a wood-en toothpick supporting a paper umbrella with flowers printed on top.

脊.story: Look", says the teacher in biology class. "The spinal column holds your flesh together, just like the metal rod of this umbrella (he demonstrates this with an umbrella covered in I-Ching symbols) holds the umbrella together".

合.story: He had such a big mouth that he could easily fit one whole umbrella in it.

塔.story: In order to build a pagoda in this small Japanese garden everything has to fit: the soil to the left and the flowers in the upper right corner.

王.story: A King is one（一） who rules over the land （土soil）.

玉.story: The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...

宝.story: On treasure island is a single house - where all the jewels are stored.

珠.story: The king of the Oysters produces special Vermillion pearls!

現.story: The KING ... can SEE clearly the PRESENT state of affairs in the land. (maybe he hees them in the crystal ball on the left?)

玩.story: Even the king played with toys in the beginning.

狂.story: Oh no ! A pack of dogs has bitten the king. He has turned into a rabid lunatic !

旺.story: The Sun King (Louis XIV) was known for his effulgent reign.

皇.story: Ancient Rome had Emperors instead of Kings, and they wore white robes. Thus an emperor is a king in white. (make sure you picture a roman emperor not a japanese one and you'll be ok).

呈.story: The mouth of the king is displaying his bling.

全.story: The fat king hogs the whole space under his umbrella. (tweaked version of radical tyro's story. "fat" makes a more vivid image for me.)

栓.story: The fat king under his umbrella offers useless advice to the workers. "You'll need the whole tree to plug that gap". Imagine a grossly fat, incompetent king under a parasol giving annoying advice to sweating workers who know what they're doing. (I always have trouble bringing up the "whole" primitive. This story reminds me how to build that part. ).

理.story: The king of LOGIC is the computer.

主.story: A lord is a little drop down from King in hierarchy.

柱.story: The main pillar in a house should be made of the biggest and strongest tree - the lord of the trees.

金.story: The fat king taking up the whole space under the umbrella actually isn't fat - he just has two big gold bars hidden under his clothes.

銑.story: Pig-iron is crude metal (金) before (先) it is refined. If you have trouble with this character, envision a big minotaur (cow head with human legs) as a blacksmith, smelting metals and making swords for war.

鉢.story: This is the BOWL of an alchemist: see how he mixes metals in his bowl, as he follows the instructions from his book?

銅.story: I can't believe no one has used this one yet: Copper is metal which looks almost the same as gold. Really, look it up on Wikipedia, it's yellow and it's shiny (atleast in some compounds)!

釣.story: All the people that go to the Japanese festivals to catch fish part time are suckers. Me? I'm a pro. I bring a big-ass golden ladle. I'm a true ANGLING professional.

針.story: Remember the story of the needle in the haystack. Why would someone even look for a needle if it wasn't a GOLD NEEDLE?

銘.story: A piece of metal with a name on it. Well, this is basically the definition of inscription.

鎮.story: Tranquilize - using a metal syringe to get the truth.

道.story: When we go out on the ROAD-WAY, we often risk our own necks (that's why I take the train! ).

導.story: For guidance on the road-way, glue a GPS unit to your car.

迅.story: The car went too swiftly through the crossing and was hooked by the cops.

造.story: A cow creates a road by eating all the grass on its path.

迫.story: White lines on the road are there to urge you to stay on the correct side of the street.

逃.story: MARIO KART: When you're blasting down the road in Mario Kart, it's REALLY hard to escape from turtle shells. Especially the red and blue ones!!

辺.story: Caution: this kanji doesn't mean environment; it means "environs; boundary; border; vicinity". To separate the environs, create the border by placing daggers on the road.

巡.story: The cops don't PATROL anymore - they just flood the road.

車.story: My car is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.

連.story: When you put your car on the road you should always take along a few friends. Don't confuse with 運 (#303).

軌.story: My car got so stuck in a rut it required nine people pushing to get it out again.

輸.story: The car is a cattle-car, used to transport animals for the butcher's meeting - a convention on new butchering techniques. Hear the screams of the animals as it pulls up in front of the convention hall, where the butchers are waiting with their knives out front.

喩.story: Metaphorically speaking, all the equipment in your mouth is basically just a meeting of butchers, designed to pulverize whatever meat you put in there.

前.story: If you stand in front of a bull's horns, you are asking for your flesh to be cut (or butchered if you prefer).

煎.story: In many asian restaurants, meat is roasted right in front of you over flames.

各.story: Each person is gifted with a mouth to get us into trouble and a pair of walking legs to get us out!

格.story: Ranger! I want you to go check the status of each tree." "Errr, Each tree sir?" replies the ranger looking out over the vast forest. "That's Right, I want the status of each tree! Move out!

賂.story: It might sound simple to bribe someone, but then you have to graft the guy above him and the guy below him, and soon you're just giving shells to each and everyone!

略.story: There are so many abbreviations and acronyms nowadays that no brain can remember each of them. Mnemonic: ab-brain-each-ation.

客.story: Each person under my roof is treated as a guest.

額.story: Sign the guestbook page with your forehead. (Picture a guestbook full of forehead prints like thumbprints).

夏.story: In SUMMER you are hot from the top of your head down to your walking legs.

処.story: The best way to dispose of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you.

条.story: They all say they have a TREE between their WALKING LEGS but most only have a TWIG.

落.story: Water each flower or the petals will wither and fall.

冗.story: The king's crown was blown off by the wind. "Oh well," he said, "it's just a superfluous symbol.

冥.story: The beast of hades one day will wear a crown, and the number of the beast is 666.

軍.story: British army cars are at the service of the crown.

輝.story: Rays of light emitted from Apollo's chariot = radiance. Don't put the sun into this kanji. The rays are coming from the chariot directly!

運.story: Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to carry military supplies (sorry no room for you).

冠.story: Remember the SUPERFLUOUS CROWN that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying "i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING".

夢.story: Last night's date with Miss Sweden was like a dream. She even laid flowers over my eyes to crown the perfect evening.

坑.story: A whirlwind digs a hole in the ground throwing out lots of dirt until it ends up with a giant pit.

高.story: Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and top hat, trying to look TALL. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth.

享.story: In basketball however, tall children receive all the attention.

塾.story: Welcome to our cram school: you will receive a rounded education on our grounds.

熟.story: Imagine tall children sitting round the fire toasting marsh-mellows.

亭.story: The tallest Pavilion crowns the street.

京.story: Tokyo, capital of Japan: tall buildings, small people (compared to the buildings).

涼.story: When you're a tourist in the capital during the heat of summer, finding a water fountain is oh, so refreshing.

景.story: Imaging the sun rising over the capital--classic postcard scenery.

鯨.story: If fish were cities, the whale would surely be the capital.

舎.story: The cottage is so small - it has an umbrella for the roof; soil for the floor and room for only one mouth. It's not even a whole shack (シャ). 田舎 いなか rural area; countryside; the sticks (2) ; hometown 宿舎 しゅくしゃ lodging house 舎 しゃ inn; hut; house; mansion.

周.story: If my LIDDED CROCK has the same CIRCUMFERENCE as my head, I like to use it as a HELMET.

週.story: Imagine a road built so well that it takes only a week to travel the circumference of the earth.

士.story: What a handsome gentleman. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He's like a modern samurai!

吉.story: A true samurai gentleman will always mouth, "Good luck" to his opponents before a match.

壮.story: The image is a robust green bulging-muscle cartoon turtle. A TMNT with hachimaki. turtle-samurai.

荘.story: A villa is fancier (decorated with flowers) and more robust than the average.

売.story: A "samurai" will never sell his "crown" (king), even it meant having both his "human legs" chopped off!

学.story: In the school house there are kids always studying. (BTW, atomiton, this is NOT 字).

覚.story: In a schoolhouse in class: 1) you see something on the blackboard, then 2) you memorize it.

栄.story: The TREES FLOURISH in the CLASSROOM, a little too much perhaps, there's no room for the students any more.

書.story: Make sure you practice writing kanji with a brush every day before the sun goes down.

津.story: A brush laying in dirty water is a haven for bacteria.

牧.story: Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to "start breeding, and start doing it now!", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to breed with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow.

攻.story: AGGRESSION is a well-honed craft for any decent taskmaster.

敗.story: The shell who was defeated before (負 (#67)) is being chastised by the taskmaster for his failure to win.

枚.story: The taskmaster is a strict bathroom monitor who hands out only one sheet of really rough, splintery toilet paper per person. You can see the wood fibers.

故.story: An OLD TASKMASTER is no happenstance (coincidence). The older you get the more rigid in your ways.

敬.story: The flowery phrases of keigo (敬語) with which you must address the schoolmaster.

言.story: A pictogram of someone saying a four letter word from their mouth after the censors have gotten a hold of it.

警.story: To admonish is to enforce awe by means of words.

詮.story: Words that tell you the results of the whole story really elucidate.

獄.story: The wild dog family visits their cousin in prison. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth.

訂.story: Revise, revise and revise until you have all the words nailed down.

訃.story: Obituary. As a famous man lay dying, the media were already preparing the words of his obituary until a magician, with a wave of his wand, restored the man back to health.

討.story: I said some bad words, and my mother chastised me by washing my mouth out with glue instead of soap!

訓.story: The best type of Japanese INSTRUCTION is full immersion, which consists of going to Japan and swimming in the stream of words that surrounds you every day.

詔.story: The mnemonic "words to seduce the masses" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the imperial edict to the masses, thus "seducing" the masses.

詰.story: WORDS of GOOD LUCK are PACKED into fortune cookies.

話.story: Tales are always spoken, not written, and because of this, words fly out of your tongue, rather than your pen.

詠.story: If you study some words for a recitation, there is a good chance they will be stuck in your memory for all eternity.

詩.story: A poem is a temple of words.

語.story: The simplest word to say is I.

読.story: People will say (言) almost anything to make a sale (売); don't believe everything you read (読).

調.story: To tune an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the circumference, until you can clearly hear what's being said.

談.story: Think of an online discussion group where misunderstanding someone's words leads to flaming. An angry discussion = inflamed words.

諾.story: The words of the very young are useless without CONSENT from their elders.

諭.story: A PETA activist speaks at a meeting of butchers to rebuke them.

式.story: Each Indian tribe crafts their arrows in a certain style..

試.story: In an essay test, you are judged on both your choice of words and your writing style.

弐.story: II (older form of writing 2). After shooting one arrow (the dash top left), I have 2 arrows left in my quiver (bottom left).

域.story: An astronaut lands back at the launch range, kisses the earth beneath him with his mouth, then heads off to a fiesta to celebrate a safe flight.

賊.story: Burglars... those guys!!! Burglars only want money (clams) so that they can get needles (drugs) and party (fiesta)!

栽.story: The plantation is where we get our Christmas trees. We pick them out at Thanksgiving to be sure we get a good one.

載.story: Load the crops into the wagon in preparation for the harvest festival.

茂.story: When your garden gets OVERGROWN, it's like the plants are mocking you. Here, you can see the roses actually parading around the yard, wilfully choking out the other, more docile plants. Then they actually go and parade down the street!

戚.story: (Using the RTK1 supplement so I haven't had "uncle" yet.) When you take visiting relatives to a parade, hold the little ones up above so they can see over the crowd.

成.story: It only takes a single stroke of a dagger for a parade to TURN INTO a bloodbath.

城.story: The sand castle is just the 土 (#161) that turns into a castle.

誠.story: Sincerity happens when what you say actually turns into something.

威.story: The march of women - against intimidation in the workplace - is pretty intimidating in itself!

滅.story: Water flows down to destroy the march of fire.

減.story: When WATER was tossed on the PROTESTORS (a march of mouths), the numbers began to DWINDLE.

蔑.story: They gays were reviled by society, so they put flowers above their eyes and marched around.

桟.story: Japanese festival floats are often so tall they need wood scaffolds to be completed. (http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html).

銭.story: Interesting fact: The Japanese one yen coin is the only coin in the world that can float on water. http://www.hanamiweb.com/floatingyen.jpg.

浅.story: The water can't be too SHALLOW if you expect to float.

止.story: If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it's some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.

歩.story: When walking your pet, you must stop a few times along the way when nature calls.

渉.story: A ford is a place where one can walk through the water, a place only a few footsteps deep.

頻.story: I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head.

肯.story: A secret agreement between a covert gov't agency and aliens states that we will not step foot on the moon again in return for alien technology.

企.story: Mary Poppins floated down with her umbrella to undertake the job of stopping the children's misbehaving.

歴.story: A CURRICULUM is a calendar that replaces days with reasons to stop having fun.

賦.story: A warrior stands guard at a bridge collecting shells as a levy for any who want to pass.

正.story: If you do it correct on the first attempt you can stop.

証.story: Your words must be absolutely correct if you plan to use them as evidence.

政.story: Those involved in politics are always trying to elect the correct taskmaster.

定.story: In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher's HOUSE in various ways.

錠.story: Even if you lock up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end.

走.story: Hint: This kanji is NOT soil on top of mend, as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is 10 on top of mend. So my story is: If you run 10 miles, you will need to mend your socks!

超.story: A successful marathon runner needs to be able to transcend seductions, such as the possibility of rest, shelter from the rain, or a cold beer.

赴.story: Don't run into trouble," Dumbledore tells Harry. "Proceed with caution with your wand out.

越.story: The person in charge of running the parade surpassed all our expectations (by just a extra drop...)

是.story: 'Sun' 'Mend' - It just so happens that sunshine can mend your gloomy spirits.

題.story: The "TOPIC" of the day's newspaper must be placed JUST SO at the top of the PAGE to attract attention.

堤.story: Making a dike is all about arranging the soil just so...

建.story: Build is easy to remember if you can remember that archtiechts have two steps in building. 1. Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it's just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients.

鍵.story: The metal thing you need in order to enter things you build is a key.

延.story: Stretching correctly prolongs life. Even the top part of 正 is stretching...

誕.story: Nativity = born, being born. Think of birth as a painful and prolonged event. And of course, all the words and curses being yelled at the soon-to-be father for doing this to her!

礎.story: Features like stones and groves of trees are the cornerstones of a happy zoo.

婿.story: The only reason anyone talks about a bridegroom is if they're about to or have just gotten married. Of course, then you have to go on your honeymoon. So you take your woman to the zoo for a month. Pretty cool honeymoon.

衣.story: The only garments allowed in this club are top hat and scarf.

裁.story: The tailor was hard at work making sure all the pilgrims were dressed in their best garments for thanksgiving.

装.story: The TURTLE SAMURAI needs special GARMENTs for his ATTIRE since his body is much more ROBUST than others.

裏.story: The computer had carefully dressed up in clothes to look human. It was n't until I looked at the back and saw the cables and stuff that I realized what it was.

壊.story: If you stand too close to a DEMOLITION site, the dust might sting you like NEEDLES in your EYE and get your GARMENTs all dirty.

哀.story: One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a tophat and a scarf so that you can't see his whole face but only his mouth. He thinks it's cool. I think it's pathetic.

遠.story: Keep distant from a lidded crock on the road wrapped in a scarf. It might be a bomb.

猿.story: The MONKEY likes to play hide and seek with the PACK of WILD DOGS by hiding in the LIDDED CROCK. But he is easy to see because the SCARF he always wears is at the base of the LIDDED CROCK.

初.story: This is the first time we've been out of the Shire, Mr. Frodo!" Says Sam, covering himself with his cloak and clutching his dagger.

巾.story: If it looks like a towel, speaks like a towel and walks like a towel... I wonder why Heisig didn't include this one (as an actual kanji) in RtK 1.

布.story: A matador holding his red linen by his side.

帆.story: A towel makes a mediocre sail.

幅.story: In the west, the rich use $100 bills to light their cigars... In Japan, after showering, when the wealthy don't have any clean towels, they simply grab a hanging scroll off the wall and use it to dry off!

帽.story: If you wear a towel as a cap, you are at risk of being seized and searched in U.S. airports.

幕.story: There is a graveyard outside my house that scares me, so I put a huge towel over the window to serve as a curtain so I can get a good nights sleep.

幌.story: A canopy is a towel to block the suns rays.

錦.story: Brocade is the art of sewing gold on a white towel.

市.story: My recurring nightmare: Walking through the market, and suddenly realizing that I'm wearing only a top hat...and a towel.

柿.story: Nobody buys persimmons at the market, because there's a tree in the middle where you can pick them for free.

姉.story: Unlike the younger sister (妹), who is not yet old enough to date... the elder sister is on the market!

肺.story: The PART OF THE BODY most important if you work at a MARKET is your LUNGS so that you can shout out at the top of your voice "IRASSHAIMASEEE" to attract customers.

帯.story: Heisig fails to go into detail about the top kanji, but, It's not a mountain like everyone is saying. It actually means Thirty 丗 the stroke order starts with a One, then draw in the three vertical lines from left to right. Then the last stroke at the bottom closing it up. Then comes the Apron which makes up a Sash. (-Story: I made a Sash out of Thirty cut up Aprons.

滞.story: History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean water, so samurai usually had to wash their sashes in stagnant puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one's karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren't their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja????

刺.story: A TREE with a BELT wrapped around the middle. If you tighten the BELT, hundreds of tiny SABERS pop out of the tree in all directions, looking like THORNS.

制.story: The system for making leather belts involves slicing up a cow with a sword.

製.story: Made in... is a system of labels you can find on every garments.

転.story: The REVOLVING wheels of the car (with REVOLVER blaring on the stereo) kicked up RISING CLOUDS of dust.

芸.story: Imagine an old Kung-fu movie: "Try my rising cloud flower technique!!!" smash pow crack!! .

雨.story: From the ceiling hangs a towel dripping four drops like RAIN.

雲.story: Every rising cloud is a potential rain cloud. (Thanks astridtops).

曇.story: Cloudy weather is when a cloud blocks the sun (up above).

雷.story: If it's raining and you're standing in the middle of a rice field, you're sure to soon become acquainted with the thunder up close and personal.

霜.story: FROST is kind of an inter-weather, phenomenon, something between rain, snow and freezing temp’s.

冬.story: Don't slip off your legs in winter, strap two skis to your feet.

天.story: If you think of the sky as a ceiling above our heads, here you have the heavens as the largest ceiling you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the ceiling primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of.

妖.story: If you don't want to get bewitched (and who would?), then avoid any woman you see carrying what might appear to be a sapling. It's really a wand in disguise, and if you're not aware you might get bewitched.

沃.story: You use water to irrigate your saplings.

橋.story: A small 5 year old child has lost her mother in a tragic death. Her family tells her, "Don't worry, your mom is an angel now, in heaven, watching over you." The small girl takes this very literally and is found one day, gathering pieces of wood. Her dad asks her, "What are you doing with that wood?" "I'm trying to build a bridge to heaven to visit the angels.

嬌.story: The most attractive of women are said to resemble angels. Similarly, angelic women tend to be attractive.

立.story: A vase that can't stand up won't be a vase for long.

泣.story: Guys have two ways of watering when they are standing, the less common one is crying.

章.story: In the military, badges are given out early in the day, with everyone standing at attention.

競.story: TWO twin BROTHERS are competing (VYING) for the title of who is the older BROTHER. The game is that they must balance a VASE on their head and the one who drops his looses and becomes the younger BROTHER!

帝.story: The crazy sovereign stands up from his throne, wearing nothing but a crown and a towel. That's why they try to keep him locked up in the castle away from the public.

諦.story: The words of the sovereign king inspire the people: never give up! Never surrender! Okay...maybe it wasn't a king.

童.story: The juvenile stood on top of his computer and broke it. Noob.

瞳.story: In Japanese comics, the eye's of juvenilles all have enormouse pupils.

鐘.story: The METAL bell rings to call the JUVENILES to class.

商.story: Four loudmouths trying to make a deal on a vase.

嫡.story: Legitmate wifes tend to be women who are antiques in contrast to the young bit of illigitmate fluff on the side.

適.story: Think of the term from televison "suitable for all audiences" to get the sense of the word. What program could be more suitable for the whole family than the "antiques road(show)".

滴.story: DRIPS of WATER were collected in ANTIQUE VASES since the museum had a leaky roof.

敵.story: The taskmaster became my enemy for life when he smashed the antique vase holding my wife's ashes.

匕.story: To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku...with a spoon. http://tinyurl.com/co48k.

叱.story: A kid gets scolded if they don't put the spoon properly into their mouth when eating.

匂.story: The aroma of any delicacy is bound up in a spoon.

頃.story: An alarm clock with a unique design: You set it for, say, 7:00 am, and at about that time the clock reaches out with a spoon and hits you on the head.

北.story: In the north, the weather is so cold that people are often seen sitting back to back to preserve warmth.

背.story: While japanese people are generally small, people in the northern contryes have taller stature because of all the flesh they eat!

比.story: Compare the two spoons... the one on the left is funny-looking.

昆.story: Grandparent spends all DAY COMPARING photos of their DESCENDANTS.

皆.story: If you compare colors, you will find that white is produced from the mix of all the others.

楷.story: Block letters (as opposed to cursive) are rigid and lifeless like wood; they're all the same size so that all can read them.

諧.story: harmonious: If a choir is to be harmonious, all the voices need to combine to hit the right notes, and say the right words.

混.story: People have to mix their fluids (have sex), in order to create descendants.

渇.story: You awaken from your siesta because you feel extremely thirsty so you go looking for some water.

謁.story: The talk was so boring the audience took a siesta.

褐.story: Mexicans use a cloak (pancho) for their siestas. Their color is usually brown.

喝.story: If you have a siesta with your mouthopen, you will wake up with a hoarse voice.

葛.story: Flower, siesta: The muchacho was not careful. He passed the warning signs and decided to hold a siesta in the kudzu field. The kudzu grew so fast, he was completely covered by it in a few hours and not able to escape. Now, the kudzu flowers mark his grave.

旨.story: Use a spoon to eat a DELICIOUS hot fudge sundae. Duh..

脂.story: Every chef will tell you, fat is what make the meat taste delicious.

詣.story: You visit a shrine to say your wishes and offer delicious offering to the gods.

壱.story: The samurai who has been crowned number one is so good he uses a spoon to fight with rather than a sword.

毎.story: Freud believed every man wants to lie down with his mother.

敏.story: Every master(or taskmaster) must have some degree of cleverness.

梅.story: Plums actually grow on every single tree. What, you didn't know that? They do. Orange trees, apple trees, cantaloupe trees. Plums are simply mutant fruits that have been installed in the root software of every single tree. I hear that some plum-loving scientists are working on a way to hack every tree's genetic code so that every tree will bear nothing _but_ plums.

海.story: Every drop of water will eventually return to the sea.

乞.story: Lying down, Captain Hook is begging to be spared from the ticking crocodile.

乾.story: During a drought, everything begs for even a mist for relief.

腹.story: The only body part that doubles over.

複.story: My girlfiend saw someone wearing the exact same (duplicate) outfit at a party, so she doubled back to change!

欠.story: To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head.

吹.story: How am I supposed to BLOW if I lack a mouth? (Imagine a kid at his own birthday party, and - like Neo in the Matrix - had no oriface where his mouth was to be. And yet, the people cruelly cheer him on to blow out his candles...).

炊.story: Japanese cooking sometimes lacks fire, e.g., sashimi.

歌.story: Can-Can-ers lack the ability to sing a song, so they just dance.

軟.story: Cars are rough steel things, lacking softness.

次.story: Is this store lacking ice? Let's try the next one, then.

茨.story: To prevent animals from eating the beautiful flowers in your garden, the best thing to do is to plant briar bushes immediately next to them.

資.story: Assets are the next best thing to money.

姿.story: The next woman always has a better figure! Thinking like that, you'll end up alone in an old folks home longing for the good old days!

諮.story: Having a word with the next mouth over, like a neighbor, is usually a good way to consult with somebody for cheap. Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums.

賠.story: Compensation is money you give to someone to shut them up (i.e. muzzle their mouth).

培.story: To cultivate the land is to tame it, control it. In short, you muzzle it's unruly, chaotic nature. 培う つちかう to cultivate, to foster; 栽培 (さいばい) : cultivation.

剖.story: When you DIVIDE someone, there is sure to be a lot of screaming. That's why you should use a MUZZLE before using the SABER.

音.story: If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you'd be making sound.

暗.story: Picture the sun exploding - there would be a gigantic noise and then...nothing. Everything would plunge into darkness.

韻.story: What is a RHYME but some SOUND that EMPLOYEES say to get them through work.

識.story: Words are difficult to discriminate/discern from sounds in the middle of a fiesta.

鏡.story: Mirror should suggest vanity. Imagine a spoiled girl who gets her parents to buy her a Golden mirror so she can stand in front of it all day vainly admiring her lovely human legs.

境.story: In the dense cities of Japan even a small garden is a luxury. In this house, the owner has put mirrors on the boundary of his land so it feels much bigger.

亡.story: The top hat hanging on a hook belonged to the now deceased Charlie Chaplin.

妄.story: I had a problem with remembering that "deceased" went over the "woman". So, here's my story: The delusional woman was carrying her deceased husband on her back.

荒.story: After Godzilla laid waste to the city, the survivors put some flowers on the bodies of the deceased and floated their bodies down the stream.

望.story: You're dead meat, buddy, my ambition is to be king.

方.story: Note: The primitives are top hat and bound up. Compare 万 (#68). Story: A rich man wearing a top hat and bound up from head to toe hobbles up to you and asks for directions to the nearest police station because he just escaped from his kidnappers.

妨.story: If an attractive woman passes by, it can disturb your moral compass.

坊.story: Little boys always head in the direction of mud and dirt.

芳.story: She used a perfume so strong, that you can track her by following the direction of the smell of flowers.

訪.story: When you call on someone, you point your words in their direction.

放.story: Go in any direction away from your taskmaster when you are set free.

激.story: Overnight the slave got Violent and was Set Free. Overnight....Set Free.

脱.story: HORNY TEENAGERS love to UNDRESS FLESH.

説.story: The words of a horny teenager typically fall into one of two categories: either rumors or explanations.

鋭.story: Pointed is the metal devil's pitchfork.

曽.story: Formerly, horned animals were used to plough the ricefield, and it took all day. Nowadays it's done by machine.

増.story: Prices always INCREASE for LAND that was FORMERLY cheaper.

贈.story: SEA SHELLS were FORMALLY great PRESENTS. Nowadays kids wants playstation and DS!

東.story: Traditionally seen as a pictograph of the sun rising behind a tree.

棟.story: Feng Shui states that the ridgepole of a house should be made of wood and face east.

凍.story: Eastern Siberia is often frozen by ice. According to wikipedia, Yakutia (in Eastern Siberia) holds the record as the coldest town on Earth. Check it out yourself...it made it stick for me!

妊.story: A pregnant woman is a porter of her child.

廷.story: A porter has run away from his master. His punishment is to be stretched out on the rack. So say the courts in this barbaric time.

染.story: To make this dye, I used water and the barks of nine different trees.

燃.story: Any sort of thing can burn in the fire.

賓.story: This house is reserved to V.I.P. only. If you are not one of the few with enough money to call you that way, keep out!

歳.story: Santa had to put his foot down to stop a march of little guys, namely elves. They were protesting the harsh treatment they get every year-end when Santa asks them to step up toy production for the holiday season.

県.story: After sticking a fishhook in your eye, the yakuza boss probably has little more to do to convince you to move to a different prefecture.

栃.story: There are a bunch of HORSE CHESTNUT TREES on top of this CLIFF above the beach. Chestnuts keep rolling off the cliff and falling on people's heads. So far TEN THOUSAND people have been killed by falling chestnuts, and the Japanese government still ain't did shit about it.

地.story: Picture the ground as an extent of soil where scorpions are buried like land mines. Imagine a sign post saying 'no trespassing, scorpion mines' if that helps, and how it is dangerous to walk there.

池.story: Remember the story of the scorpion that begged the turtle for a ride across the pond? Halfway across the water, the scorpion stung the turtle on the neck and they both sank to the bottom.

虫.story: I see the bottom of this kanji as an arm, and the top is an insect biting into the arm, sucking some blood.

蛍.story: Bugs have to go to school to learn how to become lightning bugs. Only the brightest bugs graduate to become lightning bugs.

蛇.story: A snake eats insects and he does that outside, while we eat in the house and preferably with a spoon.

虹.story: Little is it known that a rainbow is actually created by insects of different colours flying in formation, a craft they have perfected to create the rainbows we see today.

蝶.story: A butterfly is an insect that appears after spending a generation on a tree as a cocoon.

独.story: The bachelor's apartment looked like it had been attacked by a pack of wild dogs. There were even insects in the kitchen. No wonder he's single!

蚕.story: In China it was believed that the silkworms were insects sent from heaven because of the beautiful material they produced.

風.story: They say that when an INSECT flaps its wings even the single DROP of WIND that it creates is sometimes enough to create a hurricane on the other side of the Earth.

己.story: This kanji looks like the "s" of "self", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his "self".

起.story: Be careful when you're RUNNING through the jungle, because you might step on and ROUSE a sleeping SNAKE. Then you'll have to RUN like hell before it bites you!

改.story: The taskmaster of Slytherin ( wizardry house symbolized by a snake ) plans a reformation of Hogwarts, disallowing the study of magic to all muggle-born. こわいですね！.

記.story: A scribe writes down the words spoken by a snake (i.e. a lawyer).

包.story: The snake bound up its prey by wrapping his body around it.

胞.story: Placenta is flesh/part of the body wrapped around the foetus.

砲.story: Primitive cannons fired stones wrapped with poisonous snakes.

泡.story: When water forms a bubble, it wraps a pocket of air.

亀.story: It seems bizarre, but tortoises are a genetic cross with the head of a fish and the tail of an eel. Where the shell comes from, no one knows.

電.story: Think of a two natural sources of electricity: electrical storms (a form of weather) and electrical eels. 電話 でんわ phone, call; 電気 (でんき) : electricity, (electric) light.

竜.story: Have you ever seen an asian DRAGON? it looks like an eel, but can stand up because it has legs.

滝.story: Ever went under a waterfall, vase in hand, trying to catch eels from the water as it pours down?

豚.story: Pork comes from the flesh of a sow.

逐.story: In association with 遂 (#579), our sow is on the road pursuing a mate.

遂.story: This is still Miss Piggy only she's gotten horny (as she often does) and now she's pursuing Kermit to help her consummate her desires.

家.story: Think of "The Three Little Pigs". There was a house made of straw, another made of sticks, and a third made of bricks, each occupied by a pig. So, naturally, housetop over pig means house, the central element of that story.

嫁.story: Since the Nihonjin man is hardly ever home, the woman feels more like she's married into the house than into a relationship.

豪.story: In Orwell's 'Animal Farm' the pigs overpowered every other animals. They crownded themselves as ruler of the farm and walked tall on their rear legs, a crime strictly forbidden in the animal republic.

腸.story: Intestines are the part of the body that is taken out of piglets to make piggy banks. Just imagine factory workers scraping out the intestines of real piglets and packaging them up for little children.

場.story: You're looking for a good location to bury your piggy bank savings. It has to be in some soft soil that's easy to dig up, well hidden, and easy to rememger like this kanji.

湯.story: Imagine a hot water kettle for your tea, except this one is a pink piggy bank that pours the water from its snout (and squeals when the water is piping hot). Make sure to use a potholder!

羊.story: Picture of a sheep run over by a steam roller. Must have been a ram, note the horns.

美.story: I guess this kanji proves it's not just the Welsh whose idea of beauty is a large sheep.

洋.story: This kanji refers to the waters of the Pasheephic ocean.

詳.story: Trembling from head to hoof from such a traumatic experience, the sheep gives a very detailed worded account to the detective about his wolf attack. "We need more details Mr. Sheep. Tell us exactly where the baaad man touched you".

鮮.story: This one's easy to remember. The kanji gives 2 examples of foods that should be purchased fresh. To remember which foods, take the first letter of fresh, "F", to stand for fish and the final sound of fresh, "SH", to stand for sheep: FreSH. It even puts the primitives in the right order.

達.story: Dolly (the first cloned sheep ever) grow tired of being a celebrity and escaped from the labs by digging a tunnel. She turned out to be an ACCOMPLISHED escapist, as she managed to dig a road under the soil. /Imagine Dolly performing a escape, like those movies where the main character has to escape from jail.

羨.story: A very thirsty sheep, who always lacked water, spends his days watching his fellow sheep (in the farm next door or in another pen) and being very envious of their water.

差.story: The distinction between fine and common wool, is the craftsmanship of the wool.

着.story: A pullover is donned by pulling wool over your eyes.

唯.story: The mouth of a turkey is used solely for saying, "Gobble." Likewise, your mouth, full of turkey, is solely used to gobble it up.

堆.story: After our pre-Thanksgiving massacre, we piled high all the turkey corpses atop the soil of the farmyard.

椎.story: This is the kanji for the shii tree, on which shiitake (椎茸) mushrooms grow. It's easy to picture a turkey dropping by the shii tree to gobble down some of those sweet oaky (shiitake) mushrooms.

誰.story: Do you remember that song where they say "Who let the turkeys out!? Gobble.. gobble.. gobble"?

焦.story: When I put the turkey over the oven fire, it always ends up being charred beyond recognition. I'm not a very good cook.

礁.story: Reefs are often formed from volcanic rock, or "rock that has been charred".

集.story: Hunter-gathers, searching all along the ground for food. They never look up and see the Turkeys that have gathered on top of the trees to hide. Those were some smart turkeys!

准.story: Quasi-modo, the famous hunchback of Notre-Dame wasn't actually a hunchback at all!! He used a frozen turkey to make a hunch!

進.story: Why did the turkey cross the road? To advance to the other side, of course.

雑.story: Newscast: "Among today's miscellaneous stories, we have a report on a baseball team that was chased up a tree by a turkey. Stay tuned for this and more!

準.story: At the turkey fighting semi-final, turkeys are injected with drugs via needles and splashed with water to help them last the match.

奮.story: The St. Bernard dog pounces on a turkey in a rice field and stirs up all the other birds around. See them all gobble gobbling in fear?

奪.story: Don't let the neighbor's St.Bernard rob tonight's turkey....glue it to the table if you must.

確.story: To assure that no one will get into the Turkey coop, put a huge rock in the entrance!

午.story: Noon is a good time for a ten minute nap (using lie down as nap).

許.story: If horses could speak, you might have to ask their permission before mounting them.

歓.story: Imagine a spoiled little girl. Her delight when she gets a Pegasus for her birthday... and then like all spoilt little girls she gets bored of it quickly... hence the yawn.

権.story: I have Eric Cartman of the “South Park” animated series, wearing a cop uniform, riding a wooden Pegasus (such as on a funfair), and yelling “RESPECT MY AUTHORITAH!!!”.

観.story: Microsoft Outlook works about as well as a pegasus that can't see: they both crash all the time.

羽.story: These days the biggest concern in airline safety is ICE on the WINGS of the plane. Birds that fly long distances also have to worry about getting ICE on their FEATHERS.

習.story: Imagine a white bird loosing a couple feathers as it is learning to fly. You learn a lesson as you watch it doing so, maybe you learn that “nothing comes for free” or that “one has to be prepared to loose in order to gain”...

翌.story: Your feathers would also stand up if you were a hen in a slaughter house and you heard: "The following!

曜.story: Tip: feathers + turkey : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "futon" (your futon is made from turkey feathers). REF: weekday (FRAME 576) , 濯 (#619), 躍 (#1379), 擢 (#2370), 燿 (#2594), 耀 (#2892). Story: On weekdays you hang your futon out in the sun.

濯.story: At the laundry you stuff your large futon (made from turkey feathers) in the machine, thereby causing it to break -- as shown by the water spurting out the side.

曰.story: Sayeth"?! Who the hell says "sayeth"? Doesn't seem quite right...just like this kanji, which is just like "day" but doesn't seem "quite right.

困.story: I'm supposed to make an enclosure for my tree, but if I use its wood for the enclosure, there won't be anything left to be pent-in. What a quandary!

固.story: Fossils are old things pent in that have hardened.

錮.story: RTK supplement: weld (metal, harden) - welding the metal bars of a cage together, to harden the cage even more... nothing shall escape now!

国.story: In my country (England) the crown jewels are kept pent-in in the Tower of London. Which happens to be where enemies of the state were once also pent-in (probably for trying to steal those jewels).

団.story: When you are admitted into a group like the Yakuza, you're well and truly done (だん) for. You must stick to the group like glue, and you will be pent-in for life, never being able to leave.

因.story: We once had a dog with big paws // and oh what great trouble he'd cause // we built a huge pen // to keep him pent in // and stop him from breaking more laws //.

姻.story: 婿嫁婚姻: Four kanji related to marriage, all with the woman primitive. Bridegroom: for the honeymoon, he takes her to the zoo for a month. Marry into: since the J-husband is never home, she feels more like she's married into the house than into a relationship. Marriage: is when she gets a new family name on one particular day. Matrimony: is the state after the marriage, where she has the husband pent in like a big St. Bernard.

咽.story: You can't breathe very well, so the doc looks inside your mouth to find the cause. "Oh, I see the cause of your windpipe blockage. There's a St Bernard penned up in there!

園.story: A nice picnic pent up in the park, with your crock pot and scarf (picnic blanket).

壇.story: A man on the podium announce the rules for the contest: You must fill a top hat with dirt as many times as you can by nightbreak.

店.story: Try to remember all those stores from Zelda that were inside caves and had fortune-teller like vendors.

庫.story: I think of the Batcave. It's a big cave that Batman uses as a warehouse to store his car, the Batmobile, and all his cool big-boy toys.

庭.story: When the courthouse caved in, trials had to be held in the courtyard.

庁.story: Some bureaucrats at a government office decided that the tunnels of caves need to get street signs, which are then nailed to the walls of the cave.

床.story: The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So these can be considered as beds.

麻.story: Where is the best place to hid your grove of hemp trees? In a cave, you dope!

磨.story: If you grind the hemp you are bound to get stoned quicker.

心.story: (mature content: violence) I hung the heart of my victim with a hook and three drops of blood spattered me.

忘.story: You only truly forget her when she has perished in your heart.

恣.story: Selfish lover breaks your heart and moves on to the next lover. (And yawns with a heart of ice at your suffering).

忍.story: A ninja must be able to endure the pain of clinging to a ceiling, motionless, for hours at a time, waiting for just the right moment to drop down and thrust the blade of his sword into the hearts of his enemies. By the way, this character is used in the compound 忍者 (ninja) which is why I choose to use ninja as its primitive meaning.

認.story: You are given a speech about some serious mistakes of yours, and you have to endure the whole thing, because all you can do is acknowledge.

忌.story: Remember the tale of Cleopatra? She was MOURNING the loss of her Marc Antony, so she placed the asp SNAKE to her HEART.

志.story: A samurai's intentions always come from the heart.

誌.story: This is quite simple: a document is a set of words describing your intentions.

芯.story: Giving a girl flowers is like lighting the wick to her heart.

忠.story: Their true loyalty exists in the middle of their hearts.

串.story: This is a pictograph if ever I saw one. Two chunks of meat on a skewer.

患.story: A person who is afflicted with the vampire disease can only be killed with a sheesh-kebab through the heart.

思.story: Think with your brain NOT your heart.

恩.story: Grace here is a favor freely bestowed, like a good deed. So to remember this kanji, go to the local shelter, find a big dog pent up in a small cage and adopt him. That will cause a warm feeling in your heart!

応.story: [bravo, scottamus!] To apply for the job as a (replacement) Batman, you have to make it to the heart of the cave past all the traps he set up to test you. There, you see a table with the application form on it. Now that you think about it, the ad in the paper did say "Those who don't make it to the heart of the cave need not apply.

意.story: When you get a good IDEA you get excited and you can hear the SOUND of your HEART, it's pounding so hard.

臆.story: Cowardice is the situation where you get the thought that maybe running away and saving your flesh is a good idea.

想.story: The concept of love is basically two hearts inter-acting as one.

息.story: Your breath brings oxygen in through your nose which is then pumped around your body by your heart.

憩.story: Recess to me is a school break. At recess some kiddies are comparing their latest body piercings. Tongues and noses are nothing special. The new cool is to have your heart done!

恵.story: Too easy. Imagine the Wizard of OZ. There, the three heroes asked the Wizard for three FAVORS: the lion wanted courage of TEN men, the scarecrow wanted a BRAIN, and the tin man wanted a HEART. Ok, the lion bit is stretching but you have it memorized now, so who cares?

恐.story: If your heart surgeon is mediocre in his craft, you have plenty of reason to fear. ("Oops, I think I left my scissors in there").

惑.story: She was beguiled/mislead by his charm: at the party he kissed her on the mouth, they did it on the floor and thus he stole her heart. Poor girl!

感.story: Emotion is a march of mouths inside your heart telling you what to feel.

憂.story: Melancholy makes me think of Hamlet cause he was so 'emo'. In order to play up his feelings he bares his head and holds his crown over his heart then walks (on walking legs) around the palace making everyone see how melancholy he is. What a wuss.

寡.story: The new widow sits in the house, her head in her lap (the extended stroke), her dagger in her husband.

忙.story: Busy (as in "occupied") means a state of mind where all other thoughts are perished.

悦.story: ECSTASY alters our STATE OF MIND and makes us DEVILS.

恒.story: Constancy is holding the same state of mind over a long span of time. (tweaking PepeSeco and mspertus).

悼.story: When Dumbledore died, everyone lamented it greatly. He was buried with his sunflower wand in his hand as he was so eminent. Even the death-eaters were imperiused to make them look like they were lamenting his death.

悟.story: Enlightenment is a state of mind that goes beyond the five senses.

怖.story: Someone in a dreadful state of mind has crawled into his bed and is hiding under the sheets (linens).

慌.story: When I am disconcerted my state of mind is "laid to waste".

悔.story: For all have sinned..." so everyone's state of mind should be to repent.

憎.story: Your state of mind would turn to hate when someone would take away a loved one that was formerly yours.

慣.story: Some hardcore monks have a state of mind that has become accustomed to their self-torture through piercing themselves.

愉.story: At the meeting of butchers, in their narrow state of mind, they throw lame jokes around like, 'Oh hello, it's a pleasure to meat you', and find this rather pleasing.

惰.story: When in a lazy state of mind, the things you need to do are left for next month.

慎.story: Humility is the state of mind of accepting the truth about yourself - both favorable and unfavorable. (tweaked version of Raichu's).

憾.story: Remorse is the state of mind where I feel bad for what I did while I was tired and emotional!

憶.story: Recollection is about bringing ideas back to your mind.

惧.story: When sitting through laser eye surgery, the surgeon stretches open your eye with a tight-fitting tool. The thought of a laser cutting through the lens of your eye within moments, and possibly blinding you in the case of a mishap, makes for a very disquieting state of mind.

憧.story: A juvenile's state of mind tends to go apeshit when they see something they yearn for. Usually involving jumping up and down, tantrums, and other bullshit. (Imagine giving them a big backhand across the face.)

憬.story: I'm in a state of mind where I desire to see the sun over the capital for some nice scenery for a change (no more rain!)

慕.story: Pining, yearn for... etc. Presumably for lost love. An easy one here, someone standing in the graveyard, placing an old valentine card amonst all the existing tributes.

添.story: Hawaii is a little drop of heaven nestled in the waters of the Pacific, most often visited by honeymooners and valentines. It was annexed to the U.S.A. in 1959, and more recently to Japan as well-- albeit only unofficially, and through private commercial holdings.

必.story: You swear you'll be in love forever, but invariably there comes a time when your heart is divided.

泌.story: Anything full of water will invariably begin to ooze.

手.story: This pictograph actually really works if you look at it as a hand with fingers spread and middle finger pointing down. see the very top stroke as the edge of a shirt cuff, and it will all come together.

看.story: It's a hot day of summer with a clear sky, you're sitting outside a cafe (or maybe on a reclining chair in the garden), and you watch over the kids with a hand covering your eyes from the sunlight (next time, don't forget the sunglasses).

摩.story: If you grind the hemp without a stone but use your hand instead it will chafe. (Image: "Robin, why are your hands all chafed?" 'Uh... (I've been grinding hemp all day)').

我.story: Someone with a huge EGO is too good for any romantic partner and as such has nothing but personal "hand fiestas" with himself every night.

義.story: Follow the path of RIGHTEOUSNESS like sheep follow the shepherd , let go of your ego.

議.story: Careful deliberation produces words of righteousness.

犠.story: A cow that is righteous sacrifices her milk for the human race.

抹.story: I like to RUB my FINGERS over my EXTREMITIES ....like my extremity-ly long, umm, hair.... This has been edited in response to being reported ...you can change "hair" to whatever extremity-ly long body part you like.

拭.story: Why carry a handkerchief? I wipe my nose finger-style.

拉.story: He quickly yanked his fingers out of the vase. Maybe no one noticed the attempt to steal the cookies...

抱.story: Here, I'm picturing that scene from ET (the extra terrestrial), where ET hugs Elliot before leaving. You see that EMBRACE is ET's long FINGERS that WRAP around Elliot.

搭.story: Ok, this is a little wierd, but i took this back to the kanji for 塔 (#254). I think it helps simplify the image, and also helps anchor the pagoda kanji in memory better as an added bonus. say this aloud once, and i think it will bring out a vivid image very quickly: "Now boarding the pagoda ride. Please keep your fingers inside at all times...
