To everybody else it is an origami, but to them it is also a symbol of their vows. -- "the folded words are vows". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an origami for the primitive "fold".

斬.story: I wanted a convertible so I chopped off the top of my car with an axe.

暫.story: Your car has been savagely (see steadily) attacked by an ax. It will be some days before your car is fixed. So you are temporarily without car.

漸.story: I imagine firemen working steadily to rescue a man from a crashed car. First, they spray it with water; then, they use an axe to break through the window.

断.story: [Based on fuaburisu's] A man puts some rice on a fishhook as bait, but catches a fish so strong, he needs to take out his axe and sever the line lest he be dragged into the depths.

質.story: What is this substance on this clam? I've already broken 2 axes on it! (Good question...質問).

斥.story: The kids at school used to reject me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my axe to school. See the drop of blood on it?

訴.story: I strongly reject the accusation implicit in your words.

昨.story: One can use a simple word play to remember this character - the day that I saw before today was yesterday.

詐.story: Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a word of a lie, his nose grows and he has to get the saw out again.

作.story: Mr T.'s favorite magazine is Make. He loves to make things. But he's a purist: he only uses saws, no power tools.

雪.story: SNOW isn't all that different from RAIN, except it can be removed with a BROOM because it only forms in freezing temperatures.

録.story: This character is about a recording for a music box. The tines of the mechanism are like a metal broom and the little pins on the cylinder are like metal grains of rice.

剥.story: Peel off the outside of the broom that sweeps up rice grains to reveal a saber.

尋.story: The policed inquired into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ ero in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.)

急.story: She was always bound to a broom, her heart pounding in a hurry to finish before she was punished for being slow.

穏.story: This whole kanji is a picture of calmness. The wheat has been harvested and even the vultures sit calmly watching the humans sweep and clean-up after the harvest is over. Hearts are peaceful and calm at this time of the year. Even the days are calm without storm.

侵.story: The parson ENCROACHES on the French maid; driven wild by her little broom, dainty tiara and sinfully short skirt showing her knickers (crotch)!

浸.story: The French maid draws a bath for her amorous master, but slips and falls in - getting immersed. (thanks to Nukemarine for the French maid image!)

寝.story: After work, the French maid goes home and lies down with a turtle. Turtle? Well, he's sloooow and always hard... (thanks to Nukemarine and Wakela!)

婦.story: In high society, a lady is a woman who never touches a broom or an apron.

掃.story: Whether I SWEEP something away with my FINGERS or my BROOM, I should always wear my APRON.

当.story: Some mothers use a small broom to hit their children when they misbehave.

彙.story: I was having mutual difficulties in my relationship. She was always the one wearing the crown and I was the one picking the fruit. In order to fix the problem I checked the glossary for "mutual difficulties" but found nothing. I guess we're going to have to mutually end our relationship.

争.story: This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to bound up his opponents, and with a trident, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific contenders, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them.

浄.story: Bottled water marketers contend to make their version of tap water sound the cleanest.

事.story: Just one word about this matter from your mouth and you will find this rake across it.

唐.story: Two archeologists are in a cave looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a rake and says, "What about this – T'ang, do you think?" The second puts the rake in his mouth and answers, "Yes, it does tang a bit".

糖.story: Sugar made from rice has a tangy flavour.

康.story: A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are sane and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the sane ones take out the plug and get the water out with ease).

逮.story: Think police roadblocks. They act like road sieves, letting good people through but apprehending criminals.

伊.story: The "boot" of Italy has gotten Europe all muddy. Who else could mop it up but Mr T?

君.story: There's a tendency in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. "Well old boy," a senpai might say, "If you did as much work with the mop as you do with your mouth, you would have been done an hour ago".

群.story: Good ol' boys are like sheep; they tend to flock together.

耐.story: [akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof--and I glued it to myself.

需.story: Supply and demand is a simple concept: when it rains, the demand for combs goes up to deal with wet hair.

儒.story: No more Confucian jibba-jabba! I demand you tell me why it's raining combs!

端.story: Have you ever seen those shots in movies where the hero is standing at the edge of a sheer mountain face, hair blowing in the wind? It probably wouldn't seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully combing his hair so it would fall perfectly.

両.story: Primatives celing; belt; mountain as per Cumulative Errata. See volfy post for link. Both effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the celing with your belt or jump off a mountain.

満.story: Add water THEN the flowers. With both the vase will be full.

画.story: You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs.

歯.story: Stop shoveling rice into your mouth, you'll hurt a tooth! Use chopsticks instead.

曲.story: It looks like the mouth of Bender the robot, from Matt Groening's animated series "Futurama". Thus, I use the character Bender the robot as a primitive.

曹.story: A space cadet eager to make one bend around the sun. (a dangerous maneuver).

遭.story: Close encounters of the third kind. The space cadet encounters aliens on the road.

漕.story: Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) is rowing, during some army exercise, and he's very afraid of water (Bender is a robot).

槽.story: Also as part of some army survival exercise, the cadets (including Bender see frame 1172) are sent into the woods to build a vat (for collecting water for example).

斗.story: Since the meaning of "big dipper" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of measuring cup. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup.

料.story: When buying rice, the fee is calculated by the cup. Naturally we don't just use any cup; it has to be a proper measuring cup.

科.story: University departments study things like wheat (agriculture) and the big dipper (physics/astronomy), and exact measuring cups (engineering).

図.story: Can't see direct relation to 斗 (#1261) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it's written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure map. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them.

用.story: To tenderize meat in an emergency wilderness situation, just utilize your walking stick!

庸.story: To live a comfortable life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.

備.story: Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He equips himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets.

昔.story: Once upon a time, the children were forced to eat their salad every day.

錯.story: Once upon a time, it was thought that the ancient "art" of alchemy could transform anything into gold. At that time, people were obviously confused about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as confused as ever, just about different things now.)

借.story: Once upon a time I let Mr T borrow my salad bowl, but he won't give it back. "This be mine now, foo!

惜.story: What a pity! My state of mind when i think of the opportunities I missed from once upon a time.

措.story: Long ago our ancestors set aside the use of fingers and began to use cutlery. (Raichu,11-7-2006) The way I remember it's 昔 昔 (#1268) rather than 旧 旧 (#35) is that they began to use cutlery to eat salad. (I also think about how when you visit the Medieval Times theme park, which is set in Once upon a time, their gimmick is that you eat with your fingers.)

散.story: The taskmaster is dissatisfied with the meal she's served, and scatters the salad & meat across the floor for the servants to clean up.

廿.story: A generation is 30, one stroke less is twenty.

庶.story: Commoners have to huddle in caverns around a campfire, while higher class people get heating and central air conditioning in a hotel.

遮.story: The commoners are revolting! We must intercept them on the road before they reach the castle!

席.story: Remember those poor commoners huddled in groups of 20 in a cave? The only thing they had for a seat was some old toweling (while their lords could recline on luxurious couches).

度.story: The cavern refugees are so poor that they can't afford thermometers. So, the menfolk expose their crotches inside the cavern, and approximate the temperature in degrees from how shrivelled everything looks downstairs...

渡.story: This particular form of transit is a ferry (one of the actual meanings of this character). Naturally it can only cross the water if it's not frozen, so the temperature must be above 0 degrees.

奔.story: Hustle and bustle = a big St. Bernard dog frisking about in a haystack, knocking it down and spreading the hay about, after the field hands just stacked it up.

噴.story: History of Pompei: An unexpect eruption and from the mouths of the volcano come lava that threatens the farmers collecting haystacks in the fields and the fisherman catching shells on the coast.

墳.story: After the eruption all is a tomb. The soil has covered the remains of the farmers gathering haystacks and of the fisherman collecting shells.

憤.story: Note: this word in Japanese has the idea of "indignant". So aroused here refers to being aroused because of anger over some unjust or wrong act, unfairness etc. It doesn't seem to carry a meaning associated with arousal in the sense of sex or pleasure. So, my story: think of the angry state of mind aroused at finding all your clams buried under your haystack stolen, gone!

焼.story: To the fire goes the straw man, thinking to bake a cake on it, but...

暁.story: The sun rising beside a straw man in a corn field is a classic cartoon depiction of daybreak.

半.story: Imagine karate chopping the number three in half with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first "board" breaks.

伴.story: The person who is your consort is most commonly "your other half".

畔.story: A PADDY-RIDGE divides the RICE FIELD in HALF.

判.story: In the bible, King Solomon's JUDGMENT was admired not by saying to cut the baby in HALF with the SWORD, but that it revealed who the true mother was.

拳.story: 1) I hold a roll of quarters in my hand when I make a fist. 2) I hold a quarter in my hand as I prepare to play the Iron Fist Tournament: 鉄拳 （てっけん） at the arcade.

券.story: Entering the movie, the dude asks for your ticket, so he can tear it in half. He looks at you funny when you hand him a ticket already torn in half. He quietly tears the stub into quarters after you show him your dagger with a smile.

巻.story: At a mysterious bazaar, you happen to come across something interesting: a rolled-up scroll for only 25¢. You buy it up impulsively until you realize that the powerful spell contained within is cursed by a poisonous snake. If you try to cast this spell, the snake will pop out of nowhere and bite you! Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap...

圏.story: I assosiate scrolls with spell casting, the efect of this spell is pent in a certain sphere of influence, outside it no damage is done.

勝.story: After your VICTORY cut your enemy's FLESH into QUARTERs to show your POWER.

藤.story: According to legend, the great Ogaki wisteria tree grew and flowered from magical rice grains that were planted under the quarter moon.

謄.story: Sending a facsimile to the moon can be problematic only a quarter of the words actually get there.

片.story: Fuaburisu's pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife is a one-sided version of the story. Others say he was giving her the finger.

版.story: Before the advent of printers in Japan, typewriters couldn't be built as they were in the west due to how many kanji there are. Lots of small printing blocks had to be used instead. One side of the printing block would have a mirrored (anti) image of the kanji. This is true.

之.story: Of all the kanji, this is the only one 之orro can write.

乏.story: Just one drop (of alcohol) and he starts walking in zig-zags – no wonder Zorro's living in destitution. (Note: As a primitive let 之 be Zorro or Zig-Zag: it's pictographic).

芝.story: Zorro, with a flower between his teeth for the ladies, defends his turf against evildoers. "This is my turf! And this...is for the lady.

不.story: [Smithsonian] Scene: Mr. T hanging from the ceiling being tortured. He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a drop of saliva) in the torturer's face, he says "Negative".

否.story: To distinguish between 否 negate, and 不 不 (#1217): Note that negate contains 口, which is a kind of gate.

杯.story: The maple tree is very negative about it, but the farmer still collects cupfuls of maple syrup from it.

矢.story: Zeus ran out of lightning bolts and has to drop darts from the heavens.

矯.story: Angels have now been given a powerful tool to rectify human behavior instantly, without delay - they have been allowed to drop darts on those who misbehave... spare the dart and spoil the man...

族.story: With a banner declaring "Keep Out!" and blow darts to back it up, the Amazon tribe is not that friendly.

知.story: I should know. After all, I did graduate from Dartmouth!

智.story: Wisdom is knowing everything OVER the sun (fools assume everything UNDER).

挨.story: In the busy pub, one of the dart players shoved his dart into my elbow by accident when it nearly slipped out of his fingers.

矛.story: マオ Zedong always carried a halberd.

柔.story: [tender; weakness; gentleness; softness] Love me tender, Love me perfect, Never cheat on me. Or I'll impale you on my Halberd, And hang ya atop a tree...

務.story: It is with the halberd he holds that the taskmaster exerts his power over those actually performing the task.

霧.story: This fog is the perfect weather for us to perform our task undetected.

班.story: Am I the only one who took this as penis and balls? In order to be in the man-squad, naturally you need to have two balls with your "spear" in the middle there.

帰.story: A female warrior returns home from battle. Her husband takes away her spear to symbolize the end of fighting and gives her a broom and an apron. “Boy, this is some kind of HOMECOMING,” thinks the veteran. (Adapted from johnskb).

弓.story: My personification for this primative is Legolas from the Lord of the Rings: a master at the bow. I suppose robin hood etc would work too.

引.story: This is actually a bow and an arrow. (Real origin of this kanji). Pull and release to fire!

弔.story: Perhaps a pictograph of a soldier's weapons--his sword and bow-placed ceremonially over his body before burial, while people offer their condolences.

弘.story: If you pull the bow back with your elbow, you can shoot a vast distance.

強.story: An insect who can fly vast distances is strong.

弥.story: If I recline back, I can pull my bow open a little more and more.

弱.story: Two weak archers agree on a duel to the death. They constantly shoot at each other but never manage to hit their target. But what they lack in skill they make up in determination, and they keep shooting for hours, and days, and months, until it's wintertime and their bows are coated in ice.

溺.story: Weak people placed in the water start drowning. Get some strength in those arms and learn how to swim!

沸.story: Re CharleyGarrett: This liquid looks like ordinary water, but it will instantly seethe when it comes in contact with counterfeit dollar bills. The inventor must be rich (and probably has dollar signs in his eyes).

費.story: An expense is an expense, whether you put it in dollars or in local money.

第.story: The No. 1 currency in the world is the dollar. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the bamboo represent the No. 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order (bamboo on top and the dollar on the bottom) is really a look at the future.

弟.story: Younger brothers are always more prone to mischief. Mine, you can almost see the little horns on him and the dollar signs on his eyes when he comes up with a money-making scheme.

巧.story: Adroit: dextrous, deft, skillful. Snare is a little generic so I'll use BEAR TRAP, with huge teeth cartoon style that snares you around the ankle. In the crafting of a bear trap, one must be particularly adroit. Otherwise they will become the victim of their down device.

号.story: My nickname is "No Lips". Yep, I shouldn't have put my mouth on that bear trap...

朽.story: This snare isn't terribly effective, because it's swinging from a decaying tree. Imagine the tree as being so decayed that when an animal gets caught in the snare, its struggles cause the tree to collapse into a putrid mess.

誇.story: The hunter's boast: I say, it was a "big one", but the snare broke and it got away. (credit to many others before).

顎.story: Your chin is the part of your head under your nostrils that forms the double snare that is your jaw.

汚.story: A hunter Washes, with WATER, his TWO SNAREs, because they are dirty.

与.story: David went to battle with a slingshot and it only took him one shot to slay Goliath. Partly because of this, the prophet Nathan was later instructed to bestow upon David the throne of all Israel.

写.story: A crown was bestowed to the British royalty museum, but it was only a copy.

身.story: Somebody was just looking for you. He had a longnose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face. (greenapple,16-3-2006) The way to remember that this is somebody rather than 者 (#1345) is that the story is full of body descriptions.

射.story: You SHOOT SOMEBODY with a GLUE-gun.

謝.story: In the Wild West it's shoot first, apologize later, but in Japan the words come first - so polite!

老.story: An old man, wondering what it's like in a grave, sits in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with soil, the old man saves himself by flailing his walking stick in the air.

考.story: Before shooting an old man with a slingshot, one shold carefully consider the possible consequences.

孝.story: This child has taken filial piety to the next level. He is actually carrying the old man on his shoulders.

教.story: In early Japan, filial piety was the cornerstone of education, and harsh taskmasters were employed to teach it.

拷.story: In Torture 101 class they teach you to Consider the Fingers as the first part to inflict pain to. Then you can move on to other parts (like feet, groin, head, etc. etc. ; ) ).

者.story: I find the best way of memorizing this kanji is in conjunction with the Japanese compound for ninja: 忍者 -- i.e. someone who endures (see FRAME 597 for the kanji 忍). A 忍者 is not just a 身 (somebody), it's 者 who can 忍 great 拷!

煮.story: I had a hard time with the next several frame numbers trying to use "puppet." So i thought of "voodoo doll" but then found "love doll" (which is just a special type of puppet) fit well with these 8 frames. Observe: Here I am boiling my love doll over the flames to warm her up a bit...

著.story: Here I am, putting a wreath of flowers on my love doll's head and pretending she is someone of great renowned.

箸.story: I've always wanted to use bamboo chopsticks to eat sushi off a naked woman. Unfortunately, there is no woman in my life, so this love doll will have to do.

署.story: Before giving your SIGNATURE to accept the LOVEDOLL, you should EYE over the LOVEDOLL for any damages, then give your SIGNATURE.

暑.story: Ahh, a fine sultry day with my love doll under the hot sun. I think she's getting a tan!

諸.story: Because i get tired of saying the same old thing, I have lately been trying to use various terms of endearment to my love doll. I think she appreciates it too.

猪.story: My love doll is made of special pheremone impregnated vinyl. Unfortunately, a pack of wild dogs mistook her for a wild boar and tore her to pieces. Oh dear!

渚.story: I was stranded on a desert island surrounded by water for hundreds of miles on end. I wasn't upset though - I had my love doll! What a great strand of sand to be stranded on - just me and my love doll!

賭.story: When we gamble at the shell game, I always win against my love doll.

峡.story: A gorge is where God has cut into a mountain with a pair of scissors. (synewave,6-10-2006) http://www.travelblog.org/Photos/197361.html.

狭.story: In a CRAMPED space, a brave man holds off PACK OF WILD DOGS with only a pair of SCISSORS.

挟.story: 挟まる 【はさまる】 (v5r,vi) to get between; to be caught in; (P) Story: You know how in tokyo there are those really packed trains where train staff in gloves shove people in? Well imagine being sandwiched in so tight, that when the doors close, only your FINGERS are sticking out. The train staff have no choice... they must cut them off with SCISSORS =( snip snip..

頬.story: Your cheeks contain your jawbones, which are known as the "scissors of the head.

追.story: Maestro, coattails flapping wildly, is being chased down the road by his fans.

阜.story: The maestro lives on top of a large hill so that he can play music at over ten decibels without anyone giving a damn.

師.story: A maestro in a large auditorium with high ceilings is conducting his orchestra of expert musicians at a fever-pitch, sweat pouring out of him. When the piece is over he reaches for his towel to wipe his brow.

帥.story: The COMMANDER is a military MAESTRO who never throws in the TOWEL.

官.story: No one likes classical music anymore. Our Maestro is here at home without his baton sighing sadly before he heads off for another day as his new job as a bureaucrat.

棺.story: An excellent use of wood is to make coffins for bureaucrats.

管.story: Japanese bureaucrats send all their messages through an inter-office bamboo pipe system.

父.story: Luke, I am your father. Darth Vader (really surprised nobody put this one up before: 2 laserswords).

釜.story: Your father uses his legs to stop himself from being put in a metal cauldron.

交.story: Even though your FATHER is an old man, he can't give up his party lifestyle. Once a week he still dons his cool TOP HAT (well, it was cool 40 years ago) and goes out on the town to MINGLE with the ladies. This is a pretty common thing in Japan, where old motherfuckers still think they can pick up 19 year old girls.

効.story: Mingling with the powerful can bring you success, bypassing the need for any merit.

較.story: The people I had invited to the party were mingling quite well with one another, until they all suddenly started talking about the cars they own. Pretty soon the crowd divided itself into distinct, contrasting crowds: rich snobs with fancy cars, soccer moms with minivans, and hippies with bicycles.

校.story: The schools that accepted them were posted on a TREE, the students MINGLED around trying to find their names. (コオ）.

足.story: Captain Ahab lost his leg to the great white whale's mouth and had to mend it with a peg leg.

促.story: You stimulate a person by giving him a kick.

捉.story: I felt a finger on my leg as someone tried to nab my wallet.

距.story: You can step a long-distance if you have a leg that's gigantic!

路.story: When pirates try to hide, it's always easy to find them. Their wooden legs leave distinctive prints, showing where each is hiding and the exact path he took.

露.story: After the rain the path was covered with dew.

跳.story: A turtle with a wooden leg needs to hop to get around.

躍.story: [Story for people following katsuo in making feathers+turkey a 'futon' primitive] If you're going to leap from a high place, better hope there's a futon below -- otherwise you're going to break your leg at the very least...

践.story: Pirates must tread carefully when walking on parade floats, so as not to break through the weak plaster with their wooden legs.

踏.story: You have to watch your step when moving your leg on a watery day.

踪.story: The trail of the wooden leg religion was very easy to follow, since all its followers have wooden legs.

骨.story: Your body meat is attached to the bone joints of your skeleton.

滑.story: Don't give water to a skeleton. When he drinks it, it'll sluice right through his bones, forcing you to put one of those "Caution - Slippery Floor" signs up on the resultant puddle.

髄.story: A skeleton is shuffling along the shoulder of the road, so you pull up next to him and ask where he is going. He says he's going to donate his marrow to the hospital because he got into some financial trouble and lost everything; his marrow is the only thing he still possesses.

禍.story: Continued from 祥 (#1169). Once a year, the people pray for a sign from the gods. But if the gods are feeling particularly mischievous, they'll send down a jawbone to the altar. The people see this as a sign of calamity to come. The gods think of it as an amusing prank.

渦.story: Grampa's flushing the toilet, when his denture (Jawbone) pops out and gets sucked down the whirlpool!

鍋.story: A metall pot with non-thermoconductive jawbones as handholds.

過.story: Jaws XII~! Jaws strikes the highway! Man, they're really overdoing it now.

阪.story: If you're scared of Heights, you don't want to stay at The Pinnacle; you are anti- The Pinnacle. Primitive: The Pinnacle is a dream-like gated community at the top of a mount. This allows for innumerable stories for all the kanji with this primitive since you have a whole city to work with. Also prevents confusion with "mountain".

阿.story: Can you see Africa from The Pinnacle? I can! I can!

際.story: On occasian, rituals are held at the very tip of The Pinnacle.

障.story: The officer at the gate to The Pinnacle with a giant badge sewn to his chest hinders all visitors. But not the handicapped. They're hindered enough already. They're given a badge and can pass right into The Pinnacle.

隙.story: They won't let me in The Pinnacle, but I can see a little bit of sun through this little chink in the wall. Hmm, maybe I could make this chink bigger...

随.story: [Image: Follow the 'Yellow-Brick Road' to success] The pinnacle signifies your personal goal and destination. What you're seeking to possess lies at the end of the yellow-brick road. You must follow the road to get what you want.

陪.story: In case of emergency, The Pinnacle has auxiliary guard dogs, but they keep them muzzeled until they're needed.

陽.story: A kid is perched on a pinnacle with his piggy bank. He uses the coins to catch the sunshine, and redirect it into people's eyes, far below.

陳.story: Every morning at The Pinnacle, the residents line upon the East side for morning stretches and leisure.

防.story: A giant compass is The Pinnacle's self-defense system. It points in the direction of any invaders so the city is prepared well ahead to ward off the intruders.

附.story: A sign was AFFIXED on the PINNACLE of the Acropolis so that tourists would ADHERE to the rules.

院.story: The Institution of The Pinnacle is perfect in every way. It is the new House of God, his chosen city.

陣.story: Note: This kanji is most often used in a military context. Story: Here we see an encampment of military vehicles laying siege to The Pinnacle. With other countries being envious of the perfect life they lead there that makes sense. Fortunately, the pinnacle knows how to 防 (#1302) enemies.

隊.story: Every regiment of The Pinnacle's army is lead by a Miss Piggy with a viking helmet on.

墜.story: One of the members of our air force regiment has been shot down; he managed to safely eject, but his plane crashed into the ground.

降.story: Sunglasses-missing-one-lens" is obviously the monocle. The proper, high-class way to descend The Pinnacle is wearing a monocle with your walking legs splayed to a full gentlemanly stride.

階.story: All buildings of The Pinnacle are multi-storey. They don't have much room, so they have to build up. It sucks when someone presses all the buttons on the elevator! You have to stop at each storey!

陛.story: Your highness is the pinnacle of finesse compared to all of us commoners who are but like dirt on the ground.

隣.story: America thinks it is the pinnacle of the world, looking down on all neighboring countries through its mirrored, aviator sunglasses.

隔.story: The Pinnacle, to me, is a city that makes itself out to be perfect but is filled with dirty secrets that photographers are always trying to reveal (see 融 (#1123) The city's councilmen have isolated all professional photographers to make sure they don't photograph these "dirty secrets". (which are up to your imagination).

隠.story: The wheat farmer's heart is 穏 (#1230) about the eagle not stealing his crops because of the broom scarecrow. But he still conceals all his wheat at The Pinnacle in case anyone else trys to steal it.

堕.story: Any attempt to possess the pinnacle will degenerate into a land ("ground") war.

陥.story: The Pinnacle is actually bound up by supports from olden times. Eventually, they give out, and the whole thing starts to collapse.

穴.story: A black hole is a "House of Infinity". Infinity is of course represented by a sideways "8", but here we have a Japanese "8" instead.

空.story: The craft of creating a black hole is in creating an emptiness which can attract things.

控.story: With my fingers, I punch in my bank code and withdraw some money from my account. And now it's empty again, as usual!

突.story: When you stab something you often leave a big hole.

究.story: Most research scientists have 9 holes.....two nostrils, two ears, a mouth, and four eyes...... :-).

窒.story: Sticking a plug up your hole will lead to stronger climaxes.

窃.story: The word STEALTH makes me instantly think of Solid Snake, who CUTS a HOLE in a cardboard box so he can peer out of it. 窃盗　せっとう 窃視　せっし.

窟.story: You are digging a HOLE; suddenly the ground begins to YIELD, and before you know it you've discovered a CAVERN.

窪.story: A depression is a hole in the ground. Water naturally collects there which provides moisture for vines to grow.

搾.story: Very simple visual image makes this an easy kanji to remember. Just picture that you SQUEEZE your FINGERS going through the HOLE in the handle of the SAW. You then SQUEEZE your FINGERS tight to use the SAW to cut a HOLE.

窯.story: Be sure to put a hole in that ceramic sheep before you put it over the fire. Otherwise, it'll just explode in the kiln. (If you've never done ceramics before, it's important that the object have a hole in it, or this really will happen.)

窮.story: Hard up = nothing but your body, living in a hole, with just a bow to hunt for your food.

探.story: Note: "crown+human legs" appears 7 times in RTK. In 4 cases (nos. 323, 1327, 1328, 2920) crown is above human legs, and in the other 3 (1888, 2472, 2679) one leg passes through the crown. I call the 1st pattern "Miss World" (who is wearing a crown & has long human legs) and the 2nd "garter" (one human leg passes through the crown wearing it as a garter). Story: Miss World has climbed a tree to avoid the finger that was groping for her. (探 means "grope for", i.e. search).

深.story: Thrown in deep water, the Japanese School girl tries to reach a floating tree to save herself.

丘.story: Excalibur is the sword planted in a rock. Lesser known AXCAHILLBUR is the axe planted on top of a hill.

岳.story: A point is a extra little hill at the top of a mountain. We'll call it 'Fireman's Point'.

兵.story: Listen up soldiers! We're going to take that hill. You are no longer men with human legs. You are voracious animals, with animal legs! Got it? Animal legs! Now take that hill!

浜.story: Seacoast -> Coast Guard -> "water soldiers" lined up on the seacoast defending our shores.

糸.story: I also went with Spiderman. However, in the cases where this primitive appears under other primitives, as opposed to on the left (I think there are ~5 times in this chapter) I've opted to use a similar character: Venom. This helps keep the positioning clear, especially on such characters as 細 (#1463) and 累 (#1464).

織.story: Spiderman weaves his way through the skyline while listening to his theme song on his ipod. It is played, of course, by kazoos.

繕.story: After a day being virtuouos and keeping the city safe, Spiderman's outfit is in need of some repair. Luckily, as he can shoot out threads darning is very easy for him to do.

縮.story: After spending the night at an inn, spider man discovered to his dismay that his costume had shrunk in the wash, and no longer fit!

繁.story: Important: Luxuriant does NOT mean luxurious, as the other stories indicate. Definition: abundant or lush in growth, as vegetation. When Venom realized he couldn't beat Spider-Man in a fair fight, he showed his cleverness by spraying venom all over Spider-Man's luxuriant garden.

縦.story: When Spider-man does his amazing vertical wall climbing, a throng of photographers accompanies him to get a good shot of the action.

緻.story: This kanji shows Spiderman giving a dress of the finest thread to his girlfriend. Of course, the real purpose of the gift is to get his girlfriend to doth him.

線.story: This kanji is used for train lines. Spiderman does a hot spring tour of Japan using the train lines. You can see the Spidey costume hanging on the washing line as he enjoys the onsen.

綻.story: Even though his costume is coming apart at the seams as he chases the bad guys, Spiderman is still determined to catch them.

締.story: (astridtops) Spiderman managed to get behind the sovereign. (pick your favourite nowadays country ruler who isn't doing a good job). Spidey has tightend a web around the sovereing's throat. As long as the sovereign says what spidey whispers, he will be fine. Sovereign yelping : ' we will draw are troops back! and we will spend more money on healthcare, schools and less on wars!' Spidey whispering: ' If you continue at this pace, you might be doing good things AND the people will like you.'

維.story: Hey, Spidey! Eat that turkey if you want, but make sure you eat some fibers: you want spidey threads, don't ya?

羅.story: Lots of girls in Japan wear gauze patches over one eye made of course white fibers. They think it is cute, and I must admit, I have come to think so too.

練.story: Spidey stays on the east side of the city to practice. The West Side is too dangerous.

緒.story: Spiderman has a secret fetish, he likes nothing better than to dress his lovedoll in a thong. Wierd, eh!

続.story: Even though Peter Parker has become Spiderman, he continues to sell pictures that he takes as a photographer.

絵.story: There's never a picture of Spiderman meeting Peter Parker... I wonder why?

統.story: Spidey is alloted the biggest crime fighter jurisdiction in NYC because his OVERALL arrest record is the best.

絞.story: Spiderman hates going to parties and having to mingle. He wants to strangle someone after just a little small talk.

給.story: Spiderman wanted to be a salaryman, but the suit just didn't fit him.

絡.story: When threads become entwined, each thread is tangled to another.

結.story: Ok, here, you have to think of the phrase "TIE the knot" , which means a wedding (this kanji is used in the marriage compound 結婚 けっこん ). Now, at US weddings, it ends with the couple driving away with cans being dragged behind the car. So here, think of SPIDERMAN, who will TIE the knot with Mary Jane. At his wedding, Spider THREAD attached (or TIED) to SPRAYCANS are being drug behind the limo as they drive off.

終.story: This winter is so cold that spiderman's web gets brittle! Could this be the end of spiderman?

級.story: This Kanji is the same ones used in the Japanese Language proficiency tests; i.e. ikkyuu (一級) The Kanji doesnt describe class as in a "class of students" or "classroom," but rather a grade of quality or ability. ---------- Spiderman is taking the JLPT Level 1. In desperation he REACHES OUT to grab his friend's answer sheet next to him, who seems to be doing well. The other test takers are obviously a class above him. Looks like this test is above his class of knowledge.

紀.story: Worst fan fiction ever....SPIDERMAN joins the CHRONICLES of narnia to battle a big SNAKE!!

紅.story: Spiderman crafted a crimson costume to fight crime in.

納.story: Have you heard about patients who have surgery and the doctor mistakenly leaves a medical instrument INSIDE the patient’s body and proceeds to stitch up the patient’s incisions with stitching THREAD? Can you say “malpractice SETTLEMENT”?　.

紡.story: Spiderman can spin his webs in any direction.

紛.story: Spiderman got distracted when someone yelled, "Spiderman, wait a minute." He turned around and flew into a building. ("part" also means "minute").

紹.story: Spiderman seduces all the girls he's introduced to.

経.story: The word ‘sutra’ literally means a rope or thread that holds things together. Here we see that it is a spool that is holding the threads together.

紳.story: Monkeys are very adept at swinging around trees. But when they met Spiderman, who could swing around even better than they could, they all quickly addressed him as sire.

約.story: Anytime Spiderman breaks a promise, Aunt Mae hits him one over with her ladle.

細.story: Dainty women would always rather work with thread than in a field.

累.story: (dingomick) Venom is upset because Spidey is just that much brainier than he is! He chooses to accumulate as many brains as he can, snatching them out of people's heads and storing them on top of his own, till there's just one massive brain on top of his head!

索.story: (modified akrodha's great story) VENOM has been captured by scientists and is being experimented on: they forced a CROWN of NEEDLES on his head and attached it to multiple electrical cords, which are connected to a big machine.

総.story: Spiderman could not achieve general acceptance by the media even after winning the public's heart.

綿.story: Spiderman's polyethylene suit starts to ride up after a while, so he always looks forward to the white cotton towels he wears while lounging around his apartment.

絹.story: Spider-man loves to run his mouth all over Mary Jane's silky flesh.

繰.story: After stopping a bank heist, Spiderman is seen winding his webbing around the stolen goods to trap them in a tree until the police arrive to take them back.

継.story: Spider-Man is hooked on rice--it's all he inherited from his Uncle Ben. (thanks Nukemarine).

緑.story: Spiderman's nemesis the Green Goblin is in a slump; He's replaced his glider with a broom and is throwing grains of rice instead of bombs.

縁.story: There once was a lonely little pig that constantly followed Spiderman, always nuzzling his leg and oinking tenderly. Spiderman finally caved in and decided to keep the little pig under one condition: the pig was to take a broom and sweep up all of Spiderman's leftover threads after having fought crime. The pig felt such affinity for Spiderman, he happily accepted—and did a good job too.

網.story: Spiderman traps The Rhino under the hood of his famous netting, where even Rhino's horns can not break free, in fact if the netting did not dissappear after a few hours then Rhino might even perish in there.

緊.story: Whenever Venom is tense, he loses control of his sex drive and becomes a slave to his crotch.

紫.story: Venom starts to choke on a spoon. He's about to get it out, when you manage to stop the spoon from getting out, so he turns purple, as he chokes, and dies.

縛.story: Spidey received good word that the acupuncturist working down the road was actually the evil Doctor Octopus! Spidey headed over to the clinic, and trussed the acupuncturist Doc Oc up using the maniac's own metal limbs!

縄.story: The tortoise has escaped! We tied it up with a straw rope, but all that's left of the rope are some torn threads, and the unbound tortoise is nowhere to be found. (Note that the right half here is not "eels". This is (in my opinion) a mistake in the RTK book, as we already decided in 滝 (#537) to refer to the simplified form of dragon as "eels". It is much better to call the right half of this character an "unbound tortoise".)

幼.story: In its infancy, a butterfly is protected by a cocoon, as it doesn't yet have any power of its own.

後.story: Column of walking legs (caterpillar) getting into a cocoon, about to leave its past self behind.

幽.story: The villagers haven't the faintest idea that giant coccoons resting in the mountain are soon to hatch.

幾.story: At the Mexican fiesta, there is a coccoon eating competition. How many coccoons can one person eat? No one has managed more than two before giving up...

機.story: An abacus is a mechanism made of wood used to calculate how many 'anythings'.

畿.story: People aside, I wonder how many rice fields there are in the capital suburbs.

玄.story: What could be more mysterious than a cocoon in a top hat trying to sneak in...? (Pimitive: GANDALF).

畜.story: This mysterious rice field grows not only rice, but livestock too! Picture little pigs and chickens growing right out of the ground, among the rice plants. How bizarre!

蓄.story: One sneaky farmer wanted to amass a large collection of livestock. We all know that cows like to eat flowers, so he planted lines of flowers leading to his own fields. The livestock followed the lines, eating the flowers one by one, and amassed in his field.

弦.story: A magic bow that only Gandalf can yield: there is no bowstring on it, and he uses his magic to fire arrows.

擁.story: A mysterious turkey with human fingers wants to hug me... I will never go to Tokyo Disneyland again!

滋.story: Water is doubly mysterious. It's in all our nourishment...and yet, it's really not nourishing at all.

慈.story: Mercy is a doubly mysterious turn of the heart. On the one hand, everybody wants it, but on the other hardly anybody gives it.

磁.story: A magnet is a rock with two sides; one that mysteriously pushes and one that pulls; doubly mysterious. (see astridtops' story).

系.story: (Primitive: DNA, a drop of looong spiraled thread that is the key to your lineage).

係.story: Mister T gets a DNA test, and discovers that he was meant to be the person in charge after all.

孫.story: Your grandchild is the child of your DNA.

懸.story: The prefecture has suspended all DNA research for heart disease because of corruption. All involved will be suspended by their wrists.

遜.story: My parents aren't at all modest about their grandchildren, at every opportunity they take them on the road showing them off to their friends!

却.story: [instead; on the contrary; rather] Gone is the time for stamps - use e-mail instead.

脚.story: Shins are the part of the body that Japanese traditionally sit on instead of their asses.

卸.story: Selling WHOLESALE HORSES over the internet had to be STOPPED because the cost of STAMPS was too much.

御.story: An honorable man will not try to cut in front of the line at the wholesale stamp store. (Imagine just how much honor it takes facing those long lines at the post office!)

服.story: It's customary to cover the flesh with clothing, but some designs are so outrageous they're not bigger than a stamp that just covers your crotch.

命.story: When you're born, your fate is measured, fitted, and stamped onto your soul. Good luck defying it.

令.story: (re: dingomick) "These are your orders," declares the general while passing out documents at the meeting. As everyone started to leave, the general exclaims "Oh wait! I need to certify these orders!" and went around stamping each paper with his personal chop-seal.

零.story: The amount of people that can order the rain to rain.

齢.story: You know you are fast approaching a ripe old AGE when you get ORDERS from the dentist to get new TEETH.

冷.story: To keep your water cool, just order some ice.

領.story: Two cowboys are crossing a state limit. One says to him “Did you know that in this Jurisdiction there are Orders to get your head?”, so he takes out his gun and shoots him. He claims the reward afterwards. (Thanks Fuaburisu).

鈴.story: Some restaurants have a small gold bell to call someone to take customers' orders.

勇.story: I imagined some kind of initiation rite in old China, where every young man has to show his courage. They then receive a chopseal which is a mark of their courage.

湧.story: The courageous man who went into the water to save a drowning victim couldn't be seen, except by the air that bubbled up.

通.story: I bounce down the road on my pogo stick, easily getting through the dense traffic. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a chop-seal is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could utilize it as a pogo stick). [Edit: pogo stick also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530].

踊.story: Dancing with pogo sticks tied to your legs is more like jumping about.

疑.story: (Katsuo) You come at the zoo entrance. 'Here sir, a spoon to feed the animals.' cool 'and a dart(gun) in case stuff go wrong' ....' please chop-seal (sign) here for in case of accidents the zoo is not responsible.' 'lion feeding time is. bla bla' You are having serious doubts about if you still want to go into this zoo.

擬.story: Ask a MIMIC to give an impression of DOUBT, and he will no DOUBT scratch his head with his FINGER.

凝.story: I doubt that the jello would congeal sitting on the counter, so I placed it in the icebox.

範.story: This pattern made of bamboo is for a new model of car designed to leave as small an ecological fingerprint as possible.

犯.story: Crimes can often be solved using the tools of dogs and fingerprints.

氾.story: It's a widespread belief that they cannot find fingerprints on a body that has been deposited in the water.

厄.story: Seeing some finger prints at the edge of a cliff, I wondered who that unlucky person was.

危.story: You're bound up by ropes to an unlucky person. It's dangerous, because whatever happens to him will happen to you too.

宛.story: Your address should be displayed on your house and mailbox.

腕.story: Like in Memento, I tattoo my address on my forearm flesh so I don't forget it.

苑.story: Japanese "gardens" aren't anything more than a pot of flowers on top of the mailbox.

怨.story: I couldn't drop my grudge against him. So I put a severed pig's heart in his mailbox. He got the message.

柳.story: Having decided to use SIGN OF THE HARE rather than RECEIPT and STAMP my mnemonic goes as follows: The WILLOW is the TREE that droops likes a HARE's ears.

卵.story: The Easter Bunny dropped an egg on my desk and got yolk all over my receipts and stamps.

留.story: Got a receipt for that dagger, son? If not, we're going to detain you and send you to work in the rice fields.

瑠.story: “The king has been detained by some marines!” “How do you know they were marines?” “Because they were wearing marine blue.”.

貿.story: There's a buyback program where you can trade in your dagger for money. But it's quite ineffective, since only registered dagger-owners with the original receipts can participate, and not criminals with illegally-purchased daggers.

印.story: Before sticky backs, they had to staple stamps to letters.

臼.story: I removed all the back to back staples and grinded them in a mortar to create metal dust.

毀.story: Wow, that baker must really be mad! He's trying to BREAK his MORTAR by throwing it to the SOIL. Whoa! Now he's aiming a MISSILE at it!

興.story: To me, this looks like a pictograph of a road leading to the big city (see the buildings?) where there are plenty of places to be entertained. Unfortunately in this city, every store is the same: staples. What tools! [ayoung24].

酉.story: The sign of the bird on this whiskey bottle is of course the Famous Grouse blended Scotch.

酒.story: Sake is just watered down whisky.

酌.story: At the local pub, their bartending practises are unusual. They serve the whiskey by pouring it from a ladle, like one would from the punch bowl.

酎.story: While the keyword is "hooch", this usually means 焼酎. It has similar effect as whiskey and sniffing glue has: you get intoxicated.

酵.story: The secrets of fermentation are passed to the son who displays the most filial piety.

酷.story: It's cruel to pour alcohol down a cow's mouth.

酬.story: Imagine a different kind of tax refund - instead of money, the state repays you with whiskey.

酪.story: To stay healthy, Dr. Phil told me to have some dairy products with each bottle of whiskey I drink...

酢.story: Drinking alcohol that's turned to vinegar feels like a saw going down your throat.

酔.story: God you're drunk! How many whiskeys did you have? 9? 10?

配.story: To DISTRIBUTE WHISKY during Prohibition you had to be as sneaky as a SNAKE.

酸.story: The prostitute carries an old whiskey bottle filled with acid to throw at any difficult Johns.

猶.story: The waver for this kanji means to hesitate. I wavered before going into the bar with a bunch of horned wild dogs drinking whiskey straight out of the bottle.

尊.story: I drank the Devil Whiskey and was revered by all. Too bad I had to have my anus glued shut from the damage it did to my digestive system...

豆.story: If I eat BEANS, after ONE MOUTHful I fart like some kind of HORNED ANIMAL.

頭.story: The head of the family sits at the head of the table.

短.story: He's so short, he can't even throw over a table while playing darts.

豊.story: The bountiful feast was so bountiful that it bent the table below it under its weight! いただきま〜す！.

鼓.story: I really hate the primitive meaning of "table" for "bean." I just use "bean." Anyways, for the DRUM primitive, imagine a SAMURAI who beats on a DRUM with two chopsticks, and a BEAN skewered on each end of the chopstick to produce a better sound. And the obvious story is: "DRUMing on a DRUM with a huge BRANCH".

喜.story: The samurai sitting on the drum is on a stage, and the people below him are rejoicing with their mouths in unison. It helps me to imagine the placement this way.

樹.story: The hippies object to trees being cut down for timber. They have glued themselves to the timber-trees and are beating their drums.

皿.story: Three dishes stacked side-by-side in a dishwasher.

血.story: Vampire orders blood in one of those posh restaurants. Imagine his shock when all he gets is a giant white bowl and just a single drop of blood in the centre and a drizzling of balsamic around the edge. Disgusted he calls the manager over tells him its overpriced tosh and bites into his neck with a huge gush of blood spraying everywhere.

盆.story: The part of the kitchen sink in which you wash dishes in is the basin.

盟.story: (re: Raichu) An undercover alliance between Japan (the sun on its flag) and Turkey (the moon on its flag) detected by a surveillance satellite dish. http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100126a3.html.

盗.story: You are so poor you dont know where your next dish will come from all you know is that you will have to steal it.

温.story: If you leave water out in the sun in a dish, naturally it will get warm.

蓋.story: The lid of this dish is gone! Now the whole room smells of the flowers that were used in the cooking.

監.story: The slavetrader oversees the slaves washing dishes int he kitchen. No reclining on the floor!

濫.story: Who's job is it to oversee the water level on the dam? It'ts overflowing!

鑑.story: The overseer tags his slaves with gold earrings, just like specimens.

藍.story: Indigo flowers have to be overseen because they are often picked for their beauty.

猛.story: The fierce WILD DOG attacked the CHILD who came near his feeding DISH.

盛.story: Japan's economic boom turned their empty plates into full ones.

塩.story: In the old days, salt was a worth alot, so it is not surprising to find someone reclining on the ground, mouth to plate, getting every last grain of that delicious salt.

銀.story: Like gold, silver is a metal.

恨.story: The athlete's state of mind is nothing but resentment after getting the silver medal.

根.story: Since trees eat through their roots, one could imagine roots as tree silverware.

即.story: He scratches off the silver stamp and discovers that he is an instant winner.

爵.story: An eagle stole the baron's eye in the war, but now he has a silver coin glued in the socket instead.

節.story: Counting the nodes on bamboo is an instant way to tell its age.

退.story: You see a huge army of people in silver armour on the road so you retreat.

限.story: The speed limit at The Pinnacle is posted on silver signs.

眼.story: Eyeballs made of silver. That's what they use to play pachinko with, isn't it?

良.story: With a drop of silver, the forces of good can vanquish the werewolves.

朗.story: [Image: 'Moonlight sonata'] The moon has inspired many good composers (like Ludwig van Beethoven) to write something melodious.

浪.story: Water is a good thing to have when you're out wandering.

娘.story: Your daughter is a good girl......well, let's hope so... :-).

食.story: That umbrella looks good enough to eat!

飯.story: I'm anti-fastfood. Sit down and eat a real meal!

飲.story: When you lack food, just drink something to fill you up.

飢.story: The smell of cooked food wafts past you in the wind, making your stomach rumble and feeling hungry.

餓.story: All those starving models in Hollywood - they want to eat, but their ego (about their appearance and trim look) makes sure they grin and bear it!

飾.story: [decorate; ornament; adorn; embellish] We decorate a table before eating, reclining a towel over it.

餌.story: Food made of ears is animal feed.

餅.story: Call your friend and he answers the phone "Mochi, mochi!" whatever he is eating sure is making it hard to understand. I will puzzle over the content of our conversation for some time to come.

養.story: A sheep became the foster parent for a wolf pup, feeding it with milk. This story cannot end well...

飽.story: My gluttony was only sated after I ate the hamburger AND the wrapper!

既.story: Distinguish from 曽 (#540). Think of previously as "the previous customer" in a restaurant. At a cheap sleazy diner, the waitress gives you unwashed silverware that was previously used by the previous customer. Yuck.

概.story: A murder has been commited. A corpse was found under a tree. The police chalks the outline of the victim, an old silvered-haired waitress working at a restaurant nearby.

慨.story: If you don't leave some silver as a tip, you will rue the day you earned the resentment of your waitress.

平.story: There's an even covering of water lilies on the pond at 金閣寺（きんかくじ） the Golden Pavilion in Kyoto.

呼.story: I'm a lazy fisher, so I genetically engineered a lily pad with a fishing hook at the stem and a mouth to call me whenever it catches something.

坪.story: A two-mat area is just about as much ground as you will need for a lily pond.

評.story: Good evaluation should always be words of even fairness.

刈.story: Sheaf? No. This is the sign of the X-Men. I'm going with Wolverine on this one.. Wolverine reaps the bad guys with his saber-like claws.

刹.story: Wolverine waiting atop a tree to spring down on Sabretooth at any moment.

希.story: Wolverine (sheaf, see 刈 (#1600)) hopes they invent linen sheets that he won't keep shredding in his sleep.

凶.story: Wolverine (sheaf, see 刈 (#1600)) takes out a villain who can't be cut by smacking the crap out of him with a shovel.

胸.story: Bosom is a Flesh part that should be bound up lest it provoke villian thoughts.

離.story: I've finally met my arch-rival, the evilest of all villains. Finally, I'm about to fight him. But what's this? He's suspiciously quiet. I move to attack him, and his right arm falls off at the elbow. Strange. I walk up to him and detach his left arm. Very strange. I undo his belt, and take off his top hat... BLAST! It was just a decoy turkey!

璃.story: The King's crystal got detached from his royal throne, and is missing! Looks like the turkey got away with it. He's no where to be seen!

殺.story: Wolverine (sheaf, see 刈 (#1600)) leaps over a tree and with one swipe of his claws kills a bad guy aiming a missle launcher.

爽.story: A large airship drops parachuting Wolverine clones into the bracing night air.

純.story: Earthworm Jim's prized possession is a genuine copy of the #1 issue of Spiderman.

頓.story: Ever chopped the head off an earthworm? Notice how it will grow back immediately! Beware the killer earthworms...

鈍.story: The metal hook is too dull to even pierce an earthworm....

辛.story: Eating spicy food makes you stand up ten times faster than usual, 'cause you just need to get something to drink!

辞.story: This guy's job is tasting the spicy curry at the local Indian Food Factory. He has to resign from his job before his tongue is rendered completely useless after all the spicy food that he has to try all day long...

梓.story: The CATALPA is the tree that bears the SPICY Indian bean (NOTE - The Catalpa is also known as the "Indian Bean" due to the bean pods that grow from it).

宰.story: Superintendant Chalmers is dining at Principal Skinner's house. He takes a bite of his meal which is unbelievably spicy. His wig pops off and he yells out: "SKINNERRR!

壁.story: Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?

璧.story: This kanji shows a policeman with a holed gem (which can be thought of as jewelry, I guess), but he thinks it's a doughnut. For some reason though, he liked his doughnuts with ketchup on them, so he added some, and tried to take a bite. He lost a few teeth on the process.

避.story: You can try and evade them, but they'll ketchup with you on the road... Sorry, couldn't resist it.

新.story: (I don't like the 'red pepper plant' primative so I just go for standing atop a tree). Here we have the woodcutter standing atop a tree waving his brand new axe. "Look what I got for christmas, yippee!

薪.story: If your firewood is too new and still has flowers on it, it's unsuitable for burning. You need drier wood.

親.story: I remember this one the way the Japanese do: a parent standing on top of a tree watching what his or her kid is doing.

幸.story: happiness is the ONE bite of SPICY curry.

執.story: To be tenacious, you need to have deep stores of happiness (so troubles don't discourage you) and you need to be big and round (so hunger doesn't drive you to give up). The most tenacious person of all time was happy round Buddha!

摯.story: Tenaciously clasping something with your hand.

報.story: Recall the fashion model wearing just a stamp over his crotch (服 (#1399)). When he got happy, of course, it ended up in the news report.

叫.story: There was a man in a village who had a special gift : whenever he shouted and screamed, his mouth became a cornucopia, overflowing with fruits and food of all sorts. Many of the locals thought he was a cruel man, always screaming at his wife, until they realised he was in fact very kind, and his gift brought prosperity to his family.

糾.story: A Pepsi promotion where you twist off the cap to find pictures of your favorite heroes like Spider-Man or members of the Fantastic Four.

収.story: Prostitutes can make a veritable cornucopia of income by using their crotches -- they put the "come" in "income." (A bit lewd perhaps, but effective in keeping this character distinct from similar keywords like 利 (#972) or 稼 (#959)).

卑.story: A LOWLY single rice grain, DROPPED in an empty FIELD, can produce a CORNUCOPIA of food.

碑.story: There is a grave of a lowly man with a tombstone made of a simple, small stone. If you bow really low you can read the very small inscription engraved on the stone, it says - “Now that you bowed so low to read this, you are as lowly as I once was”.

陸.story: My rice-seedlings have become sentient and will go on a mission. I can only apologise for the next 6 frames. In the distance, there is a pinnacle, which the newly-awakened rice-seedlings who are still stuck in the ground can see. Could it be the Promised Land?

睦.story: I keep an intimate relationship with my rice seedlings -- I never take my eye from the soil.

勢.story: 陸 (#1631) The rice-seedlings still stuck in the soil gather round in a circle. Their combined power forces them out of the ground at last.

熱.story: 陸 (#1631) The rice-seedlings (newly freed from the ground but with soil still clinging to their roots) gather in a circle around an oven fire. They need to heat up prior to their journey (presumably plants can't walk if they're too cold?)

菱.story: Some girls want diamonds, but others will be satisfied with just flowers. However if you think you can win her over with rice seedlings, expect her to get up on her walking legs and walk on out!

陵.story: 陸 (#1631) However, the pinnacle that the rice-seedlings finally reach with the use of their walking legs turns out not to be the Promised Land after all, but simply a mausoleum (containing many dead rice-seedlings exhausted from previous quests?). Oh no!

亥.story: A greedy hog in a top hat who has eaten all of the acorns. He even elbows people out of the way to get them.

核.story: The nucleus of an oak TREE is an ACORN.

刻.story: This famous ninja (I always use ninjas with sabres, distinct from samurai) used to engrave the kanji for his name onto acorns, and throw the acorns to distract his enemies. The legend goes that by the time his victims would pick up the acorn and read the engraved kanji, they were already dead.

該.story: I asked my teacher what this strange word meant, and she furiously replied that it was explained in the above-stated paragraph before throwing an acorn at me!

骸.story: The remains consisted of a skeleton which had the remains of some acorns in its stomach area. Whether it died from eating the acorns remains to be seen.

劾.story: Acorn Power is the people's way to CENSURE a congressman you don't agree with. Pelt your Senator with acorns today.

述.story: Why are the roads leading through the woods so sticky and dirty? Hmm... I think the forest ranger mentioned something about excess resin on the roads...

術.story: Behold the "Boulev'Art" : a life-size section of a boulevard cast in a huge block of resin. Some call it ... art.

寒.story: Some strange animal tried to steal a stalk of celery from my house. However, it was freezing and the floor was covered in ice, so the mysterious animal couldn't get any traction. Picture a stalk of celery and a pair of animal legs slipping and sliding clumsily around the ice, and never able to leave the house. Eventually it got so cold that the little animal froze to death.

塞.story: The A/C wasn't making the house cold because the filters had been blocked up with dirt.

醸.story: On the troical island of JOU, they brew whiskey while wearing grass skirts (top hats and scarves too). (Image: the strangely dresses islanders stirring a pot of brew. Careful 酵 (#1538)).

譲.story: The islanders defer to the words of their chief Jou in his grass skirt.

壌.story: My dream is to buy a small lot on a tropical island and spend the rest of my days relaxing in a grass skirt.

嬢.story: Conversation at a party: A: "Who is that lass?" B: "Which one?" A: "The woman wearing the grass skirt." B: "Alas, I don't know".

毒.story: If you grow up with a mother that drinks and smokes, you can be sure it's poison in the stuff you get from her breasts.

素.story: When he was growing up, Venom never had many friends in elementary school. Maybe it explains why he turned out how he did.

麦.story: If you eat lots of barley, you'll grow up to have strong walking legs.

青.story: Once in a blue moon" refers to a rare event. But originally "blue moon" refers to a full moon, in other words a fully grown-up moon. Whether once a month is rare or not depends on what we're talking about, but that happens to be the origin of the expression.

精.story: Before rice is refined, it is actually blue...bet ya didn't know that!! (alternate....Condi Rice was blue when insurgents blew up the iraqi refinery where oil is refined).

請.story: That door-to-door salesman can stand outside ringing my doorbell until he's blue in the face. There's a big sign on my front door, and the words clearly say "No Soliciting".

情.story: Feeling blue is a state of mind where you're dominated by your feelings.

晴.story: Sun and blue sky! Yep, the weather's cleared up!

清.story: Pure sea water is always a radiant blue.

静.story: When someone you know who is normally talkative goes quiet, it's usually a sign that they are contending with the blues.

責.story: As one grows up, one typically starts to blame all of their problems on money.

績.story: Spidey's exploits are world famous but still The Daily Bugle's pages blame him for every problem out there.

積.story: On many wheat cereal boxes, there is a disclaimer stating that "This package is sold by weight, not by volume. Some settling of contents may have occurred." well they only say that because they don't want to be blamed by people getting really disappointed after they see what a small volume of cereal the box really contains.

債.story: [bond; loan; debt] Mr. T buys a lot of high risk bonds and then blames his broker when they all plummet in value.

漬.story: When pickling you MUST use distilled water! When it doesn't come out right, generally it is the water that is to blame.

表.story: When I was GROWING UP, the SURFACE of my SCARF was always covered with snot from blowing my nose on it.

俵.story: Mr. T's punching bag has one beat up surface.

潔.story: To ensure she remained undefiled, a young girl growing up in a rough area always kept a dagger concealed under her threads, even when she went into the water.

契.story: Imagine a totalitarian regime where, while growing up, you have to pledge allegiance to the flag at dagger-point and with St. Bernard guard dogs watching you.

喫.story: This means eat/drink/smoke. Maybe you make a pledge to stop gutsing/binging/puffing, but your own mouth is tempting you to put something in it.

害.story: With kids growing up in your house, you have to keep them from harm of putting anything in their mouth, paint chips, bleach, knvies, etc.

轄.story: Control is very important! Especially when operating a car. Few people realize the harm they can cause just by losing control of their car for a second. Tremendous harm. Stay in control!

割.story: [proportion; comparatively; divide; cut; separate; split] Hey, don't take this out of proportion! I did you just a little harm, no need to come over here with a saber...

憲.story: The constitution is important. At least my parents thought so. In the house where I grew up, it was framed on the wall. Under the watchful (sideways) eye of my mother, we had to study it until we knew it by heart.

生.story: This is the first CELL of a human, the foundation of its entire LIFE, a small DROP that will GROW UP to form a complex organism.

星.story: The sun is the nearest star to the only planet with life - Earth.

醒.story: On awakening the first thing I notice is a (nearly empty) whiskey bottle by my bed. Then I see the stars are still shining. “I think I’ll go back to sleep and try awakening again later.”.

姓.story: When women marry, they adopt the surname of their husband, signifiying the start of a new life together. (adapted from gorgon).

性.story: When you're in the state of mind for creating new lives.

牲.story: Animal sacrifice = taking the life of a cow.

産.story: If you were to stand up all the products you have accumulated over the course of your entire life on top of one another, the result would probably be as tall as a cliff.

隆.story: You are struggling to the top across the humps, but you suddenly see the pinnacle and you feel new life in your walking legs.

峰.story: Walking legs" over "bushes" needs to have a primitive meaning of its own. It appears in several kanji, such as 縫 縫 (#1563), 逢 逢 (#2417), 蜂 蜂 (#2687), and 鋒 鋒 (#2768), and it is clumsy to work bushes and walking legs into every story. "Pointy" works fairly well: the walking legs are stuck on top of the pointy part of the bush; and for this character: a summit is the pointy end of a mountain.

蜂.story: A bee is an insect with a pointy (see 峰 (#1562)) stinger.

縫.story: Good thing I brought some thread, cause I need to sew my pants that I tore up walking through the bushes (see 峰 (#1683)) before we hit the road to go back down the mountain.

拝.story: I put my fingers together in worship of the bush that hangs from the ceiling -- that wonderful mistletoe which has gotten me kissed by many a girl.

寿.story: This old China man glued shrubs to his body. The added intake of oxygen from the shrubs was, according to him, the secret of his longevity. Sometimes he would sit all day in meditation without moving, and the locals believed the old man had actually turned into a shrub !

鋳.story: They made a metal casting of the Chinese man who glued shrubs to himself to increase his longevity. It's now sold around the world as it's thought that having one will increase your own longevity.

籍.story: Once upon a time, in order to enroll in a Christian school you had to answer a series of questions to ensure that you were really Christian. For example, the principal might show you a picture of a Christmas tree and a picture of some bamboo and ask you which one is most suitable for decoration at Christmas time.

春.story: In the springtime bonsai get plenty of sun.

椿.story: The tree of spring. Fact: Camellia are highly valued in Japan and elsewhere for their very early flowering, often among the first flowers to appear in the late winter [early spring?].

泰.story: If you look into Japanese gardens they seem so peaceful - with their small bonsais and the white stones looking like rice grains.

奏.story: When you play music to them, your bonsai will grow like they are in heaven.

実.story: Bonsais are grown in a house, away from the harsh reality of the real world where they wouldn't survive.

奉.story: To join the temple, you have to dedicate yourself to raising bonsai for enlightenment, and cornstalks for sustenance.

俸.story: Mr. T gets a stipend every month if he stays dedicated to his temple training, a very hard thing for the impatient T.

棒.story: Ha! If you know anything about Buddhist monks, during meditation, they're slapped with wooden rods to stay dedicated to their task.

謹.story: Muttering words of gratitude for a wonderful meal, I discreetly slipped my cabbage under the table for the dog.

僅.story: To MR.T swallowing a whole CABBAGE is no more than a TRIFLE.

勤.story: Growing cabbages takes muscle and diligence.

漢.story: In the water between Japan and China, the Sino- side has put scarecrows in the water to try and keep the Japanese away.

嘆.story: A sigh escapes the mouth of the scarecrow, who laments: "...if I only had a brain, I could learn kanji".

難.story: It is difficult for a scarecrow to scare a turkey or else they would've been called scareturkeys.

華.story: The Queen of England taking a walk round a village: 'Excuse me, I couldn't help noticing the splendour of the flowers in your garden. Simply splendid. Ten out of ten.' The villager gruffly replies: 'No it 'aint. It's all muck. An' I'm gonna cut it all down and sell it to the farmer for silage.'

垂.story: For an old man with a walking stick, even a drop of silage to carry on his back will make him droop low down to the floor.

唾.story: When some people are sleeping, their mouths droop open, and saliva drips out.

睡.story: Our eyes droop when we are drowsy.

錘.story: Wasn't it a cursed spindle that Sleeping Beauty pricked her finger on? Therefore the spindle was the metal that caused her to droop and eventually sleep for 100 years.

乗.story: It's a hay ride! You sit on piles of silage and everyone likes to imitate old-time farmers with a piece of wheat sticking out of their mouths.

剰.story: If you go for a ride and find a saber beside you, perhaps you got into an Army surplus jeep.

今.story: My MEETING is at 7- but that's NOW!

含.story: This clock includes a mouth that will tell you what the time is now. Hearing impaired people have this kind of watches... now imagine them as a big mouth under the clock.

貪.story: One begins one's life coveting money. One ends one's life coveting time -- those precious seconds ticking away on the clock. Remember to always put time over money (in this kanji and in life).

吟.story: To versify, words of rhythm needs to shoot out of your MOUTH with a CLOCK-like regularity.

念.story: Someone wishing from the bottom of their heart that the clock would stop. A mid-life crisis perhaps.

捻.story: Ever try WRENCHING a bolt with just your FINGERS? Trust me, you'll WISH you had a wrench for WRENCHING to save your FINGERS.

琴.story: Two kings were fighting over a beautiful koto (harp). So they had a clock built into it that would measure how long each one played it. That way they could be sure none played it more than othe other.

陰.story: The only shade at The Pinnacle is in the shadow of the giant clock tower, or from a rising cloud.

予.story: Beforehand, this was a halberd but I cut it short so it could be for hand to hand combat.

序.story: The preface to all human history was written beforehand in caves.

預.story: Depositing money into your savings account is something you do beforehand if you use your head. If you're in Japan your passbook says 預金機（よきんき）when you make a deposit.

野.story: These days we all work in front of computers. Beforehand we all worked out in the fields, in the plains.

兼.story: Our ninja hero, disguised as a gardener with a rake, is suddenly attacked from both left and right concurrently by bulls with animal horns. Our hero lets out a blood-curdling scream and tears his rake handle vertically in half, so he now has two wooden staffs (split rake handle) to fight with. He grips each staff (left side and right side) and rams it into the horns of the charging bulls. The force of each charging bull causes the tips of each staff to split again (split bottom of each rake handle).

嫌.story: Naturally, if you're dating more than one woman concurrently, they will certainly dislike each other!

鎌.story: This is a special sickle with metal blades on both sides. It can cut many things concurrently!

謙.story: When you are self-effacing you use words to concurrently bring yourself down and make yourself look better.

廉.story: Stores don't want you to know it, but if you find the secret cave, they run bargains there concurrently to their regular prices. (Image: pulling a certain level in a store to find the "bargain cave).

西.story: The old west represented by a completely empty whiskey bottle (compare 酉 (#1534) whiskey bottle about one third full).

価.story: Mr. T has a high value in the Old West because you see him in "Wanted" posters all over the place! (thanks fiminor).

要.story: In the Old West, women were needed because nobody knew how to cook or clean.

腰.story: If you want to get closer to the actual meaning, then I think that 腰(こし) is more like the hips or the small of the back. After being sat down in the office too long, people often say 腰がいたい！It's the part of the body that needs massaging.

票.story: In the Old West there were no ballot boxes. Afraid of fraud and fighting among the gunslingers, the ballots were posted into a slot in the top of the local church altar instead. They may have been rough, but the cowboys wouldn't fight in the church.

漂.story: The political fanatic stole all the ballots and dumped them in the stream. He calmly watched them drift away as the cops came to a screech behind him.

標.story: Trees were frequenly used as signposts in those days, indicating where one had to go to cast their ballots.

慄.story: shudder: You’re in the state of mind of shuddering with fear when the chestnut tree is falling over towards you.

遷.story: Since the days of the Old West, traveling has transitioned from trying not to step on big snakes to driving on big roads.

覆.story: The U.S.S. Old West has capsized, and all the cowboys on board are trying to restore her upright.

煙.story: In the Old West, they used to light fires in the ground to make smoke signals.

南.story: South of my belt leads to happiness.

楠.story: We traveled to southern Japan just to see a camphor tree. It's what we came for.

献.story: A South Korean street vendor is offering chihuahu snacks.

門.story: Heisig's stroke order in the 4th edition (and earlier) is wrong, so be careful -- first is the left-most vertical stroke, then draw the rest of the "sun" attachment as you would normally. In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you'll get the stroke order exactly correct.

問.story: A mouth on the Gates of Hell says "Answer me these questions three, or thru the gates ye soon will be".

閲.story: A little devil at the gates of hell reviews your record to see if you're evil enough to get in.

閥.story: You set a guard at the gate to fell intruders not of your clique.

間.story: The interval between star systems (suns) was too large, so the stargates were created to travel between them.

闇.story: Through the gates of hell there is no sound, no light, its all pitch dark.

簡.story: The simplicity of bamboo plant is in all its joints being at equal intervals.

開.story: To open the gate, use your both hands.

閉.story: The gates are too big to be closed by man. Only a genie can. "Close sesame!

閣.story: To keep this distinct from other kanji such as "watchtower" and "pagoda", I use the mnemonic "towering tower". -- In some old 8-bit kung-fu videogame, with a plot similar as Bruce Lee's last, unfinished movie, the hero must break through a gate at each level of the towering tower, fighting with opponents using various styles of kung-fu until he meets the finale at the topmost level of the "towering tower".

閑.story: Imagine the gates the Garden of Eden, the ultimate land of leisure. You're not allowed in, but if you peek through you can see trees.

聞.story: Press your ear to the gates and see if you can hear what is going on inside.

潤.story: Forgetting about the moat, the king stepped out of his gate and landed in the water. Needless to say he got wet.

欄.story: A column of text scratched on a black tree beside the gates of Hell: To the East lies The Beast.

闘.story: During the saloon brawl, one guy got glued to a table and was tossed out through the saloon gates.
