But he really wanted to fight, so he ran back through those gates (with the table still glued to his back) only to be tossed out again. Imagine him repeatedly running in and being tossed back out.

倉.story: Hint : the "godown" is like a warehouse, it's on the docks and mostly in Asia. To make an image distinct from that of "warehouse" or "storehouse", etc, I picture the goods stored there, piled up on pallets really high, and thus they have to "godown" before they can be taken outside. The front of this godown is a "meeting of small gates", i.e. a row of gates through which goods come in and out. The mouth can be an opening somewhere in the back, or the top, where cranes lift down the goods.

創.story: Back in the day the people were so excited to get hold of the Sega genesis they looted the godown with sabers.

非.story: This looks like a pictogram of 3 fingers from each hand trying to open up a crack in a wall. That's an un-believable way to escape from prison OR the UN- have a prison in the Hague.

俳.story: I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail cell/ I pity the fool. (Credit taijuando).

排.story: When ordered to go to the jail cell, the defendant gave the judge the finger and said he repudiated all that the legal system stood for if they were going to send an innocent man like him to jail.

悲.story: Saddness is like having your heart captured and jailed because of some sad or terrible event, etc. Here the sad heart waits for someone to come and un-lock their jail cell and set them free again.

罪.story: It is his guilt that is causing them. He is having these nightmares where the great (sideways) eye appears at the top of his jail cell, and is staring down intently at him. Guilt is a merciless tormentor.

輩.story: Some man jailed in Russia, is freed by his comrade (from the Communist party perhaps), who crashes into the jail cell with a vehicle.

扉.story: The only way out of a jail cell is to serve your time and walk out the front door. There are no other doors.

侯.story: Mr. T is made a marquis after he and the A-Team save the life of a duke. The duke also gives Mr. T the key to the gentleman's dart room where one can relax in luxury, smoke a cigar, and play a friendly game of darts. Mr. T eagerly accepts the key and places it on one of the gold chains that hang around his neck which acts as a key chain.

喉.story: If the marquis opens his mouth one more time, I'll cut his throat", his rival the baron said.

候.story: The marquis has absolutely no interest in issuses of climate change. He's old and near death. [Don't forget the walking stick to symbolize his old age.]

決.story: Decide!" "Decide?! Death by drowning in polluted water or death by guillotine. How can I decide?" I asked.

快.story: A large crowd in a cheerful state of mind applaude each criminal as they become victims of the guillotine.

偉.story: Mr. T is certainly an ADMIRABLE PERSON, so much so that parents are buying lockets with his picture in it and having their children wear them like amulets.

違.story: You lose your precious locket on the road to somewhere. You ask people if they've seen it, but no luck. "Just buy another one," someone says. "I mean, what's the difference?" Then of course you say "Well, it makes a huge difference!! Since it has sentimental value, I don't want a different one! " Then of course they understand.

緯.story: Spiderman buys a locket for Mary Jane because he wants to get HORIZONTAL with her.

衛.story: [defense; protection] For "defense against the dark arts" class, you go the magical boulevard and buy an enchanted locket.

韓.story: There's a young Korean male actor, Yon-sama, famous amongst middle-aged Japanese women. Extremely famous. Read about his affect on Japan/Korean relations on Everything2.com. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to Korea to see his home, started taking Korean language classes, etc. So, imagine here the misty eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their lockets with Yon-sama's picture inside watching his Korean romantic mini series called "Winter Sonata".

干.story: Dry one item in ten minutes on the clothesline.

肝.story: Well you all know that the liver is the part of the body that would be quite grateful if you led a dry lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol).

刊.story: The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry and then cut down with a sabre to be published.

汗.story: The way sweat is supposed to work: it gets your skin wet, and then as it evaporates/dries, it cools you off.

軒.story: Flats in the city are crowded. You get a space for your car in front, and a clothesline out back. Nothing else.

岸.story: At the base of mountain cliffs, there is usually a beach. You often can see people lying there, drying off after a swim.

幹.story: A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree-trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry.

芋.story: If your potatos are growing flowers and those little hooked roots, you should either buy less or eat them faster.

宇.story: Under the eaves of the house the poor family has potate plants.

余.story: You hang an umbrella upside-down on a hook of the scales and fill it with little potatoes. No luck: it weights too much.

除.story: To become a member of The Pinnacle, they test you on a scale. If you weigh too much, they exclude you.

徐.story: You can't expect weight loss to happen overnight. You should limit going to the scale to weigh yourself to once a day or once a week, in order to observe the anticipated weight loss gradually.

叙.story: Amazed at the weight of his crotch, they conferred every honor upon him. (Image: guy with his junk on a scale getting a medal pinned to his chest/around his neck/being knighted, etc.)

途.story: On this route, all trucks have to check in at the scales before they can get on the road.

斜.story: The main bar of an old-fashioned scale(balance) will be very diagonal if you place a giant measuring cup on one side.

塗.story: If you add too much water to the paint it will drip onto the ground.

束.story: Mnemonic: Bundle of joy. Here I see the proverbial stork with a baby hanging from its mouth fly straight into a tree. Painful, but he doesn't drop the bundle.

頼.story: We found a bundle of severed heads in your room, its difficult to trust you.

瀬.story: You need complete trust in your water guide to attempt Class 5 rapids.

勅.story: This is an imperial order for pizza. To deliver the huge bundle of pizzas to the emperor, the pizza boy needs huge muscles.

疎.story: [True story] In Osaka the homeless (the alienated) live in large numbers around the city zoo. Picture them in winter all bundled up in rags trying to keep warm, alienated from the society, living literally worst than the animals in the zoo who at least are bundled in their natural furs and have pens to live in sheltered from the elements.

辣.story: bitter, spicy, bundle: In a desperate attempt of creating a new drink, they decided to mix a bitter drink with a spicy one -- now bundled together for the same price of one! However, bitterness didn't go well with the spicy, as seen in the misshape to the left.

速.story: If you find a bundle of money on the road, pick it up quick before anyone notices.

整.story: Recycling in Japan, you have to make sure all your bundles are organized correctly otherwise the taskmasters won't accept them.

剣.story: If it helps, make the awl primitive ice pick instead. They're basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the icepick vs. the saber...

険.story: The edge of The Pinnacle is precipitous, so they have a guard posted with an ice pick to poke people and keep them from the edge.

検.story: You're giving a TREE an EXAMINATION. You take a wood sample from the TREE with an AWL (cmp 校 (#1371)).

倹.story: Mr. T is as frugal as they come. He uses his one ice pick for everything: to eat, pick his teeth, clean his toilet, kill people, cook, etc.

重.story: The first computer in the world was as heavy as thousand computers are now.

動.story: Even though the furniture is heavy, it'll be easy to move with all the muscles that he has.

腫.story: A tumor is a useless body part that is nothing but heavy.

勲.story: A meritorious deed? Like moving a damsel in distress out of a fire, maybe.

働.story: Mr. T's real line of work is for a moving company.

種.story: This kanji also means "Seed." STORY: Scientists have developed a new SPECIES of WHEAT that has large HEAVY seeds. Now we can feed the world.

衝.story: Two heavy trucks in a game of chicken collide while racing toward each other on the boulevard.

薫.story: Do you know how they make those FRAGRANT air fresheners? Well you take some FLOWERS, compress them with a HEAVY weight, and put them on an OVEN FIRE for a while... (cmp 芳 (#532)).

病.story: Caveman got ill after flying third class. The cabin air and food got to him. (Primitive: these all got MUCH easier when using CAVEMAN instead. ).

痴.story: Of course caveman is stupid. He doesn't know anything. He's a caveman!

痘.story: Caveman has horrible pox. They look like edamame beans oozing bight green paste.

症.story: Once you have all the symptoms right, you have correctly identified the sickness.

瘍.story: The witches piggy bank was cursed with a spell causing any thief who stole it's contents to fall ill. The illness would result in the victim being covered from head to toe in a mass of carbuncles. Crime doesn't pay!

痩.story: The sickness that only allows you to eat monkey crotch will surely make you lose weight.

疾.story: I picture a sick caveman, and two people rapidly blowing darts at him. One is blowing poison darts, the other is blowing antidote darts. Will the sick caveman live or die? Depends on how rapidly they fire.

嫉.story: If you go through women rapidly you will be the object of envy.

痢.story: For a country full of pay-per-use public toilets, sudden diarrhea is certainly the most profitable sickness!

痕.story: I suffer from silver-sickness, that is, if anything made of silver even touches my skin it leaves a scar.

疲.story: I picture an exhausted sick caveman snuggling up in a comfy pelt blanket.

疫.story: Sickness-missiles are being engineered by bio-terrorists to spread epidemics all over the world. Imagine seeing footage of a place where those sickness-missiles are built : rows after rows of missiles, and if you look closely on each is inscribed in tiny letters the name of different sickness such as "flu", "plague", etc.

痛.story: The CAVEMAN felt such a pain after his POGO STICK got stuck in his butt.

癖.story: Caveman has a bad mannerism of putting ketchup on everything he eats. I guess that's ok since raw mammoth can't be too good...

匿.story: Young kids likes to hide in cardboard boxes. (Primitive: CARDBOARD BOX, especially kids playing with them.)

匠.story: Most people don't know that one of the most revered artisans in Japan preserves the ancient art of cutting cardboard boxes with an ax.

医.story: The doctor puts the cardboard box on his head and throws a dart at a chart to determine his patients' illnesses.

匹.story: This kanji is used commonly as a counter for small animals. This is a pictograph of a SMALL ANIMAL'S view from inside a CARDBOARD BOX looking out at his masters HUMAN LEGS. He's probably hiding so the master does not COUNT him with the other animals which will probably be eaten (thus he avoids everyones EQUAL fate on the farm: the kitchen table).

区.story: That's the homeless ward of the city. Wolverine lives in a cardboard box there.

枢.story: The hinge on Wolverine's cardboard box is made of wood because he doesn't have enough budget to buy metal hinges.

殴.story: The city decides to disperse the homeless ward with a precision missile assault. They didn't know Wolverine was living in a cardboard box there though...

欧.story: Europe? Yawn... I've been to every ward(country/area)," says Wolverine interviewed from his cardboard box.

抑.story: A true stamp collecting nerd won't be able to repress the urge to get his fingers on the latest box of collector stamps!

仰.story: All stamps in Mr T's collection box are lied carefully face-up.

迎.story: Stamp-collectors sit and wait on the road to welcome new mail arrivals.

登.story: When an American Indian warrior dies, his body is placed on a TABLE inside a TEEPEE, and a ritualistic ceremony is held to encourage his spirit to ASCEND to that big buffalo hunting ground in the sky.

澄.story: Scuba divers know that when you ascend in the water, your lucidity increases (For non-divers, the deeper you go, the more you become mentally impaired by nitrogen narcosis, every 50 feet is like drinking one martini). Scuba divers also know that as you ascend in the water, the lucidity of the water improves, too.

発.story: Two pairs of human legs poking out of a teepee: you know there'll be a discharge soon, be it sexual, violent (husband returns home with a weapon), or dishonourable (soldier caught molesting a native), or perhaps all of the above.

廃.story: I think discharging nuclear weapons should be abolished. That includes underground tests in caves. You listening Kim Jong-il?

僚.story: Trivia: The right primitive is kagaribi - 尞 - fuel used for sacrifices. I would use sacred bonfire as a primitive . (Mnemonic: Top is a merged image of big and fire - big sacred bonfire that looks like little sun). Story: Your colleague got fired literally... in a sacred bonfire by Mr.T.

瞭.story: I paint a huge eye on the side of my pup tent. Why? – It’s obvious: when I’m at the camping site it makes it obvious which tent is mine so I can quickly locate it.

寮.story: This guy would rather use his pup-tent as a house, than sleep in the dormitory. So he effectively turned that pup-tent into a house by getting a postal address for it etc. (just to emphasize house).

療.story: In Final Fantasy 4, sleeping in a tent completely heals you and recovers all your HP and MP (and cures any sickness your characters may have).

彫.story: Start with a circumference and carve away until you get the shape you want.

形.story: Everyone in the kindergarten came up with fun and interesting shapes made out of Play-Doh, except for the kid with the amputated arm. Seems like you really need both hands.

影.story: The sun over the capital cast a shadow with the same shape.

杉.story: Cedar is an evergreen tree that keeps its SHAPE all year long. That is, it doesn't loose its needles/leaves in the winter.

彩.story: When coloring something in you grab the crayon of choice to fill in the shapes.

彰.story: The shape of a sheriff's badge makes it patent who he is.

彦.story: A young lad is standing atop a cliff, looking at the writhing shape of his fallen lass below.

顔.story: The lad jumps off the cliff, breaks his head, and smashes his face.

須.story: Why, I OUGHT to RESHAPE your HEAD...

膨.story: An injured body part may swell. It will begin to throb like a bass drum and will change shape.

参.story: I'm going to visit my grandpa in the hospital. He broke his elbow, and it became really big and contorted into a weird shape. I hope he will be all right!

惨.story: Whenever I have to visit the relatives... that puts me in one hell of a wretched state of mind.

修.story: Mr. T is a harsh taskmaster who will discipline you (beat you into shape) with his walking stick.

珍.story: The king has a really rare umbrella, it can change shape.

診.story: The doctor at my checkup was expressing words of concern about my umbrella shaped gut.

文.story: A twist on greenapple: The teacher puts a tophat on all pupils with gramatically correct sentences, while the rest are left with a big red X on their homework.

対.story: When sitting vis-a-vis, Scots will glue their kilt down to avoid embaressment.

紋.story: Who knew that Spiderman was Scottish! He has sewn his family crest onto his uniform.

蚊.story: The mosquito (an insect) knows only one sentence: Bzzzzz.

斑.story: The sentences exchanged between the two kings got more and more heated, finally leading to a fight which left the whole area speckled with blood.

斉.story: The Scotsman goalkeeper adjusted himself. He reached down and adjusted the two things between his skinny fencepost legs.

剤.story: When my medicine dose is way too large, I adjust it by cutting it into smaller pieces with my saber.

済.story: When the goalkeeper finishes the game, he drinks a lot of water and adjusts himself.

斎.story: An exorcism, or "purification" of the soul. The possessed girl is tied to two posts next to the altar, her head spinning around and around. Then the priest says the required sentence: "The power of Christ compels you!

粛.story: Even though it's a maddening task, the monks stay solemn as they rake rice between the fenceposts.

塁.story: Playing baseball in a rice field with sparklers stuck into the ground to act as bases.

楽.story: Zelda: Ocarina of Time - The white sparkly thing is Navi. She's hovering/dancing around a tree to the legendary Lost Woods music.

薬.story: New-age medicine involves using things like music and flowers (aromatherapy) as treatment.

率.story: Keep separate from proportion. Gandalf is trying to adjust the aspect ratio of his monitor from 4:3 to 16:9 so that he can watch Lord of the Rings in widescreen format. He's poking around the inside of his monitor with a magnesium needle when he causes a short circuit which sets his needle on fire making the needle look just like a sparkler.

渋.story: If you eat something astringent water will stop the sparkly sensation in your mouth.

摂.story: Now that I'm a responsible adult, I have to get my vicarious thrills from watching stupid people put sparklers up to their ears and burn their fingers.

央.story: A person with a big mouth wants to be the center of attention.

英.story: The original great seal of the king of England had a very ornate flower in the center.

映.story: In the solar system, the Sun is the central source of all light, everything else just reflects it.

赤.story: He was stabbed with a dagger, and little drops of red blood dropped onto the ground.

赦.story: The student blushed until his face was red, so the schoolmaster decided to pardon him.

変.story: It's quite unusual and abnormal to see an apple with walking legs running away from the person who wants to eat it!

跡.story: Pirate pokes the tip of his wooden leg into an apple to disguise his tracks.

蛮.story: The barbarian picks an apple from above and eats it even though there is a worm (insect) in it.

恋.story: The romance between Snow White and Prince Charming started when Snow White took a bite of poison apple and her heart stopped.

湾.story: In his most daring feat, William tell used his bow to shoot an apple off the head of his son across the water of the gulf.

黄.story: The salad did not look very appetizing... The sprouts were yellow and there were animal legs sticking out of it.

横.story: A tree went all yellow. It died and fell down, ending up sideways.

把.story: Japanese censorship laws require pornos to use a mosaic screen, so you can't see what the porno chick is grasping with her fingers (but you can assume, neetch).

色.story: Bound up in the Rubik's cube are the 6 different colours.

絶.story: The Spider-man's multi-colored tie-dye costume comic book series was discontinued after only one issue because of poor sales and fan protests.

艶.story: To print something with bountiful colour, they use glossy paper.

肥.story: PART OF YOUR BODY excretes something that is commonly used for FERTILIZER. Sometimes this process is slow, so you solve a RUBIK'S CUBE while you sit and wait.

甘.story: Little red riding hood is carrying around a wicker basket filled with sweet baked cookies for granny.

紺.story: Much like Violet Beauregarde from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Spiderman failed to heed Willy Wonka's warnings, and upon chewing on the 3 course meal chewing gum turned a very navy shade of navy blue.

某.story: I had the same idea as fuabrisu. A generic person is described here as having body sort of like a tree trunk and head sort of like a wicker basket.

謀.story: I imagine a clique of catty girls conspiring against a another girl...they are exchanging lots of words, chatting about how so-and-so girl is now up to such-and-such (gasp!), and how they will spread the word about it.

媒.story: In a divorce, the woman needs a mediator because she won't talk to that so-and-so. Imagine the woman on the ground and the so-and-so up in the tree, and the poor mediator climbing up and down, trying to mediate their fight.

欺.story: Kasparov practices deceit by grabbing your rook while pretending to yawn.

旗.story: The United Republic of Chess' national flag is actually a banner with a rook, that way they can hang it at every tournament.

期.story: The slowest remote chess game ever: a one month period between every move.

碁.story: Go is chess played with stones.

基.story: Fundamentals of chess: use the rooks to protect your ground.

甚.story: It's a tremendous match between the two chess-players. They are clearly eachother's equal.

勘.story: Intuition is a tremendously powerful resource of the mind.

堪.story: Because I hid myself behind a huge dirt barrier I dug, I was able to withstand the tremendous nuclear blast.

貴.story: Inside your purse is all of your money and your keys (き) etc. All of your precious valuables.

遺.story: Bilbo bequeathes the "PRECIOUS" to Frodo, who will carry it on the long ROAD to Mordor.

遣.story: Dispatch all cars and chase the maestro! He's gone crazy and stolen a ladies purse!

舞.story: The yakuza boss reclines in the oaken bathtub wearing his shades while his personal harem dances nakes for him.

無.story: When I enter the wooden tub heated by flames in the onsen, I can let all my worries slip away and be submerged into nothingness.

組.story: The leader of the Spiderman association has tons of Spiderman figurines lined up on his shelf.

粗.story: Refined rice [1535] can only be found in exclusive grocery shops. Coarse rice by contrast fills the supermarket shelves - don't go looking for anything else there.

租.story: The EU and US impose such high tariffs on food imports that third world wheat (the most basic of staples) never reaches first world supermarket shelves.

狙.story: When her home was invaded by a pack of dogs, the little girl climbed on the shelf and aimed various items at the dogs below.

祖.story: The ancestor worship is so common in Daoist and buddhist countries that you can buy tiny altars to put on the shelves, one for each deceased family member.

阻.story: In a last ditch effort to thwart the invaders of The Pinnacle, they push glass shelves over the edge onto their heads below.

査.story: A whole team of cops is sent to investigate how a tree could grow on top of a shelf with no soil or water.

助.story: HELP! Someone's pinned under this bookshelf and it's gonna take a lot of muscle to lift it off!

宜.story: It seems like every time my Japanese friends send me their best regards, they accompany them with a gift. Over time, I've gotten so many that I had to buy a second house which contains nothing but several fancy shelves. Each shelf is dedicated to a certain friend of mine and contains every last one of their presents.

畳.story: The king is peacefully sleeping on his new tatami mat when all of a sudden a shelf falls over and kills him. You can see his crown poking out and the brains splatter out the top of his head from all the pressure.

並.story: This is a simplification of 竝, a ideogram of two people standing in a row.

普.story: People at Universal Studios wait in rows so long that the sun goes down.

譜.story: Musical scores are in a universal language.

湿.story: You first wash you clothes with water and wring them until they are just damp before hanging them in a row under the sun to dry. If you don't wring them damp first they will take days to dry!

顕.story: One day a row of Suns appeared in the sky, turning everyone's heads upwards.

繊.story: Spiderman has to stay slender, so during thanksgiving, he keeps away from the long row of food.

霊.story: After raining for two days in a row, you plead with the SPIRITS for some relief. (Adapted from johnskb,21-5-2006).

業.story: A truly gruesome profession: an abattoir worker. Where the carcasses are upside down in a row that have not yet been cut up into sausages and steaks.

撲.story: After a row husbands take their wives upsides down over the knee and slap them with their fingers on the bottom (if that doesn't get me banned…).

僕.story: Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig method, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it's the kanji for "boku." Males usually use either "boku" or "ore" (instead of "watashi") to refer themselves. "Boku" is slightly boyish and soft; "ore" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use "ore" -- but when he's one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to "boku" when he pleads "come on baby, it's ME!

共.story: The character for 洪 (#1939) gave me the idea to use together as a primitive for Noah's Ark. Noah kept plenty of salad on board to entice the animals with their animal legs to scurry on board together, two by two.

供.story: It took over 600 frames for Mr T to 作 (#1142), the Ark, but when he was finally done, he cast his saw aside and submitted the Ark to Noah for his approval. "I pity the foo who doesn't climb aboard this ark," said Noah to his friend.

異.story: Noah's Ark is so uncommonly large, he can even fit a rice field on top to feed the animals.

翼.story: The thing about feathers is that they usually cover the entire bird. A creature with feathers only on its wings would be very uncommon.

戴.story: At Thanksgiving, it’s uncommon for people to accept humbly the food: most people just dig in.

洪.story: Water plus Noah's Ark equals deluge.

港.story: During a deluge, all the poor snakes get washed into the harbour.

暴.story: Having spent all day stringing together grains of rice he suddenly had an outburst, "I can take it any longer!

爆.story: Actually means explosion, like an outburst of fire.

恭.story: Noah feels like he gets no respect from the other passengers on the Ark, but they all make him Valentine's Day cards to show how much they respect what he's done for them.

選.story: There were so many snakes on the road to Noah's ark so they had to elect which two would represent the snake species.

殿.story: Mr. President! We all stand here together under a national flag. One thing is certain: we'll never give in. We are launching nuclear missiles now to implement mutually assured destruction protocol.

井.story: I nearly died by falling in a well. Actually, on two separate occasions. I'm glad to see they've added these fence posts. Now the well will be much safer.

丼.story: A little one is eating a domburi while standing over, looking down into, a WELL. He drops it, and it falls down & down until it looks like nothing more than a DROP, landing at the bottom of the well!

囲.story: The village surrounded the well with a wall so kids wouldn't fall in.

耕.story: If you just grow your christmas tree in a well, there will be no need to till the soil.

亜.story: In Asian countries, people use II chopsticks to get things into their mouths. Just imagine someone shoving a piece of sushi into their mouths with chopsticks.

悪.story: Because Asian people started to eat Western food, their hearts became bad and they started having heart attacks.

円.story: The shape of a Yen coin.

角.story: A museum display of two walking sticks bound together under a glass canopy, showing the first device used to measure an angle.

触.story: For insects to get in contact with each other, they need to place their antennae at just the right angle.

解.story: Did you know that you can unravel a cow? If you stick the dagger in at exactly the correct angle, the whole cow will just unravel.

再.story: The king has eaten too much and has to get a new belt again. See his fat rolls hanging over?

講.story: I have a funnel attached to my laptop that takes my prof's lecture and puts the words into a text file. The bigger the funnel, the more accurate the conversion, so picture a bunch of laptops with large, unwieldy funnels attached to the USB port.

購.story: Subscription is like a money funnel, because the receiving end is small (just one company) and the other end is wide (the whole country).

構.story: Trees with good posture look like funnels. For example, http://static.flickr.com/53/118084202_8896e54a14_m.jpg.

論.story: Right part: academic conference (a meeting, some of the attendees making notes in scrapbooks during presentation). Argument at academic conferences is naturally carried out using words.

倫.story: Mr. T talks about ethics at the academic conference. "I pity the fool who gets caught plagarizing someone else's stuff!

輪.story: During a talk at the academic conference, speaker shows an introductory slide depicting the structure of car, and then moves on to the more narrow topic of wheels.

偏.story: Mr. T is very partial to hentai comic books. I know because he dropped a pile of them when I accidentally bumped into him at the door to kinokuniya!

遍.story: Go down the road in Japan and you will find comics EVERYWHERE, newpaper stands, 7-11, Tsutaya, even the supermarket. Comics are everywhere here along the road.

編.story: I took the compilation of covers of all my Spider-Man comics that I had saved in a scrapbook and glued them on my door.

冊.story: Pictograph. I think of that Harry Potter spell book that had to be bound shut coz it wanted to eat you.

柵.story: A palisade is a "fence of stakes especially for defense," usually the stakes are very strong, set closely together, and pointed on top. Tome can be seen as a pictograph of several close-set wooden stakes, braced by one horizontal bar.

典.story: This kanji means a code of law, not a secret language or symbolic language (such as programming code) ... Story: The code of law is a tool used to bend citizens to society's will. You can use the image of a totalitarian state, but be careful not to confuse it with the pinnacle primitive 阪 (#1294).

氏.story: Looks a bit like Ft => Family title => Family name.

紙.story: Spiderman doesn't have a single paper with his family name on it (because he doesn't want to reveal his identity).

婚.story: Marriage is the day in this woman's life where she gets a new family name.

低.story: Mr. T travels to Japan and knows he must bow lower when presenting his business card.

抵.story: Most japanese find it impossible to resist pushy businessmen in Japan when they push their damned business cards into your fingers.

底.story: I put all those useless business cards at the bottom of a cave.

民.story: All the people of the world with all their family names shouting with their big mouths.

眠.story: In an Orwellian sense, the eye watching the people never sleeps.

捕.story: I was retreating from the battlefield. In the chaos, my friend threw his dogtags at me to give to his family. I managed to catch them with my fingers as the chopper was lifting off.

哺.story: The extremely efficient (military veteran) wet-nurse keeps track of which infant has been SUCKLEd already by marking each MOUTH with a DOG-TAG. (Cf. 吸 (#744)).

浦.story: The water of the bay washes all the dog tags up after the battle.

蒲.story: Bulrush was the flower that you could see near almost all bays in japan before the japanese started putting concrete everywhere. Just check how many percent of Japan's coastline that is concretised... you'll be surprised.

舗.story: A shop in an impoverished country is just a cottage with a dog tag identifying it.

補.story: I usually hear supplement in "dietry supplement". So you're given a cloak for extra fibre and dogtags for extra iron. Keeps you regular and stops you feeling tired and run-down.

邸.story: So fed up am I, I've finally built city walls around my residence to keep these Japanese from soliciting me with their business cards.

郭.story: The city finally received the enclosure that it desperately needed, city walls to protect it against attacks from the tall kids.

郡.story: County cricket. "I say old boy, you've hit that ball clear over the city walls. That's six and out!

郊.story: The country folk and and the city folk mingle at the outskirts of town, just past the city walls.

部.story: Within the city walls, this section of town was so noisy that we had to muzzle them up.

都.story: A vision of a futuristic METROPOLIS: standing at the window of your 400th floor apartment, hand in hand with your LOVE DOLL, gazing out at the gigantic CITY WALLS that you can never escape.

郵.story: The drooping citywalls was generating a lot of angry mail for the city officials.

邦.story: He reminisced about his home country: "Ah, back in my home country, the bushes grew so high that they covered the city walls!

那.story: If you arrive with two swords at the city walls, expect some interrogatives before they'll let you in.

郷.story: Your hometown is where you broke out of your cocoon (born), and where you left when your hair was silver (died), your whole life was spent inside the city walls.

響.story: People's voices are like echoes of sounds from their hometowns....you can always tell where they're from by how they talk.

郎.story: The daughter is a good girl that grows up to be a woman. The son is a good boy that grows up to defend the city walls.

廊.story: Your son plays in the corridor pretending he's exploring a cave.

盾.story: This is a magic shield with ten eyes which have the power to drag the victim towards it.

循.story: This is mostly used in the word 循環, "circulation" (of buses through their routes, of blood, etc). So I think of a column of little Roman soldiers with their shields marching sequentially through the veins of a person, as an anthropomorphization of the immune system.

派.story: Drag + rag gave me trouble until I came up with zombie for it. The zombie population became more diverse, separating into different factions. One of them being the water Zombies.

脈.story: The vein is the part of the body most lusted after by the flesh hungry zombies (drag & rag - see revenantkioku frame 1855).

衆.story: Masses of zombies, splattered with blood. (any zombie movie).

逓.story: (I prefer 2 towels over cornstalk and belt) - Have you ever wondered why your parcels always end up in such bad condition when you get them? Or why you never get them at all? That's because you've never looked at how they're actually delivered - each postman is given a load of parcel post and 2 towels to drag them down the road on.

段.story: This is a military-grade staple gun! It can be loaded with real missiles.

鍛.story: As a discriminating metalsmith, I use the highest grade metals when forging such precision devices as staple guns and missiles.

后.story: The empress is cruel. Normally she'll violently pull her servants by the ear when they've failed to follow orders. But one time she dragged this one guy around the palace by the mouth. She must have been really angry—ever since that moment, he's never been seen again.

幻.story: After the play, The Phantasm of the Opera hangs up his cape on a clothes hanger and returns to his cocoon to sleep.

司.story: The porn director has one big mouth. "Don't bother putting your clothes on a hanger, just get started.

伺.story: Mr. T is the director. You better pay respects to him!

詞.story: The big mouthed diretor is even picky about the parts of speech you use, shouting, "More verbs! Less adjectives!" and such all the time.

飼.story: After a pride of hungry lions ate the director, the producer decided to tone down his documentary and film domesticated cats instead.

嗣.story: The director's mouth dropped open as he flipped through the scrapbook of properties he was about to become heir to.

舟.story: I see this kanji as a pictograph of a two story boat seen from the front. The glass canopy is the body of the boat. The drop on top is the chimney. The horizontal line is the ceiling/floor between the the 1st/2nd floor. Finally, the two drops in the middle are the lights on the decks.

舶.story: The most famous LINER is the Titanic, which struck an iceberg and sunk. Just imagine that huge LINER strucking an even huger mass of white ice.

航.story: To navigate a "boat" through a "whirlwind" takes a skilled navigator.

舷.story: The gunwale is perhaps the most mysterious part of a boat for it is neither a gun nor a whale.

般.story: Carrier?! This means "general" (as in the general public or generally). OK.. Carriers, i.e. boats with missiles, are not available to the general public.

盤.story: What do you call a "CARRIER" of DISHes? A TRAY.

搬.story: When workers neglect workplace safety, their fingers get cut off and carried away by the conveyor belt, which looks like a 'finger carrier' in that case.

船.story: A boy floats his toy boat in a gully and imagines it as an immense ship.

艦.story: The warship towers over the smaller benign boats, overseeing their safe path from port to port.

艇.story: In venice, the boat used by the courts to transport criminals is a rowboat.

瓜.story: 何これ???? ok, sorry to be crude... if you claw at a girls melons, she is gonna give you the elbow.

弧.story: Joan of Arc ("arc" also means "bow" in french) is practicing with a bow, shooting at melons in a distant field.

孤.story: Unlike the celebrated story of Momotaro the peach boy, no one knows the story of the melon boy who was left an orphan.

繭.story: This is a simple two-column manga showing the metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a cocoon. First, the caterpillar gets under a large flower (bees tend to hang around flowers, which scare away other predators). Then, in the first frame, we see the caterpillar (insect). Then, a bar separating this frame from the next frame (remember that Japanese manga run the other way!), in which we see the insect covered with thread, making a beautiful cocoon.

益.story: The benefit of having sharp horns and fast legs is that an animal can get to the food dish first.

暇.story: Some jackass-like people have way too much spare time. You can find video's of them all over the internet, if you like such things, you can watch it all day. You see them stapling their mouths shut, or throwing eachother upside down in boxes or kicking each other in the crotch.

敷.story: Arrowheads are spread all over the field. The taskmaster profiteerer forces you to find them all using a compass.

来.story: You horny bastard, don't come, at least not yet!

気.story: Captain Hook, his spirit crushed, is lying on the ground cursing Wolverine who has defeated him with his far superior claws.

汽.story: Water vapor almost looks like a spirit but has no soul.

飛.story: Hooks with small wings attached look like hummingbirds with a long beak. Two hummingbirds are trying to fly away with our little measuring box. What do they want it for?

沈.story: (thx geezer) The maimed waitress (no head and arms just her legs and trunk) is dropped into the water with a cement crown to make sure she sinks. She shouldn't have been so nosy about her yakuza-boyfriend's schemes.

枕.story: The guy who was thrown into the river to sink was given one last request. "If I'm gonna be sleeping with the fishes," he said, "can I at least have a pillow? I'm real sensitive." The mafia bosses laughed. "Look, my doctor said I can only use wooden pillows, I have a real serious condition. Can I at least die comfortable-like?" The mafia dudes said fine, and let him have his pillow. They tossed him the river and drove off...and after a minute, he bobbed to the top, thanks to his floating wood pillow.

妻.story: Ten rakes woman. your wife digs her fingernails into you and it feels like 10 rakes when she finds you ontop of another woman.

衰.story: If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven't seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, begging people to throw it for him. Note that the mouth is closed only after the stick goes in, as is only logical.

衷.story: The guy from 哀 (#428) shared his inmost feelings with a girl and she rammed a walking stick down his throat. It ruptured his inmost organs.

面.story: When Jim Carrey puts on The Mask, he can make it seem like he has 100 eyes popping out of his head.

麺.story: I always eat barley noodles with a mask on - it stops them splashing in your face.

革.story: You can feed twenty mouths for a year for the price of ten leather coats.

靴.story: Leather shoes are nice because they change shape to fit your foot.

覇.story: In the Old West, cowboys had hegemony OVER the Indians despite their leathercraft and ability to navigate by the moon.

声.story: When an enemy's flag is raised, a true samurai can split it in half with just his voice.

眉.story: The eyebrows hover over the eyes like a divided flag.

呉.story: As a present, I gave my dentist a hand-crank tool for spreading mouths. He was so happy since it makes his job easier.

娯.story: A man from a less enlightened society comes for a visit, and asks the host to give him a woman for some recreation.

誤.story: It is a rookie mistake to believe the words when your sweetie says "You don't have to give me anything for my birthday." Trust me, your sweetie wants something, something shiny, and if you disappoint, you will suffer.

蒸.story: This kanji is used in compounds for the steaming of food and also for smoking/fumigation. Here we have the Japanese once again trying to replicate the French cuisine, only with a twist, steaming food with flowers (think of flower-smoked ham for example). Flowers must first be completely soaked in water, and then poured over a thin piece of flooring under which there is an oven fire.

承.story: To get someone to completely acquiesce it takes 3 dunks in the water before they give.

函.story: Damn racoons ill show them. I put a snare in the bin as well as a few phosphorous sparklers so as to scare the shit out of the buggers as they rummage through my bin.

極.story: Can simplify this using 朽 (#1331). Then: The expedition to the poles is bad for your health, and the decay that started in your mouth spreads to your crotch – at which point you fall to the floor.

牙.story: The kanji looks like an elephant with tusks. the box is the elephant's eye. The final stroke is the tusk.

芽.story: Zoo keepers are baffled as to why the tips of the elephant's tusks keep budding into flowers.

邪.story: The wicked queen builds her city walls out of menacing tusks.

雅.story: Goodness gracious! Such an elegant turkey with a tusk." This mnemonic is meant to join RtK's keyword with a better proposition. Heisig could have used "elegant" here, which is not confounded so easily with 淑 (#778), and accurately represents the character's meaning (it is also the chosen keyword in Kodansha's Kanji Learner's Dictionary).

釈.story: Animal track primitive: As expected, animal tracks were left in place of the trail of rice I'd purposely dropped the night before. EDIT - also try the footprint for a primitive meaning, the classic symbol of detective films. STORY: This shakuhachi player is so talented, he can do interpretations of animal noises too. They're so realistic he soon has animal tracks leading straight to wherever he's playing.

番.story: The famers take it in turns to watch out for any animal tracks on their rice field.

審.story: At your divorce hearing the judge tells you to roll dice to see who keeps the house. ("I can't believe what I'm hearing!" you say).

翻.story: Don't play dice with birds. When you're not looking, they'll flip the dice with their feathers.

藩.story: This character refers to feudal clans that were abolished in 1871 (Meiji 4) in favor of prefectures (廃藩置県), and thus were predecessors of the modern prefectures. As we know from 落, flowers and water drops each have their own way of falling. This character says that clans' location was decided in the way flowers, water drops and dice fall: at random. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29.

毛.story: I've heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That's not hair, that's fur!

耗.story: The amount of "fur" (needles) on a Christmas tree decreases, until it doesn't look all that good.

尾.story: A dog waves its furry tail like a flag.

宅.story: This kanji is, of course, pronounced "taku", and it seems the owner of this home is a little bit otaku himself. He has hung up locks of hair suruptitiously obtained from various females all over his house. A veritable hair fetishist, and certainly someone whose home you wouldn't want to visit.

託.story: When you consign a matter to someone, you get their word and a lock of their hair (to be used in a voodoo ritual if they don't keep their word).

為.story: In this kanji, you can see 3 katakana characters: ソ, ユ, and then ユ again followed by TAIL FEATHERS. STORY: "So (ソ) you (ユ) wanna DO it?" "Only if you (ユ) do" says the female bird as she raises her TAIL FEATHERS.

偽.story: Mr. T doesn’t "DO" FALSEHOOD. It goes against everything he stands for. “I pity da foos who revel in FALSEHOODs!”.

畏.story: The man being tortured was apprehensive as he saw his tormentor approaching with a hairpin poised to pierce his brain!

長.story: The Geisha with long hair uses an ornate lacquered hairpin to bundle it all up.

張.story: The longbow is follows the design of a standard bow, only it has been lengthened.

帳.story: In ancient China books were rolled-up scrolls of paper. So notebooks were nothing more than long towels.

脹.story: Taking Viagra let's your blood vessels dilate...resulting in a body part getting long.

髪.story: Japanese teenage girls consider the style of the hair of the head very important. If a particular style is trendy, soon they all want their own hair in the same shape as that of their friends.

展.story: You use an American flag to wrap up a salad for a picnic and bind it with a hairpin. Now imagine unfolding it to open up the bounty you've fixed up for yourself.

喪.story: I miss my parents dearly. Here they lay, under a big cross, their mouths side by side. I stick hairpins in their graves. CAREFUL: the stroke order/primitive order is: ten, L mouth, R mouth, hairpin. "Soil" is not drawn in its stroke order.

巣.story: Owls only nest in fruit trees.

単.story: Owls are smart...for this owl everything is simple coz his brain is ten times more powerful than mine.

戦.story: George W. Bush's plans for war were so SIMPLE. To him, its all just a big FIESTA.

禅.story: Knowing ZEN’s emphasis on “nothingness,” it’s not hard to envision a ZEN ALTAR being quite clean and SIMPLE.

弾.story: Hunting with a bow is too complicated. I'm switching to something simpler--using a bullet.

桜.story: I was taking a picture of my girlfriend under the cherry tree during 花見, when an owl happened to poop on her at the exact moment the shutter snapped. It's really my favorite picture , just don't tell her that.

獣.story: The owl looks for its prey in the rice field. It sees so many potential animals to eat but since it only has one mouth, it decides that the tasty looking chihuahua will be its meal for tonight. (adapted from Copycatken,1-9-2006).

脳.story: The brain is the part of the body that can give you the wisdom of the owl... or the wickedness of the villain.

悩.story: The owl villain is the one that troubles me most of all the super-villains. He's just so smart... you never know what he'll do! Definitely enough to put you in a troubled state of mind.

厳.story: This represents a stern looking owl, perched up on a cliff. This cliff is quite famous for daring individuals to cliff dive off of, but is any of them daring enough to threaten the owl?

鎖.story: The chain on this chainsaw is made of little metal shells.

挙.story: This is a special owl-luring tool. All you need is to raise it in your hand. Owl will come flying and perch on it right away.

誉.story: This owl's reputation skyrocketed after he created a tool in order to speak human words.

猟.story: [game-hunting; shooting; game; bag] According to unicode.org and wwwjdic, 鼡 and 鼠 (鼠 (#2856)) are variants. So, for 鼡 (which I'll call rat) I have: an owl, flying in the wind, can easily spot a rat even if it's hiding in the cornstalks. Now 猟 is easy: wild dogs are having fun by game-hunting rats.

鳥.story: There is only one bird with such beautiful white tail feathers: the albino peakcock.

鳴.story: A chirp is quite simply the sound that comes from the mouth of birds.

鶴.story: The original version of the "Ugly Duckling" was about a crane who grew up in a turkey coop. All the other birds made fun of it for not having a wattle or a snood or fanning its tail...

烏.story: The book's story is just fine, but I found a kanji dictionary explanation also interesting: As crows are all black, it's hard to see where their eyes are (black on black), so a stroke is removed from the part in the pictograph where the eyes would be.

蔦.story: In the jungle there is a flowery vine called hedera rhombea that attracts humming birds by the dozens. They scoot around the flowers sucking up nectar off the vine.

鳩.story: Pigeons are the birds that come in hordes after baseball games to eat all the trash left by fans.

鶏.story: The vulture's husband is a chicken...heck...who am I to judge their interspecies love? They're both birds so its cool.

島.story: This island is the home of the terrible mythical bird Roc. It sits mighty atop the mountain waiting for the next hapless ship to pass by.

暖.story: Ducks migrate south for the winter... they follow the warmth of the sun.

媛.story: You want to know about a beautiful woman? There's a woman that's so beautiful, the birds migrate to her instead of the sun!

援.story: You abet the escape of migrating ducks by pointing them the way.

緩.story: Oh no Spiderman has some migrating ducks stuck in his web, he has to slacken it so they can get out.

属.story: These bugs BELONG TO an extremist group promoting insect independence. They are parading the FLAG of their group, the Nationalist GNATS, and wearing explosives BELTS for their planned terrorist war.

嘱.story: The commando gnats entrusted their mouths to the translators and what came out was "All your base are belong to us!

偶.story: Mr. T accidentially stepped on Jiminy Cricket (a brainy insect, with a belt sort of sash to hold his "conscience" badge).

遇.story: I was finally able to score an interview with the wisest being around: Jiminy Cricket. However, his schedule is really packed, so they had to squeeze me in while his tour bus rode between gigs. In fact, it was really short---after a few miles I was kicked out of the bus and stranded in the middle of the interstate. But man, it was worth it!

愚.story: Don't be foolish!" says Jiminy Cricket as he lashes you with his belt. Follow logic, like me, not your heart.

隅.story: Jiminy Cricket has a favorite corner he likes to slip into at The Pinnacle for a long drink.

逆.story: There's a road that's been inverted- it's gone from horizontal to directly vertical! The only beast that could possibly climb it is a mountain goat of course.

塑.story: A legend says that if you model a mountain goat (with tail and everything) from dirt and leave to the light of the moon on the 朔 (#2862), the dirt will became flesh. (blackstockc).

遡.story: On the first day of the month, all the salmon go upstream, up the road, to the mating grounds.

岡.story: White mount , Fuji mount , olympus mount whatever ....The choice is yours but wherever you go they sell those snowglobe souvenir : under a GLASS HOOD you can see the mount with a MOUTAIN GOAT standing on top of it .... So kitsch you just can't forget it .

鋼.story: Mount Fuji is completely made up of a metal known as steel.

綱.story: Spiderman saves Japan from floating away by tying Mt. Fuji to mainland Asia using a hawser made of web.

剛.story: Mount everest is very sturdy, you can hit it all day with a saber and it wont even wobble.

缶.story: Horses kept in the mountains have a unique savory taste. At least so the text on this tin can would have us believe, which contains 100% authentic mountain horse.

陶.story: At The Pinnacle, traditional pottery is done by binding up a bunch of tin cans into whatever pot shape desired.

揺.story: For the condor primitive: A condor is like a vulture, but twice as big and it lives near mountains (a suitable place for such a majestic bird). For swing: I'm sitting on a swing when a condor comes by and picks up the whole swing set with its big finger-like claws and now I'm swinging in mid-air. Weeeeeeeee!!!!!

謡.story: Noh chanting?!? I meant "NO CHANTING!" Now all you, just shut up! Not another word! Don't you know that chanting can provoke attacks from the local condor? So, no chanting, and especially no Noh chanting.

鬱.story: [New story 2020] In the middle of the GLOOMY grove 林 you find a tin can 缶, containing a beautiful crown 冖, and a flask with very nice-smelling fragrant herbs 鬯! You feel so happy and lucky after finding these interesting items... but suddenly, they start changing shape 彡 in your hands... and turn into ashes! So, in similar fashion, your feelings, and the shape 彡 of your face, go from happy to really GLOOMY... and now you truly understand why this place is called the GLOOMY grove.

就.story: In the capital they have been having hearings concerning bioethics and bioengineering they call as their first witness a chihuahua with one human leg.

蹴.story: The soccer player was concerned that his peg leg would affect his ability to kick.

懇.story: The skunk here is Pepe LePew of Looney Tunes fame. He's a very sociable skunk, as far as skunks go, but instead of having a "heart of gold" he has a heart of silver (since he always finishes second in the game of love).

墾.story: It was the groundbreaking of the new farm, but there was an uninvited guest to the ceremony. It was a famous skunk, the one with the familiar silver stripe. The feet of the crowd rushing from the ceremony site churned up the soil very nicely. The ceremony was ruined but the groundbreaking was a great success.

貌.story: Skunk, white, human legs: You should have seen the shocked countenance on the girls' face when she saw the skunk nibbling away at the white human legs of the corpse she found in the woods. (Because of that, and the smell of course).

免.story: Obviously this is the rabbit from Alice, excusing himself and rushing away on his legs, as he has a binding day schedule. This is at the same time an image, with bound=ears, day=head and legs are just legs. The image is used in 兎 (#2235).

逸.story: Bugs Bunny eludes Elmer Fudd by pretending to be roadkill.

晩.story: At nightfall the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep.

勉.story: Notice how BUGS BUNNY's legs (hint about stroke extension) are starting to get big MUSCLES? It must be because he's always EXERTING himself on the run from Elmer Fudd (or from kicking the shit out of Elmer Fudd when he catches up!!).

象.story: An elephant has huge ears, like a rabbit, and a big, fat body, like a sow.

像.story: The statue of liberty is being replaced by a statue of Mr. T riding an elephant.

馬.story: Turkey with the drops at the top removed and tail feathers added (this matches stroke order and there are the tail feathers already, why not have the whole bird). If you take the two drops of 隹 as wings, then horses are like turkeys, but have no wings and have more prominent tail "feathers". Both are actually supposed to be pictographs, though.

駒.story: The cute little innocent-looking plastic pony on the desk of a student is in fact a trojan horse, hiding phrases in its belly which are used for cheating during an exam. No pony will be permitted on desks during tests!

験.story: We just verification that there are indeed no soldiers in the belly of this trojan horse. We're just gonna stab it in the belly with this awl to check.

騎.story: If the equestrian team used trojan horses, it would be really strange.

駐.story: Parking in the dark may be difficult...specially if you're parking a trojan horse. To lend you a tiny bit of help, take this candlestick with you, and at least you'll have some light.

駆.story: You have to be craaazzzzyy to drive a buggy led by a team of horses through a ward of Tokyo!

駅.story: Anyone living in Japan knows that train stations play little melodies when the train is about to arrive. In Ye Olden Days, when horses and carriages were used for transport, the carriage driver would play a little melody on his shakuhachi to let the passengers know the carriage was arriving at the next station.

騒.story: The hidden Greeks inside the Trojan Horse are getting boisterous as one of them is bitten in the crotch by a nasty insect. If they don't shut up, the Trojans will hear them...

駄.story: The Greek warriors inside the Trojan Horse are complaining about this burdensome plump warrior who is not helping at all (say, just eating candies and watching). - "You know you're such a burden!". Note : be sure to keep "plump" distinct from the primitive meaning of "round" ("fat man").

驚.story: You stand in AWE at the 8th WONDER of the world, a huge TROJAN HORSE.

篤.story: A fervent horse doesnt need to be whipped with a bamboo stick during a race, it will go fast by itself.

罵.story: In ancient Japan, the most grievous insult was to poke a rival's horse in the eye (consider how rare an expensive a steed was in those days). It was the final step in preparation for a duel to the death.

騰.story: Every quarter moon, the cost of a trojan horse rises one quarter by inflation.

虎.story: Magic wand + first two strokes of pelt (皮) + diced + human legs. A wizard who turns people he doesn't like into newts with his magic wand goes for variety - he has always wanted a tiger pelt - but things go awry when the tiger promptly dices and eats him, leaving only a pair of legs. (a fitting end for a wicked wizard).

虜.story: Captive men are thrown to the tigers. I think you can imagine something else is done to captive women...

膚.story: Ending up in a tiger's stomach is not good for your skin, as it's full of stomach acids.

虚.story: In Japanese folklore there is no hell, but there is the void. There, a row of tigers waits in the blackness to devour those souls who have failed in their spiritual life.

戯.story: This is a story about the end of the universe. The universe is turning into a featureless void. There's nothing we can do about it except for throw a fiesta and frolic a little bit before it's all over.

虞.story: The dentist couldn't help but feel uneasiness as he used his hand crank mouth tool on the tiger in his chair.

慮.story: Real meaning: "to ponder". You have to think with prudence (ponder carefully) about approaching a tiger, as is evident from 虎.

劇.story: A great Indian drama acted out every year is how a poor Bengali boy fended off the tigers from his pigs using only a sabre.

虐.story: Here we see the evil tyrannizing tiger. What is on his chest? A giant E, for EVIL, of course.

鹿.story: Bambi wanders into a cave and sees a side order of salad and 2 spoons...but what's the main course?

麓.story: Many deer can be found in the grove at the foot of a mountain.

薦.story: It is recommended that deers stick to eating flowers. If they try to eat birds, they may end up choking on them, like this one here. Note that the head (白) is gone and the visible part of the body which is normally written with a stroke of the head must by necessity be drawn with a stroke of the tail.

慶.story: In this kanji, "deer" replaces the "head" primitive from the "melancholy" kanji. Poor Ned is feeling melancholy so Uncle Jimbo (of South Park animated series) suggests a good deer huntin' trip to fix that and turn that melancholy into jubilation.

麗.story: The anthropologist made an exact deer painting from the cave ceiling on the ceiling of his house. Too bad they're both mediocre. All his wife could say was, "How...lovely.

熊.story: Most don't know it, but bears have the ability to walk on fire. They're invincible creatures!

能.story: The amputee has no hands but only stumps of flesh beneath his elbows. To give him the ability to eat he has two spoons implanted in his arm stumps, one in each side.

態.story: This guy has an attitude problem – lots of ability, but his heart's not in it.

寅.story: If you draw the sign of the tiger on the ceiling of your house, you will sprout tiger's legs (animal legs) and be able to run and pounce like the big cats yourself.

演.story: That was some great performance! He caused the water to shoot up into the air and form the sign of the tiger in airborne droplets. You sure missed a great performance!

辰.story: Bruce Lee is such a badass he climbed a sheer vertical cliff using only 2 hairpins.

辱.story: During the shooting of one of his first movies in China, Bruce Lee fell through the cheaply built movie set, and into a barrel of glue. As you can imagine, to put Bruce Lee in that position must have caused great embarass to the chinese producer. Note the hints in the story for the position of the primitives.

震.story: Bruce Lee has magical abilities in his newest movie. He can conjure rain and earthquakes.

振.story: Bruce Lee shakes the confidence of his opponents by simply waving his fingers in front of them, they know that each of them is a deadly weapon in their own right. Hwwaaaa...

娠.story: Any woman spending a night with the virile Bruce Lee is bound to end up with child.

唇.story: I love Bruce Lee dubbing. His lips move, but sometimes words don't come out of his mouth.

農.story: The most unlikely persons in the world to take up agriculture must be Bender and Bruce Lee. An awkwared moment as they stare on the various farming utensils, hoe, plow. Both with straw hats on and blue overalls, and drawn in Groenigs irrevent style.

濃.story: The agriculture of Florida is concentrated on making concentrated orange juice. Just add water! Imagine a can of FCOJ, dumping it into a pitcher and adding water.

送.story: After worshipping the golden calf, God sent the Jews on a long road through the wilderness.

関.story: The golden calf is sent to the gates of Hell for it's connection to false idols.

咲.story: Evil blossoms from the mouths of those who worship the golden calf. (Playing it safe and avoiding the image of a flower completely).

鬼.story: A ghost, or oni, wandering slowly on its human legs, searching for brains to eat. What looks like an elbow here is actually a pictoral representation of the forked tail protruding out of its rear.

醜.story: The ugly oni can't get a date so he drinks sake by himself at the bar.

魂.story: When we die, our soul rises up in a ghostlike rising cloud of mist up to heaven (we hope) (Adapted from darg_sama,28-10-2005).

魔.story: The witch sold me some hemp that made me see ghosts don't do drugs.

魅.story: Ghosts have not yet left the world, they must still have a deep fascination with their past life on Earth.

塊.story: This word somehow reminds me of a golem... an oni made from soil.

襲.story: The top 16 strokes are the chinese radical for "dragon". Joining up both meanings of the radical we can name the top part of this kanji "imperial dragon". Two-headed snakes do exist as biological curiosities, and they look a bit like a slingshot (with the heads splitting at a junction). Our imperial dragon here, the pet of a Chinese emperor, is a rare "three-headed slingshot-snake" kept in a vase and fed with meat. When the emperor attacked neighbours, his army wore the imperial dragon garment.

嚇.story: To upbraid someone, you criticize them in a menacing way. In other words, you jaw at them with your MOUTH until both sides of their face turn RED (hence the double-red).

朕.story: The king says "Only We are allowed to partake of the flesh of the golden calf.

雰.story: (This is atmosphere as in ambiance, mood). Rain is only part of the atmosphere for a romantic porch date. Food, music, and candles are the rest.

箇.story: You've entered in a chinese shop where apparently the only item in sale is old, dusty, hardened bamboo (for construction for example). It looks like these items have been there forever. Asking the clerk if anything else is available, he doesn't understand and instead asks - "Two items? Three items?" (the kanji is a counter for items) - thinking you want to buy something.

錬.story: Tempering should be done with the metal facing east. (If not, the metal may pick up the earth's magnetic field).

遵.story: You must abide by the revered rules of the road! No devil's brew and stay glued to your lane in the road!

罷.story: Hey, screw you! Don't you look down on me! I have the ability to quit anytime I want!

屯.story: The game characters from Worms sleep in their barracks at night.

且.story: Moreover is a literary term to shelve what you had just been talking about, to come back to it later.

藻.story: Let wooden goods = furniture. Then: Walking along the sea shore you see some washed-up furniture with water (waves) splashing against it. From a distance it looks like flowers are growing out the top, but as you get closer you see it is in fact seaweed.

隷.story: The samurai sits on the altar and watches the slave rake rice all day.

癒.story: At the butcher's meeting, all the butcher's who have a heart disease attend the faith healing workshop.

璽.story: If you find a jewel with the imperial seal on it, just let it be. You wouldn't want to be accused of stealing the royal family jewels.

潟.story: Right part: mortar bound up over oven fire, comprising boiling cauldron. Lagoon is a shallow pond, thus easily warmed by sun, large-scale equivalent of a boiling cauldron.

丹.story: How about a rusty cinnabar colored dilapidated boat, found abandoned somewhere. The smoke-stack and the keel have fallen off...

羞.story: The sheep is ashamed of it's sheepish nature, and dons the sign of the cow as a disguise.

此.story: I'm not going to use 'this here' as a primitive because it's too vague. But 'stop and sit down', usually tied to a tour guide explaining scenery works for me.//Stop and sit down to have a look at this here.

柴.story: (From mantixen's) I'll stop and sit down on this here tree, which happens to be brushwood. Now I have to brush wood off my butt.

些.story: Those two tourists from my tour group don't have a whit of common sense. They never stop and sit down when the tour guide tells them to!

砦.story: Stop and sit down to listen to the tour guide's story. "These stones down there used to be a fort, but the enemy came and tore the place down. It has never been rebuild".

髭.story: Please stop and sit down to look to the painting up there", the tour guide says. "We don't know exactly who is on the painting, but from the shape of the hair and the distinctive beard, we think they meant to depict President Lincoln.

禽.story: The villain from 離 (#1492) and 璃 (#2048). Now, hidden under an umbrella (don't want to be recognised), he is after any fowl for dinner. (fowl = birds such as chicken, duck and turkey).

檎.story: A flying fowl smashes into a tree and all the apples drop off. "Eureka!" shouts Newton, who happens to be watching.

憐.story: Tom Cruise - American with sunglasses (thanks synewave). I can't sympathize with Tom Cruise's state of mind regarding scientology.

燐.story: Tom Cruise's shoes caught on fire, because he was using phosphorous to shine them.

麟.story: As a scientologist, A DEER to TOM CRUISE, is not just a deer. It is actually a descendent of a camelopard that was sent by extraterrestrials.

鱗.story: Little known fact: Tom Cruise turns into a merman at night, scaled like a fish and everything. Weird.

奄.story: Can't work with the Heisig primitive of Dachshund, as the all encompassing big eel is obviously the mythical Norse Midgard Snake.

庵.story: The hermit's home, his hermitage, is a simple CAVE where he lives with his pet DACHSHUND.

掩.story: When your fingers completely cover something, it is shrouded from view.

悛.story: In my sorry state of mind, I wanted to make amends for cheating on my wife with a legal prostitute.

駿.story: This should be obvious, owners of prize race horse (STEEDS) are paid to have their STEED mate with another (hopefully to produce a prize winning foal). Yep, the STEEDS are glorified HORSE HOOKERS.

峻.story: There are legal prostitutes waiting on top of a steep mountain. Not only is the mountain steep, but so are the cost of the legal prostitutes.

竣.story: I like mantixen's thinking. As long as its still standing up, the streetwalker still needs to complete her job!

犀.story: Mr. Rhinoceros doesn't see well, so to prevent an unwanted attack, I don't surprise him. I always approach waving a flag attached to my walking stick. I've drawn a picture of the I-ching and an attractive cow on the flag, so Mr. Rhinoceros will stay calm when he sees it.

皐.story: What's a lunar month? The amount of time it takes a white to read just ten pages of the I Ching. Reviewing the Kanji notwithstanding.

畷.story: PRIMITIVE: Four crotches = orgy. The rice-field footpaths were where we used to have orgies back in the day.

綴.story: (Note: This kanji actually means compose/spell.) Spiderman, spell "crotch"! "Uhm.. ok.. krotch..." "Wrong!" "krotsch?" "No!" "crotsch?" "No!" "crotch?" "There you go, even though you needed 4 tries..

鎧.story: Without the right metal, that there suit of armor won't mount to more than a hill 'o beans!" said the dwarven smith as I embarked on my quest - with my aluminum-foil hat and shield.

凱.story: After eating a mountain of beans, I was able to triumph in the wind contest.

呑.story: After planting the saplings, the villagers open their mouth and quaff large quantities of sake!

韮.story: You can tell green onions from leeks because leeks are the ones that flower.

籤.story: I never play the lottery. I'd rather be whacked by bamboo staffs as I pass down an assembly line than do that. Of course, when a buddy wins, I'll go to the fiesta and enjoy the special salsa packed with green onions, but I will never play the lottery myself.

懺.story: Someone stole the bamboo from the previous lottery--but I'm sure their state of mind is very penitential.

芻.story: The 2 mountain goats have to bind up all the hay then the farmer might give them their horns back.

雛.story: The chick got lost in the hay. Now mama turkey is throwing the stuff all over looking for her chick.

趨.story: If you suddenly open the barn doors, the rats will scurry away, RUNNING quickly over the HAY scattered across the floor.

尤.story: A chihuahua with one human leg is understandably not as fast as other chihuahuas.

厖.story: Subject to even more cruel experiments in the name of biological science, the one-human-legged chihuahua is injected with chemicals that alters his shape grotesquely, and makes him as immense as a cliff (see how he's tall enough, standing right beneath it, to reach the top?)

或.story: A certain drunken mouth is on the floor at the fiesta moaning "Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa".

兎.story: A real rabbit always leaves DROPs of poo pellets behind, and his ears are no longer bound up (compere 免 (#2126)), so they flap above like helicopter blades (pictograph), and his MOUTH still is wide-open with the STAFF-like tongue, and his powerful LEGS still look like a human's.

也.story: This is the kanji for the classical form of "is". I think Heisig's keyword "est" is the old english or latin word for "is". The Scorpion this est!

疋.story: The zoo is full of critters.

菫.story: This is a violet cabbage, hanging from a nail on the kitchen wall.

曼.story: Spending the day with your eye on your crotch as you meditate on the mandala.

云.story: Think of manga where what a person says is quoted in a rising cloud.

莫.story: Thou shalt not kill", 'cause the graveyard is full. There's no room left to dispose of the evidence!

而.story: If you lose your comb, there is no point just hoping it will turn up. You must carefully comb the whole house looking for it, and then you will find it.

倭.story: Mr. T was selected to head up the committee studying the Yamato period.

侠.story: Mr T approaches the knights and stabs his scissors into the table they're seated at. "I pity the fool who questions my chivalry!

倦.story: Mr. T invented the book because he was fed up with scrolls.

俄.story: Mr. T is known to be particularly abrupt with anybody that has a big ego.

佃.story: Not so long ago, if Mr T was working in a field, he would have been a slave.

仔.story: Remember that sordid 件 (#959) when Mr. T was caught having relations with a cow? Well, some months later the heifer drops off the child at T's place. Does Mr. T share responsibility for his animal offspring?

仇.story: Mr. T uses a baseball bat for hitting foes. "I pity the foe! I mean fool!

伽.story: Mr. T looks after the kids by making sure they get enough カロ ries.

儲.story: Faith, lovedoll: Mr T, having faith in the word of God, prayed really hard for the girlfriend he could never get in the regular way. God listened, but sent him a lovedoll instead. Being severely disappointed, mr T decided to prostitute her and make a profit instead.

僑.story: Mr T, angel: Believe it or not, but mr T is actually an angel. He emigrated from heavens to right the wrongs on planet earth.

倶.story: Oy, mate", the carpenter calls out to Mr. T, "where did you leave my tools, mate?" Mr. T just hates it when people call him mate. It inspires him to misuse their tools.

侃.story: Mr. T is a man of integrity. Every time he opens his mouth, integrity just seems to stream out.

偲.story: At a memorial service for Mr. T, everyone is thinking "I pity that foo".

侭.story: Mr. T is exhausted! As is the woman who just gave him shakuhachi.

脩.story: Once again, Mr. T ventured out into the remote area to visit his old taskmaster (see 悠 (#958)). However, the old taskmaster has become very weak. His flesh looks like dried meat and his heart almost stopped (no heart). He stayed a whole month to take care about his former teacher.

倅.story: My son", sniffs Mr. T, "I'm so glad that you are now a college graduate" he said.

做.story: Note that the meaning of this (rare) kanji is "make (something) / do (something)", not "get by with". Story: Mr. T doesn't rely on happenstance, he makes things do what he wants. Edit: In fact three Japanese kanji dictionaries I checked all list 做 as an alternative to 作 作 (#1224), so "make (alt)" might be the best keyword. Story: Mr. T by happenstance found an alternative way to make things. (See also bennyb & faneca's notes).

冴.story: (Note that per Heisig, this doesn't mean 'able to cut'; it means mentally sharp, adept, or 'on your toes'!) During the Ice Age, cavemen had to be especially careful around the woolly mammoth, because they were more mentally sharp than they looked. If the cavemen weren't careful, they could end up impaled on the mammoths' tusks!

凋.story: You don't want the lettuce to wilt, do you? So, you put ice around the circumference of the serving tray, and then the lettuce on top of that, so it cannot wilt.

凌.story: On their walk to the Promised Land (陸 (#1513)), our brave rice-seedlings are faced with an unforeseen obstacle: An ice glacier the size of a rain puddle. Will they be able to pull through?

凛.story: Much more stately than that soil podium, this is made of ice. You can still see the dude standing behind it in his top hat, and he still spouts pretty much nonsense as many times as he can, but you have to admit his showy altar is quite stately.

凧.story: I'm drying myself at the 露天風呂 (outdoor hot spring) when a sudden gust of wind catches my towel and blows it into the air. I chase after it and onlookers remark, "Look, he's flying a kite!

凪.story: A lull in a storm occurs when the wind stops.

夙.story: The earlybirds always get all the best food at the buffets, and all the latecomers get are just leftover bones, you can almost see the wind and tumbleweeds rolling over it.

鳳.story: Souring in the winds there is only one bird left. The phoenix. It scorched the other birds, never to return...

剽.story: threat: To keep the ballot box safe from threats, the poll watchers were given swords.

劉.story: Because the police had confiscated the swords (though they got a receipt in return) from the group of men protecting the gold transport, bandits attacked them with sabers and slaughtered every last one of them.

剃.story: The younger brother wants to look cool and shaves himself with a saber instead of a razor.

厭.story: The poor chihuahua who had fallen down a cliff was totally despondent about his position. He saw the sun and the moon pass by, but expected no rescue any more.

雁.story: Mr T is sent on a mission to find a wild goose that swallowed some important, top-secret chemicals (they were in a baggie, so he has to find it before it dissolves!). After searching for clues and tracks, he finds it - and backs it up against a cliff. In a heroic move, Mr T jumps off the cliff, grabs the wild goose, and lands on the ground on his back, protecting the volatile wild goose. He then looks at it - wait - this isn't the wild goose, this is a mere turkey! Sent on a wild goose chase!

贋.story: The police hoped to catch the crooks making counterfeit money, but it all turned out to be a wild goose chase.

厨.story: What happened to the kitchen? It was here a second ago... Well, it fell off the cliff. See the table down there below the edge of the cliff? Maybe we can glue it back together. Of course, first we've got to retrieve the kitchen from the base of the cliff.

仄.story: So, you found a dead person abandoned at the bottom of the cliff? You think I might be involved? What are you trying to insinuate?!

哨.story: Boy scouts nowadays blow sparks out of their mouth to start a fire. Sure beats rubbing two sticks together .

咎.story: Each time I see this kanji I reprehend the person primitive for knocking the each primitive out of shape.

囁.story: If someone's whispering you'd need three ears close to his mouth to be able to hear it.

喋.story: Two good friends looking at their childhood tree house and remembering how it seemed like generations ago since they were up in it chattering away all night.

嘩.story: Mouths quarrel over who is more splendid.

噂.story: If you open your mouth to gossip about people, it's usually the most fun if you have some juicy bits on people who are generally revered, for instance that they are secretly glued to their bottle of Horned Whiskey.

咳.story: I looked up, opened my mouth and suddenly an acorn fell in! I had to cough it up quickly so that I wouldn't choke.

喧.story: To clamor means to open your mouth and proclaim loudly your opinions.

叩.story: These &^% stamps won't stay fixed to the envelop when I lick them with my mouth. No matter how hard I bash them, they come loose every time. Aargh!

嘘.story: うそ = Something void of truth coming from your mouth.

啄.story: Just like the ones on a rhinoceros, there are little birds who like to peck at the skin near the mouth of a sow and clean it.

吠.story: The mouth of a chihuahua is good at barking.

吊.story: A towel dangles under his mouth to keep him clean at dinner.

噛.story: Use your teeth to chew what you put in your mouth.

叶.story: come true" is a better keyword IMO. If you speak your wish 10 times it will come true.

吻.story: Dimples. Those knots on the sides of the mouth. Too easy.

吃.story: S... Si... S... Sir!" the beggar's mouth stammers when appealing for some help from the business man. See the mouth open and close like a fish out of water would.

噺.story: He really can spin a tale. Every time he opens his mouth, some new and creative tale comes out.

噌.story: Miso is full of active microbial cultures, so when you put it in your MOUTH, those bacteria just INCREASE and INCREASE until your mouth is overflowing with miso!
