邑.story: The city walls are beautifully built. High above you, shows you the famous mouths of former city mayors, all smiling down at you, integrated into a total mosaic making the city walls a unified beautiful work of art.

呆.story: His mouth fell open dumbfounded when he woke up and found himself on top of a tree.

喰.story: Ingest is a fancy word for what you do with your mouth as you eat.

埴.story: This one rhymes: "If you fights wiz Cassius Clay, you'll hit the soil, boy, straightaway!

坤.story: While "autochthonous" can mean "indigenous" in ENGLISH, that is NOT one of the potential meanings of this character (thus, the majority of these stories will not help you with meaning). Rather, the kanji is "autochthonous" in the sense of being Earthly, mystic, and portentous (the ancient, primitive, sacred power of DIRT and SOIL). A vague, poorly-chosen keyword all around. Mantixen's story does the best job of conveying accurate meaning--> "A monkey likes the earthy/autochthonous feel of soil".

壕.story: A DUGOUT is a dry moat found around Japanese castles. The SOIL is arranged so as to OVERPOWER (or give the advantage to OVERPOWER) an attacking army. If dug in a low lying area it fills with water and becomes a moat (濠 濠 (#2400)).

垢.story: Big consternation in the court! A little bit of soil in the garden touched the empress' face and left a blemish there. Courtiers fainted left and right...

坦.story: I'm usually flat on the soil passed out at nightbreak.

埠.story: You idiot! Why on earth did you build the wharf on a large hill? Are the ships supposed to sail through the dirt to get there? That is seriously the WORST place you could have built it.

堰.story: Soil, box, sun, woman: In Peru, they were constructing a dam and to this end, soil was gathered from the surrounds. During the excavations, they found a box, containing little statue of the sun woman (godess). A nice archeological find, but detrimental for the dam building efforts, since the work was to be halted.

堵.story: I was relieved to find my stolen lovedoll tied to some railing. She's a bit dirty but still good!

嬰.story: The woman removes the two shells covering her breasts (for modesty) and then attaches the suckling infant. How very Little Mermaid...

姦.story: Many women violate me at the same time. Then I woke up.

婢.story: Handmaiden's are usually quite lowly women, but this one is a special (just look at the way lowly is drawn).

婉.story: When asking a girl out on a date, you are only well finished when you have her address and phone number.

娼.story: Harlots are women who make a lot of money, usually, so they or their pimps are quite prosperous. Look at all her bling bling, shining like more than two suns. Who says vice doesn't pay?

妓.story: In the 平安時代（へいあんじだい）, the courtesans (women who lived in the royal courts) often stayed in the side portions of the palaces, the section that branched off the main building. Idea taken from illustrations in a copy of the Tale of Genji.

娃.story: The photographer took a picture of this fair woman framed by ivy.

姪.story: Little did you know, the woman who made you climax was your niece.

嬬.story: As any servant knows, a mistress who runs things well must be nature be a very demanding woman.

姥.story: The woman version of an old man is an aged woman.

姑.story: According to Japanese traditions, daughters-in-law have to pay respect to the woman who is their mother-in-law, because they are older.

姐.story: A young miss in a rich Japanese household is often treated with such care that she is a like a woman who is put on a shelf like an ornament.

嬉.story: Finally, I got a woman ... I have to just shriek and rejoice, I'm so overjoyed!

孕.story: A woman says to me “I’m expecting – there’s a child in here (pointing to her stomach)” I put my ear to her stomach and suddenly the child punches me – I see the shape of its fist in the stomach wall. “Well, you might be expecting, but I certainly wasn’t expecting that” I reply.

孜.story: Well, yeah, the kid's assiduous: he's got that taskmaster on his back all the time! What else would you expect?

宥.story: It really soothes my mind that I possess a house. Now at least all my payments are going towards something solid, instead of just throwing it away as rent.

寓.story: When you see Jiminy Cricket near a house, it will imply that Pinocchio isn't far off.

宏.story: During an extensive search of a murderer's house of horror, homocide detectives found an elbow body part by the side of another body. Surely there were even more victims than they imagined.

牢.story: For a cow used to free-grazing, being stuck in a house is equivalent to being in jail.

宋.story: The Sung dynasty was so-called because people kept trees in their houses and as a consequence birds sung in them.

宍.story: I was once served venison at home, but the only way I could eat it was to down a six pack first.

屠.story: Generals usually see their soldiers as mere puppets in their war game. These poor sods are given a flag and told to fight for their country. As if that would make good all the butchering.

屁.story: You haven't smelled a fart like his! His were so bad, that when he cut one, they had to wave a flag to keep folks away. None compare to the farts that he farts.

屑.story: You aren't supposed to throw an American flag out with the rubbish. The proper way to get rid of a flag is to burn it, shown here by holding a candle underneath it.

屡.story: Imagine the flag of Japan. I frequently go there for its tasty rice and to see its beautiful women.

屍.story: After meeting death, a flag covers the soldier's corpse.

屏.story: This folding screen looks quite pretty, with all the national flags printed on it, but folding and unfolding it is rather complicated. It looks more like a puzzle than a utility item.

嵩.story: High-reaching aspirations usually revolve around the mountain that is the tallest. For climbing, for descending, for just bring there - the thrill of it all.

崚.story: The next step on the sentient rice-seedlings; journey, after their miraculous 凌 (#2136) from being trapped: mountains in the distance, extremely rugged mountains, and nowhere to go next but through them.

嶺.story: This mountain lies exactly between two prefectures, so naturally there was a struggle about which prefecture had jurisdiction there. And would you believe it, one of them gained jurisdiction over the base, and the other over the mountaintop.

嵌.story: No way that sweet girl can fit those mountains of hers into an A-cup. They'll be severely lacking space. Too many sweets I guess.

帖.story: The fortune teller tells me that in the future I will have my own quire. "Is that choir as in 'group of singers', or quire as in 'sheets of paper'?" I ask. She can't tell because her crystal ball is too misty, so I rush to the bathroom, grab a towel, and use it to wipe the crystal ball. Turns out to be quire as in 'sheets of paper', of course.

幡.story: When I go to gaming conventions, I always bring my banner: a simple towel with the dice logo on it. Let's roll!

幟.story: Yep, it's a party alright. The kazoo fiesta noise is audible from far away, and look, they fashioned pennants out of towels to use as a signal flag for beckoning visitors in.

庖.story: The cleaver was found with the dismembered body wrapped up in a cave.

廓.story: The Fight Club had no licensed quarters, so they battled it out in the enclosure down inside a cave.

庇.story: This overhang has so much shade it's comparable to being in a cave.

鷹.story: CAREFUL: 雁 (#2273) contains "cliff", here we have "CAVE"!

庄.story: In the Shire, hobbits used to live in caves. Nowadays their holes in the soil still look a little like caves.

廟.story: With few visitors, the tomb sanctuary in the cave is only open in the morning.

彊.story: If you can't pull your bow all the way back, you need to strengthen yourself by eating a stack of pancakes and waffles.

弛.story: The scorpion nibbled on the string of my bow and loosened it. Now I have to string the bow again!

粥.story: Rice gruel gives you the strength to use two bows at once.

挽.story: To stop workers losing fingers on the lathes, the company has decided to issue lucky rabbit's feet to its workers.

撞.story: If you bump into a juvenile he is bound to give you the finger.

扮.story: How do you like my disguise?" "Umm... the fingers are only part of a disguise. You should really disguise the other parts of your body, too.. o.o" (Imagine the guy is just wearing camouflage gloves or something along those lines.)

捏.story: knead: After spending all day kneading dough, I realized there was dirt under my fingernails. Whoops, forgot to wash! I think I'll keep this to myself; it could be bad for business.

掴.story: Reminds me of a Star Wars quote, Leia: "The more you tighten your grip, Tarkin, the more star systems will slip through your fingers." (i.e., the tighter you clutch, the more countries you'll lose).

捺.story: In Nara, they do not accept はんこ, in fact their seals are done by simply impressing fingers into hot melting wax (fingerprints are unique!).

掻.story: Insects on your crotch make your fingers want to scratch.

撰.story: You reach into a bag of assorted lollies with your fingers and pull out two snakes stuck together.

揃.story: This Kanji means "be complete; uniform; all present"... when you want to build something or cook something, you use your FINGERS to muster together all of the parts/ingredients you will need IN FRONT of you.

捌.story: If you deal with the Yakuza, you might get a finger separated.

按.story: Think of shiatsu. You press down on someone with your fingers to help them relax.

播.story: Means "plant; sow" When sowing seeds or planting flowers, the results will turn out better if you disseminate the seeds/plants with your FINGERS in TURN . A red flower here, then a blue flower, a red flower, then a blue flower, etc...

揖.story: For deaf people, whose ears do not function properly, the interpretation of speech is often attained by using their fingers in sign language, and pay close attention to the mouths of others.

托.story: The keyword in the book is "receptacle" (which is an actual word unlike receptable). I picture a kidnapping demand where a finger and a lock of hair of the victim is placed into a receptacle and sent to the family.

捧.story: DEVOTE (new rtk3 keyword). Think of the Yakuza. To show their DEVOTION to the clan, they must be DEDICATED enough to cut off their FINGERS if they fail a task.

撚.story: Bad guys in movies always twirl their moustache with their fingers, and that sort of thing.

挺.story: The courts use their fingers as a counter for tools used in murder cases.

擾.story: A new dance, called the "commotion" where you move your fingers in a melancholy way. (Derived from "The Locomotion": Everybody's doin' a brand new dance now, Come on baby, do the Locomotion.)

撫.story: I was petting my pet, but when I looked at my fingers I saw . . . nothingness – my pet had bitten them off.

撒.story: Use your fingers to scatter sprinkles on top of your ice cream cone まく.

擢.story: Tip: feathers + turkey : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "futon" (your futon is made from turkey feathers). REF: 曜 (#618) , 濯 (#619), 躍 (#1379), outstanding (FRAME 2272), 燿 (#2594), 耀 (#2892).

摺.story: Think of Braille – rubbing things with your fingers in order to learn.

捷.story: Someone tries to lay their fingers on your spoils, and you run after them hitting them with a broom as they run from you.

抉.story: The penalty for gouging out someone's eyes is to have your fingers guillotined.

怯.story: The gambling addict's state of mind ... wincing as he realizes that everything he owns is gone.

惟.story: The state of mind of a turkey is to ponder the meaning of life while waiting to be eaten come November.

惚.story: Infatuation is the state of mind that makes a knot form in your heart.

怜.story: The commando team under orders need to be quickwitted and are always in the right state of mind for action.

惇.story: The state of mind of the tall child whom receives all of the attention is often surprisingly considerate. They have known nothing but kindness in their life, and thus act the same in return!

恰.story: I was in a state of mind to ask my wife if some slinky outfit from the closet fit her. "As if!" she yelled, "that belonged to your previous girlfriend!

恢.story: Imagine the state of mind of a person who takes some viagra, thinking it will enlarge his package, but somehow it reduces it to ashes instead.

悌.story: The state of mind of a younger brother has respect for elders, including you if you're the elder brother.

澪.story: The canals on Mars contain zero water.

洸.story: Rays of sunlight on the water make for a glistening effect.

滉.story: You know you are deep in the water of a bounding main (deep body of water), when you look up and can no longer see the rays of the sun above you.

漱.story: To gargle, put a bundle of medicine in your mouth with water and throw your head back as if in a yawn.

洲.story: Australia is the only continent that is surrounded by water on all sides, yet is still a single state.

洵.story: You have got a really, really plugged up bathtub - so plugged up, as a matter of fact, that when you get out of the bath, it takes an entire decameron for the gently swirling waters to go all the way down. You are really annoyed at this (it's gross, besides), so you get a tiny little sun and bound it up with twine, and lower it into the drain. It clears the clog right up, and the swirling waters zip right on down!

滲.story: We have a prettily shaped umbrella, but when it started to rain, water seeped through and three of our elbows got wet. So much for design over functionality.

洒.story: In the wild west everything was so dirty! With the limited water people could spare, a simple rinse was the best your clothes would get.

沐.story: In the forest fire, they doused the trees with water to prevent more damage.

泪.story: Water drops from your eye are teardrops.

渾.story: As the Pharaoh's chariots tried to cross the Red Sea, gushing waters came and crushed them.

涜.story: The church is selling holy water for the faithful, but if you dare to say its tap water, they'd tell you you were blaspheming.

梁.story: What seemed to be water dripping from the wooden roofbeam was actually drops of blood dripping from a sword lodged in it.

澱.story: Mr. President is visiting the city of New Orleans, where the sediment is being cleared away that got there when the water rushed in during hurricane Katrina.

洛.story: Old Kyoto was once the capital, but if has fallen from grace and the flowers that used to decorate its houses have all disapeared.

汝.story: One of the modern commandments: "Thou shalt not imagine wet women, dripping in their bathing suits".

漉.story: I filter my water using a deer. Sure I'm a naturalist, but you know what? The filtered yellow "water" tastes MUCH better!

瀕.story: Water dripping repeatedly on someone is enough to put them on the verge of insanity.

濠.story: A moat is a water structure used against something potentially overpowering.

溌.story: If you discharge a water gun, it sprays water of course!

湊.story: They started playing music when the ship of the emperor came in sight over the water and was brought into port.

淋.story: Picture yourself living in solitude on a tiny island. There are only two trees, and you keep getting splashed by water from sea waves.

浩.story: According to the book of revelations, abounding waters will be the first sign of the apocalypse!

汀.story: These spikes mark the water's edge in ancient times. Notice that the water level is actually much lower today.

鴻.story: A bird often found near creeks is the large goose.

潅.story: When the pegasus attacked, we did what we could and soused it: everyone knows that a wet pegasus is a dead pegasus.

溢.story: Water is to the benefit of all live forms, so when a place has a lot of water, you soon see it brimming with life forms.

湛.story: Inundation (flooding) is due to a tremendous amount of water.

淳.story: The immaculate conception resulted in the tall child who could walk on water.

渥.story: Before raging wildfires approach the town, homeowners will spray hose water on their roof to moisten the house as a preventative measure.

灘.story: Rough seas are a body of water that is most difficult to travel over.

汲.story: When you draw water you reach out and take the water from the well.

瀞.story: A river pool is a little spot of WATER over on the edge where the water can be QUIET for a while before going back out into the roaring river to flow.

溜.story: Water, detain: At the airport, crazy EU customs regulations made that every person carrying water bottles was detained and the water bottles themselves impounded. As you may imagine, in the customs office, there was quite a cumulation of water bottles.

渕.story: Moses threw the golden calf into a nearby abyss, chased the offenders that had worshipped it with a saber, and cleaned the whole spot it had been standing with water as to wash away the sins of these people.

沌.story: Chaos theory holds that a single EARTHWORM wriggling can cause huge flows of WATER all over the planet.

濾.story: The strainer exercises prudence on the water, only letting the good water pass.

濡.story: Those who demand water will be drenched.

淀.story: If you get caught in an eddy, the water seems determined to pull you in. (Edit: As Sam79's post says, "eddy" isn't a good keyword. This kanji refers to things that stop moving such as water, air, speech, etc. "Stagnate" has been used elsewhere, so maybe "go stale," "stall," or "stop moving" would be suitable keywords. Story: The water reaches a determined position and stops moving).

涅.story: This kanji should mean black soil. It is is used for Buddha's death and nirvana (涅槃 (ねはん)). Story: Fabrication of black soil. Use water to wash away other colours and and dry it in the sun (sun over soil).

斧.story: Father is sitting on top of an axe, and when I ask why he says, “Axe? It’s a hatchet, and I’m trying to hatch it”.

爺.story: Father!!! My Father exclaimed when he saw my grandpa again. [耶 (#2720)].

猾.story: The sly criminal gave a skeleton to the pack of wild dogs chasing him.

猥.story: The indecent man made even the pack of wild dogs 畏 (#2069).

狡.story: You have to have cunning to mingle with a pack of wild dogs and get away unharmed.

狸.story: A raccoon dog joined the pack of wild dogs as their computer-literate otaku member with circles around his eyes.

狼.story: A pack of wild dogs has to be really good to catch a wolf.

狽.story: The pack of dogs got all flustered when they tried to open the shellfish with their snouts.

狗.story: Mother dog: “I don't like our pup hanging around with that pack of wild dogs because he picks up all sorts of bad phrases.” Father dog: “Don't worry, he's only a pup – it's just a phrase he's going through”.

狐.story: A pack of dogs chases a fox who has stolen a melon! Must be a vegetarian fox...

狛.story: From the pack of wild dogs only white ones are chosen to be a-un (to guard the temple).

獅.story: In "The Lion King," Scar was the expert who did all the scheming, and the three hyenas were his pack of wild dogs that did most of the dirty work.

狒.story: The hunter employs a pack of dogs to hunt baboons, which he sells to zoos for a lot of dollars.

莨.story: If you smoke these tobacco flowers, you can blow funky smoke halos (rings).

茉.story: If you know someone called Jasmine, then just imagine yourself sticking a flower in her extremity.

莉.story: Thanks to Nathaniel Hawthorne, the hawthorn flower is now profitable.

苺.story: The strawberry plant is one that mothers really like. Not particularly for its flowers, but for the fruit of course, so they can make fresh strawberry pies.

藝.story: Its the oldest technique in the book. When surrounded by the evil rice seedling forces (they have gathered all around the ground around you), you dispense a cloud of rising smoke from your feet, and disappear, leaving only flowers behind.

薙.story: Get a 雉 (#2584) to trim your flowers for you.

蓑.story: Flower, decline: After your flowers have declined (i.e., lost their bloom), you can always use the remains to weave a straw raincoat. It's all about recycling these days...

苔.story: Flowers can be seen on the pedestal covered with moss.

蕩.story: When the prodigal son returned, he was greeted with flowers and hot water for tea by his mum.

蔓.story: The alien plant from outer space flowered and started drawing mandala's on the ground with its tendrils as a way of communication.

蓮.story: A lotus can either be a flower, or else something that takes you along (the car make).

芙.story: There's a popular myth amongst flower girls that the face of their future husband is hidden inside a lotus flower.

蓉.story: Those little flower buds contain a whole lotus blossom when they grow bigger.

蘭.story: The orchid thief tries to steal exotic flowers from the east, only to be stopped customs at the departure gate * 蘭 【らん】orchid.

芦.story: You must play a tune using a hollow reed, to open the secret door hidden beneath the flowers.

薯.story: A yam has a signature flower that differentiates it from a sweet potato.

菖.story: Only prosperous people (picture someone with a lot of bling) can afford to have iris flowers in the house regularly. They're too expensive for daily use.

蕉.story: Like the fruit itself, banana flowers look charred as they age.

蕎.story: I gave the angel a flower. In return she gifted me with a year's supply of buckwheat to feed my family.

蕗.story: In Aikita, the butterbur grow so huge that they use them to line public walking paths. The large flowers at the top (don't get it confused - they may look like leaves, but they are really just broad, green flowers) provide shade and make for a very pleasant public path way. Check it: http://hojinashi.cocolog-nifty.com/photos/uncategorized/101.jpg.

茄.story: Eggplant is a low カロrie flower (thanks Peppi).

蔭.story: Behind the scenes, in the shady areas, they trade various flowers: oh, yeah, gather 'round the good stuff!

蓬.story: You bring a wormwood flower to a 逢 (#2497) for the bitter parting at the end.

芥.story: Mustard has a lot of flavor jammed in to its flowers.

萌.story: You need a lot of bright light to germinate flowers.

葡.story: Grapes are totally a conspiracy, I'm telling you. They're pretty little plants with flowers that grow in clusters, and they are sweet, I know, but...Bound up in each little grape (the skin is like a wrapping) is a tiny RFID tag that the government uses to spy on you. That's why they sell them in such large quantities for so cheap - if you "pass" a few of them out, no matter - odds are that at least one will stay inside you. They especially push them on kids.

萄.story: I heard it through the grape vine"' using a pair of tin cans bound together to form a 糸電話 hidden amongst the flowers.

蘇.story: Famous resurrection: Jesus. There's the fish and loaves of wheat bread he's got under his arms and flowers in his hair.

蕃.story: First the flowers grow up, but if you aren't attentive, they have a tendency to grow wild, playing dice out in the garden to kill time. A bad seed, indeed. Flowers grown wild!

苓.story: A truly invasive parasite, the cocklebur is a flower that attaches itself to its namesake and proceeds to order the host around, the poor guy.

菰.story: Orphans sleep on the flowers of a rush mat.

蒙.story: Flower, crown, one, sow: Each year, just before Christmas, one sow is selected among many to wear a crown adorned with flowers. Unknowing of her fate, there is a party in her honor that evening. Near the end, the lights suddenly darken and a lot of noise can be heared. When the lights go on again, the sow has been slaughtered and is ready to be baked for Christmas dinner.

茅.story: There are two methods for swimming up on your enemy unnoticed. A ninja using a grassy reed, making sure the flower is first removed, will approach stealthily. A warriors scabbard, once the halberd is removed, can also substitute for a breathing tube in a pinch.

芭.story: A plantain is a flowering fruit that looks kind of like a banana, and of course bananas look sort of like a comma, so you might even say that they have a sort of comma-design.

苅.story: You reap what flowers you mow. (thanks synewave).

葱.story: The onion is a plant that has such spicy fumes, that you have to cry as if your heart is in a double knot.

葵.story: The hollyhock is a flower that can grow as large as a teepee. It almost reaches to heaven.

葺.story: When shingling with flowers, they can often block up your mouth and ears unless you wear the proper safety gear.

蕊.story: A male flower attracts many hearts with its stamen.

茸.story: My mother used to joke that if I didn't wash my ears properly, mushroom plants would be growing out of them.

蒔.story: All it takes is time to get flowers after sowing seeds.

芹.story: The axe murderer glares at his flower garden victims "First Parsley, Sage, Rosemary, and Thyme!

苫.story: The thatching of the old thatched roofs in rural Japan often has FLOWERS growing out of it when it's gotten weathered. So you can pluck them and use them like tea leaves to tell your FORTUNE.

蒼.story: The godown was filled with pale blue flowers, probably some drug...

藁.story: When a giant drinks a cocktail, he needs a straw of large proportions. He hollows out a tall tree for the straw, and sticks a giant flower on the rim of his drink.

蕪.story: Turnip flowers? Gross, but at least it's better than nothing to eat.

藷.story: The sweet potato is a plant that can be used in various dishes quite well.

薮.story: I don't even know where Heisig got this keyword from. Using "thicket" instead: Picture a thicket with a large number of flowers.

蒜.story: In the temple were two altars. One of them had the usual array of fl0wers, but the other was adorned with garlic, so that the locals could pray to keep the vampires out.

蕨.story: After eating all the BRACKEN FLOWERS on the CLIFF, the MOUNTAIN GOAT belts out a huge YAWN and takes a nap. Unfortunately he never wakes up as the BRACKEN is highly carcinogenic to mountain goats....

蔚.story: Military officers make for good fertilizer. So after a war the flowers in the military officer's graveyard grow plentiful.

茜.story: Madder red is an extract from a flower which was used as fake blood in western films.

莞.story: The candle rush doesn't bloom often, but when it does, the flowers must be perfect.

蒐.story: Debt collectors will even hustle ghosts for the flowers on their bodies' graves.

菅.story: Sedge is a flower (plant) that looks like grass, much like bureaucrats look a lot like real humans.

葦.story: After breaking up with her boyfriend and ditching him, she threw the flowers and locket he gave her into the ditch reeds.

迪.story: Imagine a trail of brussel sprouts along a road. You follow it, picking up each sprout and eating it as you go along. Eventually, after the last sprout, you find your reward – a milky Way.

辿.story: When you're following someone along a road high atop a mountain, it is easy to track them down, since all tracks lead down.

這.story: There are words written on the road, but you have to crawl along to read them: 'If...you...can...read...this...you...look...silly...'

迂.story: Due to potatoes in the road, there was a detour.

遁.story: It really eludes me why we have two kanji with the same keyword... this one and 逸 (#1973). But lets intertwine their stories: The rabbit, who eluded capture (逸 (#1973)) on the road, was finally caught when someone threw a shield over it.

逢.story: Going out on the road to use a pointy (see my comments in 峰 峰 (#1562)) part of my anatomy, is called a tryst.

遥.story: On the long long road through the desert, far off you can see a condor flying...

遼.story: (From astridtops) Faraway (2nd edition keyword) from civilisation, there are no camping sites, so you can see people in a pup tent near the road doing some wild camping instead.

逼.story: When the wealthy go on the road, they always pretend to be pursuing pressing matters, so they speed along in their big BMW's.

迄.story: Beg in the road until you get what you want.

逗.story: The negotiations had reached a complete standstill. To try and get things moving again the meeting table was placed in the middle of a busy road! That should do the trick!

鄭.story: A St. Bernard balances a bottle of horned whiskey on his nose to get it over the city walls as a courtesy to his exiled master.

隕.story: Working at The Pinnacle in not easy. The only vacation the employees got was when a meteorite fell on The Pinnacle.

隈.story: On the pinnacle of the secret government organisation, every nook and cranny of the pinnacle is under government control, even the ricefields. You can't even drop a hairpin there without being noticed.

憑.story: I entered the stable and felt an icy chill. Yes, that horse is possessed and the only way to deal with it is a stake in the heart!

惹.story: You have to be young at heart to attract the opposite sex.

悉.story: Without exception, the heart of every hunter starts beating like crazy as he comes upon the tracks of an animal.

忽.story: His heart got tied in a knot and he died instantaneously.

惣.story: The caveman, introducing his firstborn son: "And this is thing with heart. Come yesterday from woman's stomach.

愈.story: Nick XXX needs a heart transplant quick. He goes to a meeting of butchers where one of them is about to chop up an ideal heart. Nick snatches away the heart from under the butcher’s knife – just in the nick of time. (note: replace XXX with a Nick you know).

恕.story: forgive" is a better keyword for this. A woman forgives with her mouth, but it has to come from the heart.

昴.story: In this astrological tempel, a sun is depicted, overarching the Sign of the Hare.

晋.story: The churches teach that if we eliminate horniness as a universal trait, we can make progress as a society.

晟.story: When the sun comes up and sets the sky aglow, night turns into day.

暈.story: My halo is as bright as the sun, and is actually made from a wheel I pulled off a chariot.

暉.story: Every day, the chariot of the god glitters as it moves from from east to west.

旱.story: Dry weather is of course good drying weather, so everyone puts their clotheslines out under the sun.

晏.story: Under the sun and the clear skies, you can really relax.

晨.story: The ancient villain in the Bruce Lee movies said to Bruce: "In the morrow, when the sun is high in the sky, I will feed you to my pet crocodiles".

晒.story: In the Old West, the sun was the only method for bleaching hair.

晃.story: The sun's rays passed through to the very bottom of the limpid pond.

曝.story: An outburst of sun is a good time to air out your things.

曙.story: At DAWN, the SUN starts it's DAY of work, yes? So doesn't it need to SIGN IN with with SIGNATURE? Just picture that silly image for this kanji.

昂.story: Sending mail to the sun. It would take a whole box of stamps to elevate it that high.

昏.story: At dusk every day I go out in one of those airplanes that leaves a vapour trail and write my family name just above the setting sun. (I have to wait until dusk so that the sun is low enough in the sky).

晦.story: Every month, there is one day that is the last day of the month.

膿.story: If your flesh gets stung by the thorns of certain plants while doing agriculture work, your wound may infect and show pus.

腑.story: That municipality is so unsafe, thugs will attack you and cut the viscera out of your flesh to sell them on the black organs market.

胱.story: It starts in the bladder, passes through a certain body part and then appears like a ray of golden light!

胚.story: When she took the pregnancy test because she thought she was carrying the flesh of an embryo, the test was negative and she dropped it on the floor.

肛.story: The anus is the part of the body where crafty smugglers often hide small valuables.

脆.story: If you're a fragile person, lots of things are dangerous and will hurt your flesh.

肋.story: Without ribs, our flesh wouldn't have the power to stay upright.

腔.story: A body cavity is an empty space within your flesh.

肱.story: An armrest is something that lets you rest the flesh of your arm by keeping your elbow by your side.

胡.story: Only uncivilized people eat old flesh.

楓.story: How do you know if a tree is a maple tree? Easy: Just stand next to the tree on a windy day, and if you get covered in maple syrup, it's a maple tree.

楊.story: Because it's easy to spot, a purple willow is the tree that marks where my piggy bank is.

椋.story: The Oriental elm is, of course, a tree fairly representative of the Orient and thus it is common in the capital in order to show ambassadors what the Orient is all about.

榛.story: Tip: bonsai and wheat are later combined into 秦 (#2889). Story: I come across lots of trees all planted in the Manchu dynasty. Then I notice every single one is a hazel tree. I wonder why? In the Manchu dynasty people must have been hazel nuts.

櫛.story: This magic comb will comb the nodes out of wood/trees (and make the grain straight).

槌.story: Sick of being chased, the maestro grabs a wooden hammer to fight back with.

樵.story: Mallet seems to be a poor word choice for this A lumberjack won't cut down a charred tree as they're not useful for anything.

梯.story: The tree was a little too high, but, hey, no problem, I'll just use my younger brother as a ladder!

杭.story: Use pickets to hold down the tree in times of whirlwind.

柊.story: The holly tree has leaves which are always green. This is very practical in winter, when so much isn't, so that's why it became very popular as christmas decoration.

柚.story: The citron is relatively unknown overseas, but citron trees are beginning to sprout up everwhere in Japan.

椀.story: Wooden bowls made of wood have the address of the maker on the on the side.

栂.story: The tree your mother warned you about is the hemlock.

柾.story: Give the spindle tree a spin, if you can guess where it lands correctly, you'll get a prize!

榊.story: The sacred Shinto tree is a tree of the gods.

樫.story: The evergreen oak is a tree most strict with its leaves: they must be evergreen, or else!

槙.story: The tree of white lies is the Chinese white pine. The tree of truth is the Chinese black pine.

楢.story: The special brand Horned Whiskey is riped in special oak caskets made of the Japanese oak tree.

橘.story: The tachibana, or mandarin orange, is a type of tree which sometimes yields poor quality fruit. In such times, instead of simply standing up and inviting customers to make a deal, you must force the sale of your mandarin oranges by brandishing a halberd and forcing the customer to make a deal with you by purchasing your substandard fruit. [Note: along with 柚 柑 (#2482), this is used to describe all citrus plants - 柑橘類 かんきつるい means 'citrus fruit'.]

桧.story: According to the Wikipedia article, Japanese cypress (hinoki) is grown for its high-quality wood, which is used in the building of "temples, shrines, traditional noh theatres, baths" etc. So, this tree is vital to the construction of many of the major meeting places in Japanese society. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamaecyparis_obtusa.

棲.story: My wife wanted a special place to roost, so I built her one - on the top of that tree.

栖.story: For nestling, the west side of the tree is best – otherwise you get woken up by the sun in the morning. Remember: West is best for your nest.

桔.story: When you see bellflowers next to a tree, ring them for good luck.

杜.story: A normal grove is 林, so in a temple grove half the trees have been removed and replaced by soil (presumably for graves).

杷.story: All the grain that was spilled under the tree looked like a mosaic, but someone took a grain rake and disposed of it.

梶.story: An oar looks a little like a wooden tail.

杵.story: Tree, horse: At cooking school, I learned that there's always a relation between the item you will pestle and the size of the pestle itself. When I read in a cooking book that I had to mash up a horse with a wooden pestle, naturally a tried to obtain a tree to do the job.

杖.story: Wood of a certain length can be used as a cane.

樽.story: The most revered tree is one that can be used as a wine barrel.

櫓.story: The village that made its living out of catching fish above all was prone to be raided by pirates. So they made a watch turret out of trees and would look every day if the pirates were coming.

橿.story: How does an oak tree become sturdy? By eating pancake stacks for breakfast every morning. That's a sturdy oak.

杓.story: A wooden ladle is of course a ladle made out of wood.

李.story: A kid falls out a tree and the father exclaims, "Damn, son! Watch where you're going when you go plum-pickin'!

棉.story: Before 綿 (#1467) is made into thread for Spider-Man's white towels, it simply grows on a tree as raw cotton.

楯.story: Escutcheons are noble shields that depict the coat of arms of a family. They are usually made out of wood.

榎.story: A Japanese hackberry tree is a type of tree that only has full foliage in the summer. It loses its foliage in the winter.

樺.story: A birch tree can have a great aura of splendor with it's shiny white coated trunk.

槍.story: When Sir Lancelot wants a new lance he goes down to the godown (they have a nice selection for sale) and tries some out by thrusting them into a nearby tree.

柘.story: The 桑 (#754) may be nice and let you dance around it, but if it were a wild mulberry tree it would try to protectiself by throwing rocks at you.

梱.story: How do make a bale? Simple. You take a tree, like the one on the left, and you pent it up like the one on the right. Just like that.

枇.story: A loquat is a tropical fruit tree, that compared to other trees has an odd seasonal pattern: it's fruit is ripe in late winter or early spring.

樋.story: A downspout is made by hollowing out a tree and placing it to carry water "traffic" from your rooftop down to the ground.

橇.story: Santa needs to wear 3 fur coats when he rides his wooden sled.

槃.story: To the enjoyment of humans, many trees are carriers of delicious fruits.

栞.story: Two birds high up in a tree drying out after flying through a storm. "How will we get back on track? We lost our bearings!" number one cries. "Don't worry," the other one says, as he flips out his mobile. "I have it bookmarked.

椰.story: (Note: ear + city walls = 耶 (#2720)). I see a tree with an exclamation mark painted on it. "Why is that?" I think, "An exclamation mark indicates danger, but it's only a tree". Then a coconut drops on my head. Ah, it's a coconut tree.

檀.story: Sandalwood is the ideal wood for a podium: it's easy on your sandals!

樗.story: ~~ Keyword should be sumac ~~ Sumacs are worthless trees. They don't protect from rain so you shouldn't use them for a ceiling - and they stink so you can't use them to make snares.

槻.story: The zelkova is a sort of elm tree that is very good for making bonsais, setting a standard for other trees, so to speak.

椙.story: Due its tendency to encrypt all its messages, the cryptomeria has been a fairly prosperous tree whereas all the other trees have already fallen prey to espionage.

彬.story: Cedar trees are so copious they only come in groves.

桶.story: One of my favourite pastimes is that I like to jump out of a tree on my pogo stick and try to land in a bucket. When successful it makes a very satisfying "clang". (Note: new primitive pogo stick = chop seal + utilize, for explanation see my entry at 通 (#1511).)

楕.story: The 惰 惰 (#676) way to draw an ellipse requires two wooden pegs and some string (http://tinyurl.com/252zgx).

樒.story: The star-anise is an evergreen tree kept in secrecy for it's aromatic oil.

毬.story: I requested that the cat do something and he spit up a furball.

燿.story: New primitive; let futon = feathers + turkey (i.e. my futon is made with turkey feathers). Then: Twinkle, twinkle little star, oops my futon is on fire.

燎.story: The fires outside the puptent of the sentinel are watchfires.

炬.story: A gigantic fire was started by the Olympic torch.

焚.story: I'm really bad at making fires, I needed kindling from a whole grove of trees before I managed to kindle the fire.

灸.story: A mummy is running around the room on fire after his moxa treatment goes wrong.

煽.story: Fanning the flames with a fan.

煤.story: Teacher: "How is soot formed?" Student: "Well, there is a fire, so-and-so, and then there is soot!

煉.story: The East are the best at 錬 (#2186) because their fires are the best at firing.

燦.story: After the evening rice, the guest set out to entertain the children of the house with a dazzling show. He pulled a wand seemingly from out of his crotch and suddenly it appeared to be on fire! Ohs and ahs ensued.

灼.story: The cook just got a new set of pots and pans from the master of the house. Putting them on the fire, they shined so much the refulgent shine blinded him until he blocked it from his view by holding up his ladel.

烙.story: With an iron that has been in the fire, each beast is subjected to branding.

焔.story: When The Pinnacle collapses, there'll be plenty of flames for sure.

烹.story: If a fire goes smoothly you will have stew in no time.

牽.story: A mysterious crown appeared on the cow that wouldn't come off no matter how hard we'd tug.

牝.story: The cow in this frame 牝 is filling a spoon with milk from its udders, so it must be a female animal. (The cow in the next frame 牡 is rolling around in the soil and is, not surprisingly, a male animal.)

牡.story: Male animals are dirty pigs in English, but in Japanese they are dirty cows ボ ボウ おす お- おん-.

琳.story: The mechanism in my old grandfather clock suddenly broke with an almighty chime and one of the jewels was thrown out through the window into a nearby grove of trees. I'm now searching for the jewel in the grove while the clock continues to chime incessantly.

琉.story: The king was given two choices by the abductor: either the king gives him the lapis lazuli jewels, or he throws the king's infant son into the stream.

瑳.story: The king's servant got lazy and didn't thoroughly burnish some of the king's many jewels, thinking "he won't notice the difference." However, the king most certainly did notice the distinction between the burnished jewels and unburnished ones: "Off with his head!!

琢.story: The king realized he looked like a pig and sought to hone his body through exercise.

珊.story: Neptune, king of the sea has a special tome containing all the different types of coral.

瑚.story: The king had a coral reef installed in his lake.

瑞.story: The king wished he was as handsome as Fabio standing on the 端 (#1251) of a mountain combing his hair, but he realized he was fortunate in other ways.

玖.story: I spent a long time polishing the king's jewelry until it was all jet-black just like he ordered. Well, it felt like a long time, but it was actually just 9 minutes. (In addition to jet, this kanji is also used as 9 in legal documents.)

瑛.story: He who possesses the crystal stone is the rightful king of England.

玲.story: When the king barks out his orders, all the chandeliers and other ornaments in the palace start tinkling.

畢.story: First, we sow the rice field, then we plant the flowers, and lastly we plant the corn. (Stroke order and story in one).

畦.story: Ivy grows on the paddy-field ridge encircling the rice field as opposed to the intra-field paddy ridge that divides it in half.

痒.story: If you think wearing a wool sweater is itchy, just think of how sheep must feel! They must be so sick of wearing that itchy wool all the time!

痰.story: When your sickness involves inflammation, you will produce phlegm (perhaps inphlegmation?)

疹.story: He had a curious form of measles : the red marks on his skin were all in the shape of an umbrella. The doctors of course couldn't explain it...

痔.story: Hemorrhoids 痔 are the sickness suffered by people who sit in meditative poses for long periods at Buddhist temples 寺." ( Joseph De Roo's "2001 Kanji").

癌.story: The SICKNESS called cancer works by self-replication, so that its bad GOODS grow more & more until a vertiable MOUNTAIN of them forms on you-- that's the tumor, the awful sign of cancer.

痺.story: This sickness seems to prey upon the lowly of society mostly, and causes paralysis in its final stages.

眸.story: Here you have a picture of him with his apple of the eye: you see him keeping an eye upon his favourite cow, while leaning on it with his elbow.

眩.story: If you see mysterious things in front of your eyes you're definitely dizzy.

雉.story: I threw my dart at a pheasant during the hunt, but hit a turkey instead.

矩.story: That carpenter can never remember where his tools are, so there is a gigantic arrow pointing to his carpenter's square.

磐.story: If you want to take all the stones out of this crag, you'll need a large carrier.

碇.story: A grapnel is a small anchor with several hooks, used for anchoring small boats, or to pull up sunken objects (it looks very much like a grappling hook). The position of stones underwater determines where the grapnel will catch.

碧.story: Notes: 珀 (not in Heisig) means "amber". Story for both: A bus is stopped at some traffic lights in Japan. Inside, King Henry VIII and Barry White are arguing over whether the lights are yellow or amber. The lights change to "Go", and Mick Jagger (stone) then joins a new argument over whether the lights are blue or green. They compromise on blue-green.

硯.story: This is not an ordinary rock, if you look carefully you will see that it is an ancient inkstone.

砥.story: In Bedrock, people had business cards made of rock and engraved using a grindstone. (Big ups to Katsuo).

碗.story: Teacups at the Japanese restaurant are usually made of stone and have the name and address of the restaurant written on them.

碍.story: Those gremlins! At night break they insist on coming out and gluing stones all over the place. These obstacles make it nearly impossible for me to get to work!

碩.story: Mount Rushmore is a place in the US where the heads of illustrious presidents are carved into the stone of a cliff.

磯.story: To qualify as a rocky beach (as opposed to a sandy beach), how many stones does the beach need?

砺.story: Whatstone would make the best whetstone? I wandered ten thousand cliffs in search of an answer.

碓.story: Some mills use an animal, typically an ox or donkey, to rotate the stone. But in this mill the stone is being pulled round by a turkey.

禦.story: The beautiful woman has to fend off honorable admirers every day, who want to drag her to the altar and marry her.

祷.story: If you want longevity, go to an altar and beseech the gods.

祐.story: Picture a Japanese altar that contains ancestral tablets, placed on the right (on the left would be the incense).

祇.story: From http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinto: Whenever a child is born in Japan, a local Shinto shrine adds the child's name to a list kept at the shrine and declares him or her a "family child" (氏子 ujiko?). After death an ujiko becomes a "family spirit", or "family kami" (氏神 ujigami?). Therefore, if your family name is inscribed in the altar, then you will become a local god.

祢.story: The ancestral shrine has an altar that shows little reclining figurines of ancestors.

禄.story: Ancient Japanese officials collected their salarium in the shrines. A priest would collect their rice grains with a broom, and sweep it unto the altar, where the officials could collect their rice.

禎.story: When the wheelchair-bound Felicity was healed at the altar (by one of those healer priests), she was finally able to stand upright and was overcome by felicitation.

秤.story: I use balancing scales to make sure everyone gets an even amount of Wheaties.

黍.story: Millet is a small grain whose importance was greater in prehistoric times. Nowadays, it has been supplanted in the West by wheat, and in the East ("under the bamboo umbrella"), by rice.

禿.story: The dude was so upset about going bald that he covered himself with a wheat sack so that only his legs were showing.

稔.story: Every day, the farmer works in his wheat field, making a wish that his hard labor will bear fruit.

稗.story: Crabgrass is lowly wild grass, quickly spreading with nasty roots, and difficult to remove out of your wheat field.

穣.story: A bumper crop is a very full crop. In this particular case, the bumper crop is a wheat crop, grown by this excentric guy in a grass skirt, who has gone completely native, but knows the secrets of how to get a good crop!

稜.story: Wheat, rice seedling, walking legs: The next hurdle for mission of the rice seedlings with walking legs was the imperial authority. They had to cross through a wheat field, but the imperial authority didn't give permission for rice seedlings and wheat to mix. How to solve this...?

稀.story: This region only has sparse agriculture. The few farmers hope their wheat crops will do well, but the soil isn't really good.

穆.story: I'm being obeisant to Doctor's orders -- trying to get into shape by eating only wheat and drinking only from that spring.

窺.story: Ladies, I apologize for peeping through the hole, but, you know, it's just standard protocol.

窄.story: That hole is still too tight. Bring the saw to enlarge it!

穿.story: There's a knock on my door, and it's the local dentist accompanied by an elephant. The latter is a patient, and the dentist explains that he wants to drill a hole in its tusk, but his normal dentist's drill is too small, so could he borrow my big DIY drill. Anyway, I drill the hole in the tusk for him.

竃.story: The original Japanese kitchen stoves were powered by electric eels (hey, Edison never made it to the far east!), so a small hole had to be placed in the dirt under the stove (for the eels to swim around in).

竪.story: When you're a slave to your crotch like me, you're often afraid to stand because you don't want people to see your longness.

颯.story: When I hear rustling in the night I stand up and go to check out what it is but it's always just wind.

站.story: A characteristic of an outpost is the lack of usual facilities. Here we see a fortune teller with no crystal ball having to make do with a vase.

靖.story: Many repose peacefully in a blue vase after being cremated.

妾.story: It's a concubine: feel free to 接 (#725) her all you want.

衿.story: Cloak, clock: The cloaks of Muslims have a tiny clock on their lapel, so that they can keep track on when to pray...

袷.story: Cloak, fit: The lined kimono was lined in such a way that it made people appear to be slimmer than they really were. Even people who didn't fit in the accompanying cloak still bought the lined kimono...

袴.story: You can 誇 誇 (#1332) with words, or you can instead show off your expensive cloak and hakama.

襖.story: Before you open the sliding door to the core of the nuclear reactor, you'd better put on your anti-radioactivity cloak.

笙.story: The Chinese panpipe is an old musical instrument made of bamboo. People practiced the Chinese panpipe their whole life just so that they could play for the emperor, often a bad performance would have the emperor take their life away from them.

筏.story: The bamboo was felled to make a raft.

簾.story: I see a load of bamboo for sale at a bargain price and decide it’s so cheap that I’ll buy it and make my own bamboo blinds.

箪.story: If you are making a rattan box, then the best advice I can give you is to use bamboo and keep it simple.

竿.story: In Japan they use bamboo poles to dry their clothes on.

箆.story: Compare the effectiveness of beating a person with bamboo, a belt, and a spatula.

箔.story: If I have any bamboo shoots left over from my stirfry I wrap them up in foil to keep them moist overnight. Then I can use them the next day.

笥.story: The film director is making a new low budget version of "The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe". As we watch him, he appears to be constructing something out of bamboo. Finally the director says, "Well, no lion or witch yet, but thanks to this bamboo at least the wardrobe is finished".

箭.story: Bamboo, in front: Martial arts movie. The hero walks through a bamboo forest, and suddenly an arrow shaft stands quivering in the bamboo tree just in front of him. Time for some action scenes.

筑.story: I can't play this ancient harp! It's craftsmanship is so mediocre! The bamboo is hard and stiff! Give me a new koto any day of the week.

篠.story: Mr T uses a stick of slender bamboo to beat his taskmaster that he chased up into the tree.

纂.story: During post-production of a movie, redaction is required for "red action", or action that results in a bloody accident, like when they miscalculated how large an object Spider-Man could hold up with both hands.

竺.story: My bamboo cane is collapsible. It can fold into two separate bamboo sticks.

箕.story: The chess player has a bamboo fan that he brings along to his matches for good luck. It has the power to make the user WIN NOW. Thus it is a winnowing fan.

笈.story: I see a panda wearing a backpack, and every so often something inside the backpack reaches out and grabs bamboo. (it’s acutally a baby panda reaching out to grab bamboo to eat).

篇.story: Each livraison (installment) of the scrapbook is delivered by post, and sits resting on your doorstep for when you get home. Of course, it might blow away so the postman has put heavy bamboo blocks on top of it.

筈.story: Should you put bamboo through your tongue? If you don't already know the answer yourself, you shouldn't even ask.

簸.story: To winnow you need two things: a winnowing fan (no. 2643 箕) and a pelt (to use as a bag to collect the grain you winnowed).

粕.story: Settlings at the bottom of sake are white and made of rice.

糟.story: New cadets aren't allowed to drink with the seniors, so they have to settle for the rice lees at the bottom of the empty sake bottles.

糊.story: The uncivilized used rice as paste.

籾.story: Unhulled rice still needs a blade taken to it.

糠.story: Rice bran is for old people: its benefits to sanity in additional to being delicious rice make it an instant sell.

糞.story: Rice is easy to digest, so if you poke through your excrement, finding bits of rice is uncommon.

粟.story: Maybe the Japanese ought to rethink their nickname for America. Seriously, the only "rice" I have seen in the wild west is foxtail millet.

繋.story: This should do the trick: http://tinyurl.com/dzhu4g.

綸.story: Spidey assists the older ladies at the twine convention by providing them with a continuous line of twine to knit with. They thank him for the twine with some wine.

絨.story: Spiderman, burgler - money (賊 (#381)): When the old lady returned from visiting the fiesta, she found a burglar in her home tied up with carpet yarn. A note said: Regards from you friendly neighborhood Spiderman. Well, she was not amused when she saw the remains of her carpet.

絆.story: Spiderman, half: Since only half of his family was left (aunt May, uncle died), Spiderman kept strong ties with her.

緋.story: Spiderman is put in a jail cell by the fashion police for wearing scarlet. (His fellow inmates include Scarlet O'Hara, Scarlett Johansson, Captain Scarlet, The Scarlet Pimpernel, etc).

綜.story: Spider-Man's religion is a synthesis of spirituality and scientific proof.

紐.story: A vegetarian replaces all his leather bootlaces with string, saying “There’s no sign of the cow in this thread!”.

紘.story: Spider-Man poses with his hands on his hips to convey being larger than life.

纏.story: Spiderman, cave, computer, human legs, soil: To summarize the newest Spiderman comic: Spidy needs to turn off a computer in a cave (countdown clock for nuclear bomb). However, his human legs get stuck in the soil (some kind of quicksand). The situation seems hopeless... but somehow at the end of the comic, Spiderman has saved the day.

絢.story: Spider-Man is quite the womanizer. When he sees a hot babe, he whistles and calls, 'Hey, gorgeous, how'd you like to be bound up with Spidey for a decameron?' Unfortunately most of the women he whistles at don't know what a decameron is; some of them think it's a hot car.

繍.story: Spiderman solemnly swears that he hates embroidery, but everyone knows he loves it, he's always got the sewing machine out when nobody else is around.

紬.story: Spiderman decides to try a new diet of sprouts to see how it affects the consistency of his web. To his surprise (150m above ground) a lovely line of pongee comes out instead. Time to think quickly.

綺.story: Spiderman's a strange guy, wearing such ornate outfits to make himself look 綺麗【きれい】.

綾.story: The rice seedlings notice that Spiderman's blocking their path to the promised land. So they put on da mask which was made of a figured cloth and managed to outsmart spidey.

絃.story: The thread with a mysterious origin... hint: its not from a plant!

縞.story: Spiderman, tall: Spiderman seemed taller than he really was, due to the stripes in his uniform. As is to be expected from our textile expert...

綬.story: Spiderman accepts the ribbon for most fashionable super hero.

紗.story: If there are very few threads, then the light will come through and the fabric be considered to be a gossamer.

舵.story: A household spoon is used for the rudder of your model boat.

聯.story: My friend's new dangly earrings are interesting--cacti strung together with butterfly cocoons.

聡.story: Policymakers' ears have to be attentive to the heart of the public.

聘.story: Ear, sprout, snare: When the summons reached his ears, he sprang up and started running. However, he suddenly noticed a delicious cooked meal of Brussel sprouts. He started to eat it, but it was snared! Appearantly, his loyalty had been tested and it was clear which was more important to him...

耽.story: The waitress's addiction to drugs got her caught up in a huge mess with the mafia. Before maiming her and throwing her into the river to 沈 (#1888), they cut off one of her ears.

耶.story: Quiet!!!! The city walls have ears he exclaimed.

蚤.story: Fleas jump onto your crotch, take two drops of blood, and then go on their merry way: what vile insects!

蟹.story: The crab isn’t truly an insect, but certainly looks like one. They’re real tasty, too, but you have to unravel it if you want to eat it.

蛋.story: At the zoo, most animals think of insects as just good sources of protein.

蟄.story: Rather than die, tenacious insects go down into hibernation.

蝿.story: I unbind my tortoise to let him catch that pesky insect the housefly.

蟻.story: The ant is an insect of righteousness, putting the group before its individual concerns.

蝋.story: While I’m game-hunting, I cover my dogs with wax so that they won’t be bother by insects.

蝦.story: Shrimp are the only “insects” that I can eat in my spare time: anything else requires way too much willpower.

蛸.story: The octopus holds up two of his legs so that they look like antennas and then walks on the other six. He bears a strong resemblance to an insect when he does that.

螺.story: 螺　(にし) is a fresh water mollusk with a shell like a screw. When the mollusk has died the shell is used by insects like a house. Thus, insects accumulate in the screw shell.

蝉.story: Cicadas are simple insects: they just pop out of the ground, mate, and die, albeit only every ten years or so.

蛙.story: There he sits, eating insects with his long tongue and blending in with the green ivy. It may no be easy being green, but it is easy being a frog.

蛾.story: The moth is an insect with an ego -- always looking for the (lime)light.

蛤.story: An insect fits right into the clam's mouth before it clamps shut.

蛭.story: The leech is an insect that sucks on you, but good luck reaching climax with all that blood being lost.

蛎.story: An insect crosses ten thousand cliffs to make it to sea, only to be eaten by an oyster.

罫.story: Keeping my eye fixed directly over the paper, I hold down the ivy and melt the strands with my magic wand. Viola, ruled lines are created! I bet most people think a machine does it.

袈.story: In Japanese RPGs, you are well advised to add a stole to your clothing as a "freebie" way to add defensive points without swapping out some other garment. But since you can't find them in the shops, you have to "stole" that stole from a glamorous NPC who is ostensibly there to aid your quest.

裟.story: A monk's sash is a garment that has grains of sand in it from beachside meditations.

截.story: I’ll do the honors! So, I grabbed the knife and made an incision into the Thanksgiving turkey.

哉.story: At Thanksgiving, there’s a pretty common bet: I wonder how much you can stuff into your mouth!

詢.story: In order to provide superior counsel, I spoke to him for ten days.

諄.story: When receiving a gift, you should say something polite.

讐.story: In many Sicilian villages, when words are spoken which can never be taken back, a vendetta exists until this retribution - "a turkey for a turkey" - can be extracted.

諌.story: Words in the East remonstrate those who stand out.

諒.story: When a Japanese person says they'll meet you at the capital, it's best to verify whether they mean Tokyo or Kyoto.

訊.story: Word, needle, fishhook: The prisoner didn't speak a word in response to our query, so we got out our needles and fishhooks to get things going.

訣.story: When you split up from your partner, you say words that cut things off for good, like a guillotine.

詫.story: I'm going out with an otaku" "I beg your pardon! What did you just say?!

誼.story: After someone moves into the house next door, and after you give them a best regards gift (something they can fill their shelves with) the words you can now speak are those of familiarity. No more "始めまして" ect.

謬.story: Check-up (診 (#1860)), feathers: When, during the check-up, I noticed that the doctor had feathers sticking out of different bodyparts, I decided that his diagnosis would be fallible, since he obviously was a nut.

訝.story: doubtful: word, tusk: (During a safari). It may be me, but I am doubtful that the elephant understood any of my words. He's still coming at me, with his tusks ready.

諺.story: Words, lad: The lad keeping watch at the cliff came running to town and began pouring out words. Leader: "What? I don't understand a word you're saying. Oh yeah, now I remember... you're the lad who speaks in proverbs.

誹.story: If you slander someone with your words, you could end up in jail - Jeffrey Archer.

謂.story: That so-called specialist's exact words were "don't worry, its just an upset stomach!" When it turned out to be cancer, his words dried up quick.

諜.story: Words, generation, tree: You see that guy over there having words with that tree? That's a secret agent. And you see that tree there? That's a secret agent too: the new generation of secret agents is not limited to the human race anymore.

註.story: A study Bible has many footnotes under the words of the Lord.

譬.story: A parable is like putting ketchup on words to make them easier to swallow.

轟.story: Many cars rumble through the streets as the bousouzoku ride through.

輔.story: Car, dog tag: A car hung with hundreds of military dog tags passed by the police station. The officer on duty immediately called in for reinforcements: the notorious veteran soldier killer had just passed by.

輻.story: Wealthy people tend to have cars with solid gold spokes, sometimes they even spin with the car's not in motion, kinda cool.

輯.story: When they offered a really cheap Porsche, my mouth dropped open and I bought that car immediately, but if I had had my ears open, I would have heard, "Some assembly may be required.

豹.story: Imagine that in the cartoon series the pink panther is in a dispute with a skunk. Picture the skunk filling a ladle with its stink liquid and then emptying it onto a snoozing pink panther.

賎.story: Money, float: It's despicable. They throw down money off the carnaval float, while there are so many people in this world living in poverty. Just give it to them. Despicable!

貰.story: You get money from the generation above you.

賑.story: Bruce Lee made his clams in the bustling city of Hong Kong.

贖.story: To make atonement for taking one shell, the samurai must pay four shells.

躓.story: At the border crossing, a man was trying to smuggle a controlled substance in his wooden leg. He would have made it too had he not stumbled and spilled the contents.

蹄.story: After He lost a leg in combat, our sovereign king got a wooden leg as a replacement. Since He thought it was a little boring, he added a hoof for kicks. (Wow, that was totally unintentional, I like).

蹟.story: The man who lost his leg in a accident now has to attach a wooden leg to the vestiges of his old leg. He only has himself to blame for drinking and driving.

跨.story: The amputee boasts about how the ladies just love to straddle his wooden leg.

跪.story: It's dangerous to kneel with a wooden leg. It might fall off.

醤.story: The leader's whiskey bottle is filled with soy sauce since he doesn't drink alcohol but likes to pretend he's one of the boys by making a strained face when he takes a swig.

醍.story: When filling a whiskey bottle with a whey mixture, you've got to get the proportions just so or it will just taste like curdled milk.

醐.story: Drinking ghee out of a whiskey bottle is rather 胡 (#2470).

醇.story: Whiskey bottle, receive: When you receive a bottle of whiskey from a Japanese person, large chance it is strong saké. It seems that giving 'sissy' saké is considered impolite.

麹.story: Malt made from barley is often bound up with rice for brewing.

釦.story: A button is metal that requires an opening in order to function.

銚.story: A big metal keg portends a good party.

鋤.story: Tilling a field by hand is very tough. A handy piece of metal to help get the job done, is the plow.

鋸.story: A handsaw is a piece of metal that helps you fix up the place you reside in.

錐.story: I used a metal awl to drill right through this here turkey: it was so much easier than using a knife to cut it open!

鍬.story: The hoe is a metal tool used in preparation for the autumn harvest.

鋲.story: In medieval times, soldiers used metal rivets to build their suits of armor.

錫.story: Tin is soft, bends easily, and melts at a low temperature. Hence tin is written as the metal that is easy to work with.

錨.story: An anchor is metal planted like a seedling.

釘.story: A nail is a metal spike.

鑓.story: A javelin is a piece of metal used for dispatching enemies – or athletics judges if they’re not careful.

鋒.story: A pointy (see my explanation in 峰 峰 (#1683)) bit of metal is a sword's point.

鎚.story: The hammer is the same as the 槌 (#2477), except it's made out of metal.

鉦.story: The church carillion was composed of metal bells that informed when it was the correct time to go to church.

錆.story: The easiest place to spot rust is when it grows on blue metal. All of my cars have been blue, and as soon as the first red rust appears, its off to the scrapheap.

鍾.story: 1) Metal seems more heavy when it's balled up in a cluster.2) Fans cluster around the stage at the heavy metal concert.

鋏.story: On the St. Bernard assembly line, the dogs pass by and the workers clip their fur with metal scissors.

閃.story: The flasher hung out by the gates. Whenever someone emerged, the flasher opened his cloak, flashed the unsuspecting person, and ran off in a flash!

悶.story: The gates suddenly slam shut, squashing your heart. Needless to say, this is agony.

閤.story: If you can't fit through the gates due to your size, try the side gate.

霞.story: Jimi Hendrix works as a weather forcaster in his spare time. Today he predicts a (purple) haze.

翰.story: How to obtain quills for free: Wait for a misty day, then under cover of the mist creep up on an unsuspecting bird and quickly cover it with your umbrella. The bird will flap around wildly trying to escape and while doing so will shed a number of feathers. You can use these as quills.

斡.story: Under the auspices of the local observatory, we looked at the Big Dipper on a misty night, huddled under an umbrella.

鞍.story: A saddle is leather that helps you relax on horseback.

鞭.story: There's a leather section in the convenience store now – that's where I got this whip.

鞘.story: A scabbard is a leather sheath that should to resemble the blade it's going to hold.

鞄.story: The first briefcase was a piece of leather used to wrap documents.

靭.story: A leather blade would make for a poor sword, because it's too pliable.

鞠.story: Wtf terminate? This is "ball". Use "leather ball" for keyword, imagine a leather american football packed with bound up rice.

顛.story: The DNA evidence reveals the truth about the crime but its too late to overturn the sentence now - they already chopped off the innocent prisoners head.

穎.story: A cheap brush tip is just wheat attached to the head of a spoon.

頗.story: Donald Trump is exceedingly wealthy, but wears a really bad toupee -- he has an exceedingly large collection of pelts to place on his head.

頌.story: Accolades are bestowed on your head in public.

頚.story: Homeless in Shinjuku, February: I keep my neck & throat warm by wrapping toilet paper around it, but my head is still cold.

餐.story: Remember that dazzling evening where you found the magic wand and used it on your crotch to make it bigger? Well this time you use the wand to disguise your little guy as food so that she thinks it's a repast. 燦 (#2543).

饗.story: After journeying the world wide, I returned to my hometown and was met with an incredible feast.

蝕.story: To enjoy watching the eclipse, you go on a picnic with your friends. But due to the dim light, you accidentally pick up and eat an insect.

飴.story: Of all the foods, sweets are definitely the ones kids put on a pedestal.

駕.story: This man is too heavy! We can't move the stretcher! Quick, add a team of horses to the ambulance!

騨.story: Being just black and white, the piebald is a simple horse.

馳.story: Use a scorpion to make a horse rush.

騙.story: This character is だます, which means to trick or fool someone. The Greeks tricked (cheated) the Trojans by hiding in the Trojan Horse, which actually had a secret door from which the hidden soldiers would emerge. It was a brilliant tactic that would be recorded in the tomes of history.

馴.story: The guy who said that you can take a horse to a river, but you can't make it drink obviously has never encountered a tame horse.

駁.story: Wolverine's had charges placed on him for murdering a horse, but he make's a rebuttal stating that he couldn't have been in two different places at the same time (i.e. There cannot exist two Wolverines). He was having dinner with his Aunt Margaret at the time, it's impossible.

駈.story: The team of horses slowed to a gallop as they started up the hill.

驢.story: The team of horses is nervously asking a tiger not to eat them. "Don't worry", says the tiger, "over in that paddyfield I can see my favourite dish – donkey!

鰻.story: A fish meditates on a mandala to gain the electric power of an eel.

鯛.story: The sea bream （たい） is a fish that often goes around the circumference of a 回転寿司（かいてんずし） a number of たいmes.

鰯.story: This is a weak fish -- you just open a can of sardines and there they are, weak and defenseless, ready to be eaten.

鱒.story: Trout are a fish often revered for their beauty (especially rainbow trout).

鮭.story: Salmon are fish that go over ivy trying to get back to their breeding grounds, killing bears along the way.

鮪.story: Tuna is the fish that posesses the most toxins (heavy metals, pesticides, mercury).

鮎.story: A fish arrives at the fortune-teller's who, without looking, says "Welcome, Sweet Smelt". "That's amazing", says the fish, "how did you know I was a sweet smelt?" "Well, most fish smell bad, but you smelt sweet.

鯵.story: The horse mackerel is a fish that must visit both its horse and mackerel relatives.

鱈.story: Cod is a fish that is packed in snow to reach the inland parts of Japan.

鯖.story: Holy mackarel! That fish just turned blue!

鮫.story: Ever noticed how tiny fish will often mingle around a shark for protection?

鰹.story: The bonito is a fish with strict preparation procedures for making 出汁（だし） and 鰹節（かつおぶし）.

鰍.story: Fish, autumn: Old man to his son: "You are bullheaded if you think you can catch a bullhead fish in the middle of autumn. It's out of season!

鰐.story: Dude! What happened to your chin?" "Well, I was out fishing...

鮒.story: The crucian fish adheres strongly to Crucianism principles.

鮨.story: Japanese consider fish to be most delicious when eaten as sushi. (Note: In practice, sushi is more often written 寿司, but occasionally 鮨).

鰭.story: Fish, old man, sun: An ominous fish fin approaches the old man, who went for a swim as the sun was going down. Soon, he'll sleep with the fishes.

鴎.story: A bird that goes to the inland wards for food is the seagull.

鵬.story: Companion, bird: Roc, the mythical bird, was searching for a companion for as long as he existed. Little did he know that he was the only one of his kind.

鸚.story: The parakeet is a bird that acts like a suckling infant when it drinks from the water dropper.

鵡.story: A parrot is a bird of the warrior, for example pirates.

鵜.story: [+brose] The cormorant was historically used in Japan and China to catch fish. The fisher would use some rope or something to tie its throat so that it could only swallow small fish. If it caught something too big to swallow, it would take it back to the fisher's boat and the fisher would take it out. This particular cormorant is going after bigger and bigger prey - but one day it goes too far, and tries to swallow your little brother! Imagine trying to yank your brother out of its throat.

鷺.story: The heron bird took the path to heroin, regrettably.

鷲.story: Concerning, bird: The US senate had a meeting concerning the eagle. Although symbol of the US, this bird is close to extinction.

鴨.story: Due to its waterproof armor, the wild duck is a bird that resurfaces even if you push it underwater.

鳶.story: The kite falcon is a majestic bird that flies in the sky as fast as an arrow. So much so that its feathers are often used to make arrows.

梟.story: The owl, being wise, is hiding its tail feathers in a tree so that its prey can't tell what kind of bird it is.

塵.story: A deer stomps on the soil and dust rises from the ground. (big ups mantixen).

麒.story: A giraffe is like a deer except that when it plays chess it has a better overview of the board.

舅.story: (from astridtops) "Real men don't use mortars", said my father-in-law, as he began to grind some stones down using only his fists.

鼠.story: You are chasing the famous three blind mice and try to catch them by slamming a mortar on top of them. Success! You can see their three tails sticking out from under the mortar. In fact the impact has broken the first two tails, as you can see from the sharp angle they bend at, and the two drops (blood) on each. The third tail still curves nicely though, and hence has no drops of blood on it.

鑿.story: This is pretty much only used in the word 鑿(のみ), chisel. Missile + metal is obviously a hammer being swung. The needle is the chisel and the mortar represents the impressions left (bored) by the chisel. For some reason the chisel is used to make a row of such impressions here, and the work is done in such a difficult place that it has to be done upside down. Perhaps this is some sort of sabotage, done in a place that is not readily visible to the outside.

艘.story: In military terms, a small craft is a boat that only has enough room for a mortar that fires walking sticks - which is pretty useless unless you hit the enemy in the crotch.

瞑.story: When you wake up in Hades, you close the eyes and try to pretend it isn't happening.

暝.story: Hades is normally very dark, and even when the sun shines in it is still murky.

坐.story: The cave was too dark for my tastes, so I went out to sit in mediation.

朔.story: On the first day of the month a mountain goat lets out a "Baah" as it jumps over the moon.

曳.story: The day seems to drag when it keeps you from having a fiesta.

洩.story: (re: Katsuo) If you tow water in a wheelbarrow, some of it is sure to dribble out.

彗.story: A comet flew by and knocked down two bushes, so I went out there and swept up the mess, cursing astrological bodies along the way.

慧.story: Comet, heart: Heisig: "The astute reader will notice that the second stroke in the broom element of comet doesn't pass through. The astute reader will take this observation to heart".

爾.story: Story by katsuo (but not yet posted) - At a small concert for the Beatles I was hanging eight towels from the celing. I asked Paul if he wanted me to stitch them together but he said "Let It Be".

嘉.story: Add a drum when you really want to applaud.

兇.story: The evil villain's favorite hobby is breaking human legs.

兜.story: The overly-cautious white geek protects his entire upper body with a special helmet he constructed out of two cardboard boxes, unfortunately his human legs could still be easy targets for bullies.

靄.story: The muchacho about to give a speech to his audience, only to be interrupted by a sudden rain, accompanied by very thick mist.

劫.story: kalpa is a Sanskrit word for a long period of time, sort of like "aeon." Once a kalpa has gone (passed), there will be no more fossil fuels for power.

歎.story: (I use "kanji" for the scarecrow primitive.) I bemoan the huge number of kanji I must memorize, but I plod on despite my tired yawns.

輿.story: I hop into my palanquin, my car of sorts, such that I may be transported to my next location of entertainment.

歪.story: In the debate, your political opponent's has such a warped sense of perspective, that he believes the negative is actually correct.

翠.story: You're so jaded by the time you graduate that when you finally spread your wings, your feathers are all jade green.

黛.story: A good substitute for black is blue-black, like the color women try to substitute for their black eyebrows with a pencil.

鼎.story: Here we have two people sitting on chairs, trying to set up their camera on a tripod and periodically checking the viewfinder with their eyes.

鹵.story: The fortune-teller tells Wolverine that in a past life, she sees him covered in rocksalt from working in a salt mine.

鹸.story: Lye is white like rocksalt and can be broken up with an ice pick.

虔.story: That tiger at the zoo was so reserved. He didn't say so much as one sentence." "Um, you know tigers can't talk, right?

燕.story: Twenty birds (swallows) are perched at the north exit (北口) of the station. I light a fire underneath them, and as they wilt and fall in the heat, passing commuters swallow them whole. Well, they are swallows.

嘗.story: There are things in the outhouse that may appear delicious, and you may even want to lick them, but I assure you: they ain't delicious.

殆.story: A pedestal in an Indiana Jones movie is littered with the bones of people who almost seized the treasure.

牌.story: Mahjong tiles, to the best of my understanding have only one side and are considered a lowly use of time.

覗.story: Sneak preview - peek - director lets you see his new movie - 店を覗く（のぞく） - have a quick noze/look in a shop (nozoku).

齟.story: [This kanji is included in RTK 3 third edition with the keyword 'disagree'] "Stop!" yelled the factory manager. The assembly line on the floor above was disagreeing with the assembly line below on whether to output shovels or shelves. The manager had them split the task.
