齬.story: [This kanji is included in RTK 3 third edition with the keyword 'discord'] [continuing the story from disagree (#40799)] The factory manager thought he'd resolved the disagreement between the two assembly lines, but there was still some discord among those on the floor below making the shovels. "Stop! If you don't cut it out, I will come down there and knock your teeth crooked!" the manager angrily yelled.

秦.story: (thx Katsuo) The so-called 'mighty' Qin dynasty died a nasty death from starvation because they focused on growing bonsai instead of wheat.

雀.story: There are relatively few turkeys compared to the widely familiar sparrow.

隼.story: The peregrine falcon is the fastest animal in the world. It can reach speeds of over 322 km/h in a dive - over ten times as fast as a turkey!

耀.story: Rays of light hit the futon, making it shimmer. Think maybe somebody wet the futon last night..

夷.story: When passing through Ebisu in Tokyo, (one stop south of Shibuya) you see an ebisu (= a barbarian/savage) whose pet St. Bernard has swallowed his bow; you can see the shape of the bow sticking through its skin. Notes: 1. I'm locating this in Ebisu to reinforce the sound; the place name Ebisu is actually written with different kanji. 2. As Meconium mentions, stroke order is 一、弓、人.

嚢.story: Grass skirt, middle, crown: The girl wearing the grass skirt had a cyst growing in the middle of her head, seeming like a crown. A sign she will be the new village elder, I heard later.

暢.story: The monkey is carefree with his piggy bank, tossing it at whatever financial opportunity he stumbles upon.

廻.story: A dishonest taxi driver is circling to increase the fare -- trying to stretch out the ride, going around the block many times.

欣.story: I feel elation when I realize the axe murderer is lacking his axe.

毅.story: A stalwart sow stands up against a missile.

斯.story: Tip: Learn "this" 斯 and "that" 其 at the same time. ("that", 其 , is not in Heisig, but is probably more common than 斯). Stories: This bushel basket comes with an axe to open it, but that one doesn't.

匙.story: After you get the wooden spoon in the "egg & spoon" race another competitor explains that you need to hold the spoon "just so".

匡.story: After the revolution, the king was put into a box so that the government could be set straight.

肇.story: Founding of a nation is usually done by the taskmasters in charge behind closed doors. They sign some papers with their writing brushes and voila..

麿.story: Bending over constantly to cut all those woodblocks has given Utamaro a bad back. Now he smokes hemp while he works to ease the pain in in his spine.

叢.story: I have a huge conglomerate (collection) of old books I'm looking to get rid of. They're not in any particular order... some are upside down in a row, some are soiled... just look through them and take whatever you want.

肴.story: Tip: "snack" or "appetizer" would be better keywords for this kanji.

斐.story: The murderer who carved symmetrical patterns into all his victims was sentenced life in a jailcell. (thanks tomusan).

卿.story: British magistrates wear wigs made of silver hair. But picture an eccentric magistrate who instead wears a silver hare on his head.

翫.story: In the beginning you learn by fiddling with things.

於.story: Image: An Arctic explorer frozen within ice, within his hands are an umbrella and a compass.

套.story: The hackneyed hangover cure is to have "some hair of the dog that bit you.

叛.story: The half that was anti- started a rebellion.

尖.story: A small tip on something large creates a sharp point.

壷.story: The samurai's crock was so old it was a crowned a heritage item of Asia, and he wouldn't sell it.

叡.story: Magic wand, crown, 1-eyed valley, crotch: The archeologist was searching for the birthplace of the homo sapience. Wearing his magic wand and his divining crown, he was able to located it in the 1-eyed valley, somewhere in Bolivia. His crotch got all excited, thinking on all the publicity of finding the birthplace of homo sapience.

酋.story: I have used Red Bull as a primitive since 猶 (#1438), so now it is easy to remember the chieftain's name: Chief Red Bull!

鴬.story: The nightingale is a bird that goes to a schoolhouse at night to learn to sing.

赫.story: Incandescent red is naturally twice as bright as ordinary red (赤). Alternatively, this is a picture of spreading (already doubled), incandescent red fire. Note: This is used by far most commonly to write 赫(あか)い, although dictionaries do not recognize such a reading (except for kanji dictionaries).

臥.story: If a person has retainers, then he can spend his life supinate (i.e. lying on his back doing nothing). (note: for the writing order think: SuPinate = Slave-Person).

甥.story: A nephew is someone you can watch grow into a man over his lifetime.

瓢.story: I enter a ballot to try to win a melon, but end up with a gourd.

琵.story: The two kings play their biwa, comparing each other's skill.

琶.story: When she's playing the lute between your two balls Japanese censors mosaic it out.

叉.story: Think of this as "tuning fork" (音叉). Then, touching a vibrating tuning fork against a crotch causes it to drip drops.

乖.story: oppose: The opposing army of one thousand went north up the mountain to strike Hamlet in his castle up the top.

畠.story: You see a white dove about to land in a paddyfield, and, believing that field to be under water, expect to hear a "plop". But the plop doesn't come, so you think to yourself, "Ah, that must be a dry field".

圃.story: My offspring is supposed to be weeding my vegetable patch, but he keeps running off to play. So I put an electric fence around the veggie patch to pent him in. Now he's hard at work in there!

丞.story: If water completely covers the floor, you will need a helping hand to clean it up.

亮.story: A tall girl in a translucent mini skirt... Hell yes.

胤.story: The cocoon like piece of flesh between human legs can produce blood relatives.

疏.story: The zoo needed a transcription of the accident report involving the infant caught in the flood.

膏.story: Your body parts will become tall if you apply a special ointment.

魁.story: The Ghostbusters were pioneers, being the first people ever to capture a ghost in a measuring cup.

馨.story: Voice, missile, incense: Before they were going to launch the missile, they were having a service to beg favor of the Gods. Then, when they lit the incense, a booming voice came out of nowhere: "Hmmm... this smell is great, no, ambrosial. Really worthy of the Gods...

牒.story: Tip: New primitive: Let Tarzan = generation + tree -- because Tarzan lives with several generations of his family at the top of a tree. (This combination appears five times: 葉 (#228), 蝶 (#521), 喋 (#2158), 諜 (#2726), label (FRAME 2926)). Story: You notice Tarzan is wearing his shirt inside-out and explain to him that clothes are one-sided and that he can tell by looking at the label.

瞥.story: My sharp eye caught a glimpse of the confidential information before it went through the shredder.

睾.story: Tip: primitives given in the book are: blood + happiness. But should be: drop + eye (/net) + happiness. Story: As you squeeze the last drop out of your testicles you go cross-eyed with happiness.

巫.story: Craft, assembly line: The sorceress was very good at her craft. She magicked an assembly line to produce all kinds of sorceress' merchandise. Shrewed businesswoman, I'd say.

敦.story: A taskmaster can be empathetic if she receives something.

奎.story: (From Greek mythology). When Perseus goes to rescue Andromeda, he finds he's made a mistake. What looked from a distance like a beautiful maiden chained to a rock turns out to be a St. Bernard tangled up in some ivy. (Andromeda was chained up a bit further down on another beach).

翔.story: If a sheep had feathers, it could soar.

皓.story: The revelation brought back by the dove left Noah beaming -- the flood waters were receding.

黎.story: tenebrous" = "dark" or "obscure." In tenebrous nights, millet is found tied in slipknots, in crop circles.

赳.story: Run, cornucopia: The thief was bold, but stupid. He was running away with the cornucopia he just stole from the feudal lord. However, he was leaving an easy track to follow as the cornucopia was pouring out its riches. So, bold, but stupid.

已.story: This character would be the sign of the snake if the last stroke didn't stop short.

棘.story: The belt of thorns around a tree is doubled in a thornbush.

祟.story: Beings exit the spirit world through the altar when you cast a spell.

甦.story: Grow late, life: It had nearly grown too late to resucitate the half-drowned man, but a passer-by was able to breath life back into him, thus resucitating him.

剪.story: Lazy guide to pruning: Grab a dagger and slash everything in front.

躾.story: With the right upbringing, you might become somebody beautiful.

夥.story: There are many fruits when they're plentiful.

鼾.story: If you snore, your nose becomes dry. I try to remember the slightly different bottom part by wanting to hit the snoring nose with two hands but can't quite reach. KUN yomi reading いびき.

陀.story: At the pinnacle of enlightenment, Shakyamuni Buddha had the ability to bend common household spoons.

粁.story: If you mark each meter with a grain of rice, after 1,000 grains of rice you have measured out a kilometre.

糎.story: A rin of a meter is a centimeter.

粍.story: The portion of a meter the width of fur is a millimeter.

噸.story: Unsuccessful dieter's excuse: "If I put anything in my mouth, I immediately put on a ton.

哩.story: Mouth, computer: The mouth on my navigation computer tells me it's only a mile left to my destination.

浬.story: Water, computer: Some water leaked into my navigation computer and now it expresses all distances in nautical miles. Very annoying!!

吋.story: If you GLUE your MOUTH shut, you can't open it one INCH.

呎.story: Mouth, shakuhachi: The hookers mouth was huge and also she was very skilled in 'shakuhachi': she could hold up to one foot.

梵.story: This is a Brahman, a fully enlightened one. He's sitting in front of a grove of trees, legs open (looks like wind), just meditating. You run up to him asking him all sorts of crazy questions, and he looks at you and smiles. "Brah, man, just chill, man. Braaaaah#." Apparently he's a surfer brahman. You ask him the meaning of life, and he smiles, and waits...waits...waits...until a bit of wind blows by. He lets out a small fart in the wind, and nods knowingly at you.

薩.story: [+mantixen] A bodhisattva visits The Pinnacle to provide flowers and meditation products to the unenlightened.

菩.story: Phonetic ボ. Bo tree is a sacred buddhist fig tree. The lovely smell from the flowering bo tree wafts down onto the meditating monks who are silent as though muzzled. 菩薩・ぼさつ bodhisattva.

唖.story: Babble is what comes out of Asian people's mouths until you learn their language.

牟.story: If you elbow a cow it's will moo. (or alternatively, a cow mooing, the sound being somewhat like ム).

迦.story: You wanna drive a Sanskrit ka? Just add it to the road.

珈.story: This and 琲 (#2968) only seem to occur in the word 珈琲 (コーヒー) where they are used phonetically. So, in practice, it might be easier to remember them as a pair and not worry about their literal meanings. STORY: For 珈: An assassin adds poison to the king's coffee. For 琲: However, fearing a plot against him, the king, summons a hapless convict from a jail cell to sample the coffee first.

琲.story: The king is in the jail cell and is trying to escape by picking the lock with his beaded hairpin.

檜.story: It used to be that for a meeting [old] you'd meet for a day to get the small details pent in. Even then such meetings were still held under the Japanese cypress [old].

轡.story: This is a picture of a horse cart (車) from which the reins (糸) go to the mouth (口) of the horse, in which is the bit.

淵.story: The abyss [old] used to be the water you were pushed into if you lost in the arm wrestling match. (the primitive to the right screams two guys arm wrestling on a table, any one else see it?)

伍.story: Mr T knows that the Roman Numeral for five is V.

什.story: Mr T also knows that the Roman Numeral for ten is X.

萬.story: This is actually the old ten thousand yen bill in Japan - Jiminy Cricket surrounded by a wreath of flowers. It's pretty uncommon to see nowadays since it was only in print for a few days immediately after the war (MacArthur wanted a way to make sure that even the rich kept their atrocities in their consciences).

邁.story: I see lots of 10,000 yen notes just lying on the road and think, "Should I stop and pick them up?" But then I realise they are old 10,000's (i.e. worthless) and decide I’ll just pass through.

燭.story: Fire, voiced - water: After the incident where the insect made a pitiful voiced sound, you decide to free it. Immediately it is attracted to the candlelight and flies into the fire. Bugger!

逞.story: Tough guys like to display there force on the road.

燈.story: In old style street lamps, to light the fire you had to ascend them.

裡.story: In the old days, instead of having a micro-computer sewn into the suit of the master spy, a whole computer was carried in the back of his cloak, although it was clearly obvious that he was a spy. "What's that um.. enormous computer doing in the back your cloak?

薗.story: Parks in Japan are designed around water, rocks and trees. A park with flowers is considered to be an alternate park.

鋪.story: At an alternative shop you can buy strange items like metal dogtags from wars, active grenades, torture sets, etc.

嶋.story: The bird got tired of the mountain he lived on, so now he's flying away searching for an alternative island.

峯.story: The alternative summit is so steep that the mountain is above you rather than beside you. People usually just go with the regular summit.

埜.story: A grove now grows on the soil of [old] plains.

龍.story: An ancient Japanese dragon, beautiful and terrifying. Here it is depicted standing on a piece of meat (its prey) and a description is written on the right margin. It is said to be like a snake that has three toes on its feet and can sometimes use its head as a flamethrower (kind of like a sling, but with fire instead of stones). (Note: The Japanese dragon has three toes, unlike other Asian dragons. Asian dragons generally don't breath fire, but Godzilla does, and it is supposed to be a dragon!)

寵.story: An old dragon's house enjoys a lot of patronage as a modern tourist attraction. (thanks mantixen).

聾.story: A Chinese dragon flying overhead can cause deafness to your ears.

慾.story: The old longing is a 欲 欲 (#855) of the heart.

嶽.story: A long time ago the Monkey King was kept in prison under a mountain Point.

國.story: Russia, an old country, has everyone pent-in and drinking vodka saying "aaaaaaaaa". See mantixen's story, 或 (#2234).

脛.story: The body part that gets wet when you wade through the sewers (a crafted flood underneath the ground) is your shin (thanks brian44).

勁.story: The powerful stench coming from the sewers is formidable.

祀.story: Old evil altar, sign of snake: In the ancient temple, they found and old evil altar with the sign of the snake imprinted on it. What evil could be enshrined within it???

祓.story: Old evil altar, chihuahua with extra leg: They opened up the old evil altar in the ancient temple. Nothing inside. But suddenly, their chihuahua grew an extra leg, and started speaking in a strange language. Time for an exorcism, one would say.

躇.story: People with wooden legs are renowned for dithering over whether to decorate them with a drop of paint or not.

壽.story: A samurai wearing a broken crown crafted an inch-thick floor under which to hide with his mouth glued, giving him longevity as his enemies failed to find him.

躊.story: I hesitate to have a wooden leg fitted as I'm not sure how it will affect my longevity.

饅.story: A bit of old food is stuck on one of my mandalas. What could it be? I scrape it off and taste it . . . Hmm, bean jam, I reckon.

嘔.story: The mouth on the left eats a whole box full of goods and then starts to retch them out again.
